column8: The game is relaxing and enjoyable, perfect for those who love interior design and decorating.
column9: The snapping and placement mechanics are frustrating and inaccurate.

column8: The game has a lot of potential and is expected to improve with future updates.
column9: The game has numerous bugs and crashes frequently.

column8: There are some bugs and optimization issues, but they are manageable and expected in early access.
column9: The game is not optimized well, leading to performance issues.

column8: The game offers a variety of customization options for furniture and room design.
column9: There is a lack of customization options for furniture and room dimensions.

column8: The story mode includes interesting puzzles and tasks that keep the gameplay fresh.
column9: The controls and user interface are not intuitive or user-friendly.

column8: The sandbox mode allows for creative freedom and extensive customization.
column9: The game feels incomplete and lacks content.

column8: The graphics and lighting are aesthetically pleasing and add to the overall experience.
column9: The story mode and mini-games are not engaging or fun.

column8: The game is compared favorably to other interior design games like The Sims and House Flipper.
column9: The game is not suitable for realistic room planning due to restrictive mechanics.

column8: Players appreciate the ability to mod and the potential for future content through updates.
column9: The graphics and visual design are not appealing to many players.

column8: Some players have experienced issues with controls and UI, but overall find the game intuitive and fun.
column9: The game has potential but needs significant updates and improvements.

column9:
[b]SuperPower 3[/b] is unfortunately a huge disappointment and a complete technical failure. It's a modernized version of a classic strategy game (a global geopolitical simulator), based on real data from various spheres of individual countries, giving players the opportunity to manage and operate on the international stage with a freely chosen, realistically reproduced country â€“ battling others for world domination.

The title certainly isn't for everyone, especially in its current state. It's a highly complex strategy game aimed primarily at fans of its predecessors, including strategy games focused on managing an entire country politically, economically, and militarily â€“ which isn't as simple a task as you might imagine. If you think that operating even the most powerful superpower is enough to easily conquer the entire world, you're wrong.

What completely depresses a devoted SuperPower fan upon seeing the latest version is that, aside from the graphics and the modified interface, nothing has really changed for the better. My excitement when I saw the announcement of the next installment was immense, but it completely vanished when you started playing it â€“ a technical mess where hardly anything works at all is the mildest description of what you get. You can play, of course, but it's an adventure for those with strong nerves and a strong will, which will be tested repeatedly throughout.

The game's fundamental systems don't work, so even if you create a "gold-flooded utopian state that trumps everything and everyone on the planet, with no taxes, and maximum government support for everything, it will still collapse over time," while the world's "shallow ends" with negative balance continue to flourish... (!?). On top of that, bugs pile up, capable of popping up at any moment, shutting down the game/freezing it permanently, deleting important saves, and so on. After a while, even the most persistent say enough is enough. It's better to switch to another product in this category without wasting time and energy â€“ because that's not what games are about.

Worse still, the game's creator has apparently done the same thing, as they haven't done anything to patch this title since 2022 â€“ they've essentially abandoned it, giving a thumbs-up to those who trusted them by paying an astronomical price on Steam for their product, only to receive a game in early development.

I strongly advise against purchasing it, and if by some miracle you decide to test its gameplay, I encourage you to check out the websites of official third-party digital game stores â€“ you can buy a key/subscription there for a fraction of the price (which is what I did).

[quote]I encourage everyone to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32785706/ ]curator[/url] to stay up-to-date on new titles reviewed.[/quote]

column9:
I bought it! But I have a huge list of complaints!

I know you can't make a game for every player, but here's the thing, Superpower 2 was a great game and started the franchise, the 3rd one, it seems, is just a more complex copy of the 2nd.

You basically have no control over many aspects of "society," which leaves you with only 2 basic missions: earn money and buy armies to invade your friends.

You might even think that the subversion mechanisms, treaties, and "socioeconomic" options would be more dynamic and intelligent, but no, they aren't.

You have even less control over your economy (besides it becoming very complex without necessarily giving you advantages or creating new things), you have even less control over treaties, even less control over secret operations, even less control over society, all without significant evolution in the game's overall intelligence.

It's become a kind of enhanced RISK with sliders that don't serve much purpose other than generating more micromanagement burden. In the end, it doesn't offer significant advantages or new possibilities for interaction with the game, such as becoming the stage for the next great technological revolution, becoming a cultural center, spreading your culture worldwideâ€”in short, there's no point in even mentioning it because none of that is possible in the game anyway.

I hope they greatly improve the game, because it has potential, and please! SIMPLIFY the management screens!

column9:
Superpower 2 was my youth. You set up communism in Canada, declare war on Australia, and all this with an interface that's easy to understand at first glance. Fun, simple, and without unnecessary hassle.
ğŸ§  And then Superpower 3 comes out. Sure, it's not as user-friendly, a bit rough around the edges in places, with an interface that feels like it belongs in an economics major. But you know, if you dig in a little, it starts to draw you in. There are more features, more settings, and the world reacts in a new way. Not everything works perfectly, but it's clear they tried to make it deeper.
ğŸ“ˆ I'm glad the developers haven't abandoned the gameâ€”they're fixing it, improving it, adding content. And there's potential hidden within this crude shell. If you're a fan of Superpower 2 and willing to put in a little patience, Superpower 3 starts to feel similar. Not after 5 minutes, but after a couple of hours.
ğŸ’¬ Conclusion: Yes, Superpower 3 is more difficult and not perfect yet, but it's not the "crap" everyone's calling it. This is a chance for something great. You just need to give her some time and love.

column9: The game feels very raw. There's very little content, and it quickly becomes boring. Bugs are everywhereâ€”control glitches. It feels like the project was rushed, without proper testing. I hope the developers continue working and polish it, because the idea is good, but the execution so far leaves much to be desired. The interface is awkward, and the Russian translation is poor. I'm requesting a refund.

I refunded it. Then I bought it again. Out of guilt... and hope.

SuperPower 3 isnâ€™t the sequel to SP2 we waited for â€” itâ€™s more like a downgraded prototype.
Character creation is pointless, the interface is clunky, the map is blurry and GPU-hungry (just give us Google Maps at this point), and core mechanics like nuclear warfare, regime change, and economic control are overly restricted or missing.

The AI barely reacts to anything, unless you blink wrong â€” then it declares war.
And yetâ€¦ I still want this to work. I love the idea, but right now it feels like a missed opportunity buried in lag and confusion.

Verdict: Only buy it if youâ€™re a hardcore geopolitics fan â€” and even then, pack some patience.

column8: Ho iniziato con l italia, arrivo ad avere un GDP di 17 trilioni ed un incasso di 3,5 trilioni, vado a salvare e rimane impallato per mezz ora allora faccio alt f4 visto che aveva preso possesso del computer, rientro ed il salvataggio non esiste piu... ah Ã¨ la terza volta che mi succede e devo ricominciare, disinstallato subito e chi in caso volesse fare una pazzia ed acquistare questo scempio gli suggerisco di andarsi a comprare una dose di eroina piuttosto che buttare soldi su questo gioco
column9: I started with Italy, I got to have a GDP of 17 trillion and a revenue of 3.5 trillion, I go to save and it remains stuck for half an hour then I do alt f4 since it had taken over the computer, I go back and the save no longer exists... ah it's the third time it's happened to me and I have to start again, uninstalled immediately and whoever wants to do something crazy and buy this disgrace I suggest you go and buy a dose of heroin rather than throw money on this game

column9:
Hello, and this is my personal opinion right off the bat. I bought this game and deeply regret it.
The only thing I got from the second SuperPower is the general concept. I recommend forgetting that this game even exists.

(1) All mechanics are terribly cut.
(2) The game is extremely unstable.
(3) There's not much to do.
(4) The developers seem to have given up after the initial failure.

And my personal sadness is that you only have two hours to try this game.
And in the end, I couldn't return it.

column9:
The game isn't as scary as it's made out to be. If you haven't played Part 2, then getting to know Part 3 won't be as painful. I think the interface wasn't designed for phones, but simply to give everything a modern look. Part 2 was a calculator interface, while Part 3 is a modern interface. Overall, it's even more intuitive than Part 2. There are still some bugs, for example, the interface sometimes disappears when you start selecting a country, as does the save interface, which forces you to restart the game.

Here's a list of the game's major bugs at the moment:

1) If you set the economy sector to public, manually set imports, and then change it back to private, you can have any amount of income at the beginning of the game. For example, at the beginning of the game, playing as Burundi, I set tourism imports to maximum. Then I changed it to private. The income was $3 trillion. That is, hundreds of times more than the country's GDP. A critical bug that breaks the entire economy.

2) After loading a save, the president's avatar disappears permanently. Moreover, I can't save the president's name. Because of this, all presidents always have the same name. In fact, reloading the game seems to break the game. The start is almost normal, but then it's terrible.

3) If I start creating an army and then reload the game, the army creation process is buggy. Because of this, I have to cancel the process.

4) The game does everything with a delay.

5) Tanks and helicopters navigate the ocean without any problems.

6) After annexing a country, the war with it never ends. And it always appears as an enemy in the interface, even though it has neither territories nor an army. And there was a message about the annexation.

I should also add that the auto-saves are annoying. Why do I have to create a new auto-save every time I exit the game? They accumulate there, and then I have to delete them. I need to enable a checkbox that disables auto-saves, so that all auto-saves are saved into one save.

And the option to occupy regions is completely inconvenient. There's no "occupy all regions" option, so you have to claim each region individually. It's boring.

Overall, the game's concept is good, but the sheer number of bugs makes it incredibly difficult to play.

column9: The game had everything to be good. But it has several bug problems... especially in war mode where commanding troops is completely bugged and practically impossible. Troops, ships, etc. get stuck in transit as an example of the various bug problems. The game has been abandoned by the developers, with no bug fixes or updates. The game is unplayable. I played beyond the minimum time limit that Steam offers to test the game and detect its problems, and I didn't get a refund. I felt robbed by a product that is sold with problems. It shouldn't even be put on sale in the state the game is in. There should be a quality control process that tests the game before putting it on sale, exposing its bugs/errors. Otherwise, it's fraudulent sales. I lost money on such an unplayable game due to errors and bugs. The minimum trial time for a refund doesn't offer the opportunity to learn about the problems found in the game.

Rating as of February 16, 2024

Absolutely do not buy this.

They released a version that's embarrassing enough to even call Early Access, and there have been no updates since January 2023.

I bought this with high hopes because of my fond memories of Super Power 2, but it's a piece of trash that left me with nightmares.

If there had been even occasional updates, I would have thought it would get better, but it's a game that has been abandoned without any updates.

column8:
I really loved the second superpower and even with the bad reviews wanted to try the 3rd. NOT Worth it, when they say runs bad THEY MEAN IT. your p[opulation continuously gets more and more unemplyed, you can invest billions and trillions into economy and it wont change, like its just a flawed unfinished part of the game, soldiers and battles make no sense and you randomly get messages about iceland annexing ireland or provinces being taken over or your territories being annexed but its just glitches and NOTHING is happening. This game isnt just unfinished, its absolutely flawed to the core. The entire deomographics wich is 1 of the 4 parts of this game is soo soo flawed your population will either skyrocket or emmigrate nomatter what you choose as desicisions based on whatever the game predetermined it would do. Trade with other nations and treaties dont work either except embargo however it isnt even listed as embargo its a trade deal wich you only realize is embargo (the opposite) when you realise the other country hates you for it, you can't actualyl tell from the economy tab however since its glitched and makes no difference

Through a quick online search you can find out this game is abandoned half finished in a alpha, not even beta stage. The company knew it was trash and released it anyways to make back the funds it lost in the little development they started and there are tons of messages online in many forums about how even though the company promised to fix the glitches after the release with the funds i guess it thought it would make from the release, the actual employees say they gave up, quit, didn't do it, etc.. due to absolutely terrible salaries among others. 

DO NOT buy this game, you may as well throw your money down the drain, even downloading it, the simple dfownload glitched and crashed steam 4 times for me, thats some never before seen levels of glitchy

column8: Essentially ended up being a scam. Devs and publisher promised a lot and the result was a buggy and completely unfinished mess. Then proceeded to just abandon the game after almost no updates after all the hype for it. My only regret is that I really tried to give the game a chance, which put me over the 2 hour refund limit. No reason to buy this at this point, it was completely abandoned after almost no updates. Itâ€™s around an early alpha level of development in its current state. Do not waste your money on this. It is the epitome of what is frustrating a lot of people with gaming companies nowadays - unfinished, buggy releases, taken to the extreme in this case. Superpower 2 is pretty fun, if old, and has some interesting mods. Go buy that instead.

column9:
Damn, finish the game, you idiots... BRING BACK MY YOUTH! We used to play such awesome RP games in Superpower 2 when we were schoolchildren and students... BRING IT BACK!

It's been over a year since the last fix. I'm amazed at one thing: how could they ruin what was already there? Why couldn't they take the second game, give it the graphics, implement modern multiplayer (without opening ports and crashes), and add a couple of mechanics (like uprisings)? Moreover, modders have already added these mechanics to SP2...
There's a chance the developers will wake up someday and SP3 will become a good long-term project, but I've given up hope :( and there are so few good geopolitical games about the modern world.

En gros c'est superpower 2 avec moins de texte, plus de graphiques et de nouvelles mÃ©caniques de jeux. J'ai regarder beaucoup de gameplay sur youtube avant de l'acheter principalement a cause de l'avalanche d'avis nÃ©gatif et les joueurs sont en gÃ©nÃ©ral trop stupide pour comprendre le fonctionnement du jeux.

De ce que j'ai pu voir c'est exactement pareil que superpower 2 sauf que les champs de batailles sont prÃ©sentÃ© diffÃ©remment, on a la possibilitÃ© d'oppresser sa population, la production de ressource ainsi que le commerce a complÃ¨tement Ã©tÃ© retravailler ce qui rend le jeux plus intÃ©ressant. Les IA sont beaucoup plus rÃ©actives, elles produisent des unitÃ©s, annexe des territoires...etc...etc La stabilitÃ© est devenue un point encore plus important. La nouvelle interface qui comprend moins de texte et plus de graphique nous donne une meilleur idÃ©e de l'impacte de nos dÃ©cisions, par exemple si vous dÃ©cidez d'investir dans une ressource agricole un graphique vous indique la population disponible pour ce secteur ainsi que la quantitÃ© de terre arable, puis le rÃ©sultat de votre investissement.
Lâ€™amÃ©lioration des unitÃ©s est beaucoup mieux pensÃ©, on a plus la possibilitÃ© de construire un tank pourri qui ressemble a un char Leclerc, le skin du vÃ©hicule sera automatiquement en accord avec ses spÃ©cificitÃ©s, on peut mÃªme amÃ©liorÃ© l'infanterie et ainsi crÃ©er des bataillons spÃ©cialisÃ©es dans tel ou tel domaine, ce qui nous offre comme opportunitÃ© de contenir un ennemi beaucoup plus puissant avec une armÃ©e moins chÃ¨re en prenant l'avantage du terrain. Donc on peut se defendre et contenir un pays comme la chine avec un petit pays sans forcement dÃ©penser des milliard dans son armÃ©e.     

Le gros problÃ¨me de ce jeux est qu'il souffre d'un gros soucis de finition, au bout d'un moment Ã§a lag tellement que aucune de vos actions ne prennent effet ou l'interface qui ne rÃ©pond plus ce qui devient assez rapidement pÃ©nible et frustrant, le jeux n'a pas bÃ©nÃ©ficier de mis a jour depuis un bon moment et a l'air d'avoir Ã©tÃ© laissÃ© a l'abandon. 

MÃªme si je me suis fait rembourser je met un avis positif pour encourager les devs, ce jeux a besoins d'une bonne maj technique.
column9:
Basically, it's Superpower 2 with less text, more graphics, and new gameplay mechanics. I watched a lot of gameplay videos on YouTube before buying it, mainly because of the avalanche of negative reviews, and the players are generally too clueless to understand how the game works.

From what I've seen, it's exactly the same as Superpower 2, except the battlefields are presented differently. You have the option to oppress your population, and resource production and trade have been completely reworked, making the game more interesting. The AI â€‹â€‹is much more responsive; it produces units, annexes territories, and so on. Stability has become even more important. The new interface, with less text and more graphics, gives us a better idea of â€‹â€‹the impact of our decisions. For example, if you decide to invest in an agricultural resource, a graph shows you the population available for that sector, the amount of arable land, and then the result of your investment.

Unit upgrades are much better designed. You can no longer build a crappy tank that looks like a Leclerc; the vehicle's skin will automatically reflect its specific characteristics. You can even upgrade infantry and create battalions specializing in particular areas. This gives you the opportunity to hold off a much more powerful enemy with a cheaper army by taking advantage of the terrain. So, you can defend yourself and contain a country like China with a small nation without necessarily spending billions on your army.

The major problem with this game is its poor polish. After a while, it lags so much that none of your actions register, or the interface becomes unresponsive, which quickly becomes annoying and frustrating. The game hasn't received an update in quite some time and seems to have been abandoned.

Even though I got a refund, I'm leaving a positive review to encourage the developers. This game desperately needs a significant technical update.

column8:
Longtime SuperPower 2 fan here. I held off writing a review because I was hoping that development of this game would resume, it has not and I don't think it will anymore. I waited a decade and more for it.

Do not buy this game. 

It barely runs and when it does it will inevitably break. It is outrageous that it continues to be sold. I'd be surprised if lawsuits haven't been filed against both the developer and publisher for selling this broken product. While it continues to be; puts a massive stain on both THQ Nordic and GolemLabs who if they had any self-respect and care for the public perception of their companies would immediately pull it off every store.

If you want a genuine example where the negative user reception is completely warranted, this is it. It didn't introduce predatory micro-transactions, it didn't have always online, it didn't have aggressive DRM, it didn't cause its predecessor to be shut down in favor of it. It is hated because it literally does not work. 

This game is the manifestation of the incompetence of both GolemLabs and THQ Nordic. If their deficiencies could be represented as a video game, this game is what that would look like.

Do not support companies that allow this to happen. People waited decades for this game and THQ Nordic and GolemLabs spat in their face and flaunt their success in doing so by continuing to sell it.

Do not buy this game.

column8:
As of this review SuperPower 3 is 34% OFF, save 100% of this game's price by not buying the game.

I purchased this game the day it came out, and i was quite disappointed.
I did not get a refund because i was hoping this game would have been patched enough to be playable, and a few months after release it was abandoned instead. 
It wasn't just review bombed either... it was review nuked into oblivion on day one, even most of the "positive" reviews are sarcastic.

For what few people might still play or buy this game, there is a beta branch which is slightly more playable and slightly less buggy than the normal branch, but i don't think anything for this game has been updated since January 2023.

I'm going to split this into two parts, things i like, and things i don't like.
* marks what i think is a feature, but could be a bug, ** marks an obvious bug. 

Things I like:
1. The world looks nice (when it isn't bugging out and pixelating itself)
2. The RTS control of units, and being able to actually see your units.
3. The Airports, Aircraft Carriers and Ports add a layer of realism by separating Air units from Land units, but you also can use 
carriers as mobile airbases.
4. **Economic Failure seems impossible now.

Things i don't like:
1. * Character Creation in a strategy game, which makes the game feel like a Sims game with geopolitical elements.
2. ** The many many bugs still unfixed.
3. THQ pulling the plug on SP3. 
4. * Nuclear missiles act like they're from a cartoon, a small black cone or something would be more appropriate, and would allow for many more warheads to be launched at the same time. 
(SP2 was actually more realistic despite it's age, especially with it's quantity of nuclear weapons.)
5. * Strategic warfare seems actually quite tedious compared to what it was in SP2.
6. * The latency of commands given to units, which only grows the larger your military and lower your tech level is.
7. ** The globe, provinces, and countries eventually pixelating themselves, making the game session unplayable.
8. * Conflict zones seem like entirely separate areas, and units don't seamlessly move in and out of those areas.
9. * Building you military is very tedious as there isn't a queue system like in SP2, you have to build one type of unit at a time, and they take an excessively long time to produce.

There are probably more things i could add but i won't.

I absolutely DO NOT recommend buying this game.

The economy section is completely incomprehensible, even though each section has very detailed explanations. The localization is only half complete, which is a minor issue; the icons are present, so it's barely functional. A lot of the data seems to reflect the publisher's bias, like the map, which is just awful to look at. Finally, it comes down to the tutorial: I don't understand how to build units, research, or move units. Hopefully, it will be improved in the future.

column9: This game is disappointing. The intro video is the only thing that looks good. The 3D models are awful and truly ugly, often having no connection to the country being played. The interfaces are cluttered, the graphics are really mediocre, and the gameplay is not intuitive at all. The game is full of errors, bugs, and oversights; it was never finished. It's only playable in English... this game isn't worth the price. If it were selling for $5.99, it might be tolerable, but it's clearly not worth $29.99. It's just an unfinished attempt at a game that's awful to play. The idea is good, but the product is terrible. There's a huge lack of skill and rigor on the part of the development team.

column8: With what could have been a very excellent game, is an utter failure. I've tried multiple different trouble shooting attempts in order to make this game playable, but it cannot be done. I couldn't even imagine trying to play this game on a regular PC, because on this high performance one I have, this should be a cake walk. The game forces you to use a laggy off-site server, making it unplayable offline, which would probably be the fix, as I'm on 1.2G internet and their server cannot keep up. Don't spend your money on this. Huge disappointment!

column8:
Super power 3 is my first entry into the series and sadly it is not leaving a great impression.

Pros:
- Great character creator
- A lot of real life situations to play
- People got mad when I attacked Canada... AS THE SHOULD

Cons:
- No tutorial with a steep learning curve
- The graphics were glitching out A LOT on my play through.
- Had several boot up errors.

I really thought I might like this game as I've been getting into the RTS games and like economy management but this just seemed like it wasn't ready for release. I give it 1/5 economic downfalls.

column8:
UPDATE 1: Just a update to this review but THQ and Golemlabs have killed support for the game do not buy this game now its a dead game

Original Review :To anyone who was a SuperPowers2 fan do not buy this game. I purchased the game because I am a huge fan of the series and nothing ever scratched the itch like SuperPowers2 did for me but this game is unplayable. Constant crashes or disconnects from the server, game breaking bugs with the economy, basic things such as sliders not working correctly and just so much more. The overwhelming negative reviews are warranted and non of the patches since release have improved the game in the slightest.  I am sorry THQ Nordic but what you are selling on this platform is so bad that it feels like a legit scam. I want this game to do well and I want to support you but I can't even play the darn thing for more than 30mins without a hard crash on a PC that is on the highend with a Ryzen 9 7950X and RTX 3080ti.

Gerne wÃ¼rde ich sagen das Spiel ist wie Superpower 2 in schÃ¶ner und mit mehr Inhalt, das wÃ¤re aber schlicht weg gelogen.
Aktuell gibt es immer wieder AbstÃ¼rze, das verstellen von Reglern lagt(Aber deutlich besser als vor dem ersten Patch), Wer einen Einheitendesigner wie in SP2 erwartet den muss ich auch enttÃ¤uschen, Gebiete KÃ¶nnen ebenfalls nicht mehr Getauscht werden und Generell fehlt hier irgendwie dieses nennen wir es mal "Versinken" in einer eigenen Welt.

Ob dieses Spiel bei mir je die knapp 800 Stunden von Superpower 2 bei mir erreichen wird  ? Nein, nicht in diesesem Zustand und ich muss leider wirklich sagen das es mir als Publisher peinlich gewesen wÃ¤re das Spiel so unfertig auf den Markt zu bringen, Fehler passieren natÃ¼rlich jedem keine Frage, am Release Tag hatte man jedoch den Eindruck es gab keine Beta Spieler anders lÃ¤sst sich aus meiner Sicht nicht erklÃ¤ren wie das passieren konnte.

Derzeit definitiv keine Kaufempfehlung so leit es mir tut.

Nachtrag 01.11.23: Das Spiel ist Tot, im Januar wurde das letzte Update Ausgespielt und es kann noch immer keine Rede von einem Fertigen Spiel sein. Ich rate hiermit definitiv vom Kauf ab.
column9:
I'd love to say the game is like Superpower 2, only prettier and with more content, but that would simply be a lie.

Currently, there are frequent crashes, adjusting sliders lags (though it's significantly better than before the first patch), and I have to disappoint anyone expecting a unit designer like in SP2. Territories can no longer be traded, and overall, there's a lack of that immersive experience, let's call it "sinking into" a world.

Will this game ever reach the nearly 800 hours I put in Superpower 2? No, not in its current state, and I have to say, as a publisher, I would have been embarrassed to release the game in such an unfinished state. Mistakes happen, of course, no question, but on release day, it seemed like there were no beta testers. I can't explain how this could have happened any other way.

I'm sorry to say I definitely can't recommend it at this time.

I'm currently not recommending it. Update November 1, 2023: The game is dead. The last update was released in January, and it's still far from being a finished game. I definitely advise against buying it.

column9:
I was really excited to try this kind of game (I'd never actually played this genre before), and since the description said it was suitable for newcomers and beginners, I wanted to give it a go.

However, what I found was a completely unfinished game that didn't properly explain what to do, nor did it match the screenshots that were supposed to prove the game's contents.

By the time I'd experimented a bit myself to figure out which slider had what effect and over what timeframe, I'd already exceeded the two-hour playtime limit, which I deeply regretted afterward, as I'd now wasted â‚¬30 on such a scam.

Generally, I'm someone who always gives games a second chance and checks back later to see how things have developed. But with this game, I find it simply outrageous to release something so unfinished, and we're not talking about an Early Access title here, where I'm perfectly fine with things not being quite finished or not working properly.

It's truly insane that such a large publisher supports something like this. I think this was the first and last collaboration, judging by the reviews here on Steam.

All in all, I absolutely DO NOT recommend buying it, and certainly not for people who want to get into this genre, because after a couple of things that are briefly explained, you're completely on your own. Oh wait, there's a link to an English website that explains the game and its mechanics in a novel format, but unfortunately, it has absolutely nothing to do with the possibilities of today's games. "Excuse me, it's 2022!"...

I haven't even bothered to check it out lately. There may have been a few updates, but after such a disastrous launch, I won't be dealing with the game again anytime soon.

Cheers

column8:
You're better off saving your money and buying SuperPower 2, installing the mods, and playing online with the Discord community. To be fair I was playing with a dual-core and not a quad-core processor (my mistake). Beyond that: I played 5 times, and it crashed all 5 times. I couldn't find any multiplayer games to join. 
The combat was worse than SuperPower 2. I somehow defeated 10's of 1,000's of opposing units with under 200 units. Though SuperPower 2's combat screened left something to be desired, at least it had one. 
The inclusion of an avatar that may have an impact on your population's approval of you, adding ethnic groups, are the only interesting additions I saw in my 2.5 hours of playing this game. Unfortunately, this addition did not outweigh the parts taken out of the political sphere you could do in SuperPower 2 and not in 3.
I barely touched the economic sphere, found nothing to note.

Go for: SP2 + Mods + Discord

column9:
This is written as of November 9, 2022. I'm starting to suspect this game was created with the intention of killing the Superpower franchise.
I even suspect it was released as a test to transform it into a multiplayer-focused online game, full of free-to-play and gacha mechanics.

They seem to be trying to resolve this issue with regular patches, but the lack of noticeable improvements is so frustrating.

The Korean translation is so poorly done that it would be better if users worked together to translate it. The translation is a mess, and some parts are rendered in English.

The UI, graphics, and everything else in this game are poorly optimized. Slowness and stuttering are commonplace, and it's incredibly resource-intensive. Unless a game like Superpower involves unimaginably high-powered nuclear weapons, it shouldn't be this demanding. Of course, it's possible to run the game on an outdated system with an Nvidia GTX 1070, 8GB of RAM, 16GB of DDR3 system memory, an AMD FX8300 quad-core, and two 256GB SSDs, but this isn't the case.

Furthermore, the convenient and detailed settings for combat, diplomacy, politics, trade, and weapon research are either regressed or virtually absent. The feature from the previous two games, which allowed players to choose whether to leave these settings to the AI â€‹â€‹or to decide for themselves, is absent, making it cumbersome when annexing large territories or territories acquired through war.

Furthermore, I doubt the will and ability to continue to maintain and maintain this game. It's a natural fate for games that receive negative reviews, are criticized, and fail to generate sales to be quietly patched and improved, and treated as if they were nothing.

You'd be better off playing Victoria 3, Hearts of Iron 4, or the previous game, Superpower 2, with its localization and mods. As things stand now, there's no answer.

column8:
[h1] [strike]Great[/strike] OK Sequel for an [strike]Great[/strike] OK Franchise [/h1]

Let me just preface this review by saying I have only played the Superpower series from 2010 onward, specifically Superpower 2 between 2010-2013. I used to host a roleplay server that was usually called "Will's RP Server". I'll start out by recalling problems I had with Superpower 2, that game was an imperfect mess, it had a lot of bugs and I don't recall a single patch being released until it was brought to Steam in 2014 or whenever that was. However, a lot of those bugs had workarounds and there was a small modding community out there that fixed a lot of issues *cough* uberfox *cough* and Superpower 2 was unique in that the host could use a mod, but the players would not need to have that mod in order to play on the server (only certain mods). Bugs and other gameplay issues aside, the most fun I derived out of the multiplayer games was from social interaction and just genuinely great RP from the community/players, I think it was an entertaining experience for most players, especially with mods. I understand people enjoy Superpower in different ways, but I just wanted to give some background and my perspective before I give my thoughts on Superpower 3.

Starting out with graphics, obviously a decent jump in graphical quality, which pretty much should be a given in 2022 unless you're re-releasing Power and Revolution again. In saying that, it's not all improved. Visual clarity is lowered by the clouds and night time and if you disable them you have to look at a pretty lacklustre water texture - not good. Thematic maps and resource filters are just a pain to visually decipher sometimes, despite what they have changed with patches.

Like other reviewers have stated, Autarky is still a thing and the economic gameplay features and functions seem to have been reduced compared to Superpower 2. Economic statistics sometimes seem to be completely unrealistic and military placements and numbers wildly inaccurate. Military research for individual countries is wrong AND outdated for many countries, even for 2018. Not having airbases a la Power & Revolution and instead using airports is interesting but also just unrealistic. Only being able to build one military unit at a time is both unrealistic and a step backwards from the SP2 system. It seems they have made a lot of arbitrary choices about what to be realistic about and what not - probably for simplicity's sake.

There are many other problems and gameplay issues I have encountered over the 100 hours I have played so far (which has been mostly on multiplayer), but many other reviewers have already listed a lot of those in their own reviews. So I will just say that the 3 or 4 patches that Golemlabs have released so far have improved this game drastically since release and that from the perspective of an old SP2 player, at this point the game could probably be regarded as "barely playable". I wouldn't really expect GL to work too much more on this considering their track record (which is fine), but they will probably continue on with it for a while yet. Which is great for those who decided to stick it out or people considering playing again or even purchasing it, but my hope is that when modders start to create things and fix issues, this game could probably be near the level of SP2 fun, albeit with a few less innate features.

My recommendation is that if you're not a hardcore fan of the series you probably won't enjoy it in it's current state, but I would 100% recommend it on sale. If people buy it on sale, the player base might start to return and grow, sowing the seeds for a future community similar to Superpower 2.

column9:
SuperPower 3 is an excellent modern strategy game! The integration of real politicians is very interesting, and the division of the gameplay into four spheres makes the game well-structured and complex. I haven't played it much yet, but I already find it to be a very realistic game that rivals the big names in the genre.

In short, kudos to Golemlabs, and what a joy to have a quality studio in Sherbrooke!

column8: This game is complety unfinished. I wanted to love it, but there are so many things missing and gameplay is just.. a flat experience, there is no depth. In SP2 you had a lot of info and choices to micromanage your country. In SP3 you have 8-10 sliders on your budget screen and 4 options of diplomacy with each country. That's about it. You still have a bit of military R&D, but that portion is tiny. This needs a complete rethink from the developers side. I was expecting even more depth and a lot nicer war/battle sim, but SP2 is far superior to this game. What a shame

The interface runs extremely poorly even on the lowest settings on a good system and the game on pause.
Good luck building more units as you wait ten minutes for the super long and jumbled mess of a unit selection list to load.

It's a hollow mimicry of the old SuperPower games.

Fix all these various issues people are griping about and I'll consider coming back with my money, for now I have requested a refund. I was so excited after all these years, only to be met with this hot garbage. Spent an hour of my time just waiting for the interface to respond to my commands. Every button press and slider was an agonizing trudge through the sludgiest UI I have seen in modern times.

The interface runs extremely poorly even on the lowest settings on a good system and the game on pause.
Good luck building more units as you wait ten minutes for the super long and jumbled mess of a unit selection list to load.

It's a hollow mimicry of the old SuperPower games.

Fix all these various issues people are griping about and I'll consider coming back with my money, for now I have requested a refund. I was so excited after all these years, only to be met with this hot garbage. Spent an hour of my time just waiting for the interface to respond to my commands. Every button press and slider was an agonizing trudge through the sludgiest UI I have seen in modern times.

column9:
Garbage! It feels like the developers got tired of making it and, at some random moment, decided to just roll it out as is. The best mechanics of the second game have been completely destroyed. In their place, there's something that defies common sense. It seems like the arithmetic operators are simply mixed up in several places. For example, if your immigration and emigration are zero, and the birth rate exceeds the death rate, by common sense, the population should be growing. But here it's declining! How...?

I tried playing as Andorra. Three economic sectorsâ€”each about 1 yard. What's the total GDP? 1 + 1 + 1 = 3? Nope, according to the developers, 1 + 1 + 1 = 1.
If consumption of a given industry's output is 10, and production is 12, will businesses import these products? In reality, there will be some imports to diversify the product range. Let's say 3 units are exported and 1 is imported. The net balance will be near zero. In the game, production can be many times greater than consumption, and at the same time, imports will also be many times greater than consumption. A completely incomprehensible mechanic.
And so on... Several pages could be written listing the game's stupidities.

column8: I can't see them "fixing" this mess. How TF are you gonna force a Superpower to build ONE single order at a time? Who OK'd that? You can literally only build 10k infantry at a time in a single order. The UI is worse than SP2 in everyway. I do not feel sorry for Golemlabs one bit. This will crush them, especially after Guild 3. This should have been a $10 Early Access title if they really needed revenue. Steam should honestly remove this crap from the store. There also isn't a single server or person on Multiplayer mode. Not one. There is no way that this game is decent even a year from now IMO. I loved SP2. All you had to do is improve upon superpower 2. I am extremely disappointed. Hopefully Steam refunds this one.

column8:
Please do not buy.

Clunky at every level.

Since I want to be a least a little bit constructive I'll concentrate on one part of this mess of a game. Military.

1. unit icon - click on icon, 50/50 chance there is an actual unit there.
2. have to move EVERY SINGLE unit. So if you have 300 tank units that consist of anything from 4 to 4000 individual tanks then you have to move EVERY SINGLE UNIT.
3. Selling military equipment. No clue how this works, your roster is still filled with the equipment, the icon is gone off the map. Why can't I just scrap the equipment????
4. Research for military, no real control of designs, got 150 different tank designs but only 1 actively used tank design, then you will be rolling the mouse wheel for an hour when you try to build more.
5. You CAN merge units but only of the same design, which is a nightmare if you have the aforementioned 150 designs.
6. Combat. the enemy will literally run rings around you, enjoy the chase:(

I'm bored typing now, just like when I tried to start organising a countries military and hit all the roadblocks mentioned above.

This game is like Super Power 2 but , and that is a BIG BUT . The developers forgot to finish the game . This should of never gotten released and should never of been called part 3 of anything . This is more like hey lets make a part 3 of our old game and forget to put 95% of the crap into it . Oh and while we are at it lets keep most of the easy and must needed game features out of it . 

  I really think this has to be one of the worse games I have ever purchased on Steam and one of the worse releases anyone has delivered .

 Lets hope they remember the customers and fix this crap.

column8: No se ni por donde empezar, el juego desde el primer inicio se ve horrible, los grÃ¡ficos son muy malos, todo depende una interfaz, le falta muchÃ­simo desarrollo en la parte econÃ³mica ya que no puedes hacer tratos comerciales tÃ©cnicamente, solo tienes que ajustar el interfaz y dejar que el tiempo pase, lo cual es aburrido y nada dinÃ¡mico. Por la parte demogrÃ¡fica es inÃºtil, no influye en nada. Militarmente te ofrece menos que Superpower 2, lo cual es una vergÃ¼enza. Es un juego que le falta mucho desarrollo y que pareciera que reciÃ©n esta en fase beta, no se esforzaron en darnos una buena experiencia, si hasta la creaciÃ³n de personaje es horriblemente pobre, no tienes mas opciones que color de piel, ojos y pelo, y uno que otro cambio facial. Si quieren jugar un sandbox de geopolitica prueben mejor el Power and Revolution, al menos ese juego a pesar de todo si ofrece lo que te dice. Por mi parte devolverÃ© el juego y guardare el dinero para Victoria 3.
column9: I don't even know where to begin. The game looks awful from the very start. The graphics are terrible, everything revolves around the interface, and the economic aspect is severely underdeveloped. You can't technically make trade deals; you just have to adjust the interface and let time pass, which is boring and completely undynamic. Demographically, it's useless; it has no impact whatsoever. Militarily, it offers less than Superpower 2, which is a disgrace. It's a game that's seriously underdeveloped and seems like it's still in beta. They didn't put any effort into giving us a good experience; even the character creation is horribly basic. You have no options other than skin color, eye color, hair color, and a few facial tweaks. If you want to play a geopolitical sandbox game, try Power and Revolution instead. At least that game, despite everything, actually delivers what it promises. I'm returning the game and saving my money for Victoria 3.

It would have been great if it had been released as a mobile game on a system like this, but

column8:
It is full of bugs from top to bottom. I fight a war, win it, occupy all the provinces of a country and cannot annex all the provinces because even though the opponent has no more troops and I have occupied every province with units, some provinces are not counted as occupied. When I zoom out, I have the flag of the country I am looking at in the middle of the picture, even if I turn to the other side of the globe, for example. The whole thing then multiplies for every country I look at so that I can't see anything because the screen is full of flags. In my opinion, the game is not a game and certainly not as advertised, it is simply a rotating globe full of bugs and sliders that are not supposed to change anything in a comprehensible way.
Personally, I will never buy another game from this studio or this publisher. For me, the whole thing borders on criminal machinations. Publishing a game like this is serious fraud in my opinion! Because what exactly did you pay the price for? It is unplayable!

column9:
A bunch of bugs:

1. Newly built units spawn in the sea off Africa and can't move.

2. Units that are split and sold become immobile; unit merging is ineffective.

3. Units sold on the international market are ignored, making the player's military bloated. New technologies are researched, but the military has to be wiped out of veterans before being upgraded, forcing players into fascism.

4. Unit movement is mysteriously inconsistent. Unit icons disappear in various ways.

5. Industrial investments are sometimes effective, sometimes billions just sit there without taking effect.

6. The annexation system is confusing. It's unclear whether it requires active-duty personnel to land, tanks, or aircraft. Sometimes there's an annexation progress bar, but more often there isn't, making annexation impossible.

I clicked the recommendation button negatively because I can't get a refund after two hours, so I can only offer positive feedback. I hope the game can be like *No Man's Sky*, going from initial overwhelmingly negative reviews to continuous updates and player approval, gradually turning the tide.

column8:
I really wanted to like this game. I am a big fan of SP2. I have to agree with others that the game appears to be unfinished. I was running into issues with a few different scenarios:

* Appears to be a memory leak as the game started to use up 18 GB of RAM after 2 hours of game play
* Unemployment appears to have a bug in it at times, I had a strong education system to train my workforce in the different tiers and it never went down.
* There does appear to be a bug with asking big countries for money. I was able to continuously ask the USA for $500 BN very often without complaint.
* The GDP doesn't increase in value when you put investment into sectors. It went down in some cases even when heavily invested.
* No inflation control. This was well done in SP2.
* Foreign Aid doesn't appear to work.
* Unable to disband military units, you can only sell them
* Moving military units around is rather clumsy. It was well done in SP2.
* You are unable to see what treaties other countries have with each other like SP2.
* Unable to create more elaborate treaties to match a more real-world scenario.

I am (was) a huge fan of Superpower 2 and actually purchased it multiple times because I found it so fun.  My anticipation for this release was probably greater than others, so despite the warnings I went ahead a purchased....big mistake.  

The game is unplayable period.  

The graphics are poor at best.  SP2's map could zoom in closer and was more detailed.

The "military" aspects are a joke.  Nothing works properly.

I would have preferred just an updated version of SP2 then this dumpster fire.  Sadly disappointed.

Il est dÃ©jÃ  l'heure de faire une Ã©val car ce jeu est tout simplement mauvais en l'Ã©tat, et que je ne peux pas continuer Ã  y jouer.
Le trailer et les images donnaient envie, j'espÃ©rais une bonne mÃ©canique et un gameplay plus intÃ©ressant pour un jeu de simulation gÃ©opolitique. Les possibilitÃ©s pour gÃ©rer le pays et les relations internationales semblaient prometteuses mais malheureusement soient elles sont manquantes, soient buguÃ©s.

[h1] Les moins [/h1]
- Pas de tutoriel. Pourtant, pour un jeu complexe de gÃ©opolitique, un tutoriel serait le bienvenue.
- Le jeu propose des scÃ©narios intÃ©ressants, mais en testant celui du conflit Ukraine-Russie, c'est devenu le bordel en 5 min avec des guerres dÃ©clarÃ©s de partout (sauf entre l'Ukraine et la Russie). 
- La gestion Ã©conomique n'a pas l'air de fonctionner. En voulant dÃ©velopper des industries, rien ne se passe (mÃªme aprÃ¨s 1 an), mÃªme augmenter les taxes d'un secteur ne semble pas impacter les rentrÃ©es d'argent. Par contre, taxer le peuple ironiquement Ã§a fonctionne.
- Les relations internationales sont trÃ¨s limitÃ©es, elles peuvent basiquement se rÃ©sumer Ã  :
[olist]
    [*]Conclure deux traitÃ©es de bonnes ententes (culturel et dÃ©veloppement humain) purement symboliques ou presque.
    [*]Mettre une ambassade, faire un embargo, ou obtenir un accÃ¨s militaire Ã  un pays.
    [*]Donne/Demander de l'argent ou des militaires (SÃ©rieux..., l'Allemagne qui me demande 7 Milliards en dÃ©but de partie comme Ã§a, WTF !)

Et mon Dieu mais pourquoi l'AlgÃ©rie d'un coup annexe une rÃ©gion de la Russie, puis attaque l'Italie sans prÃ©venir, puis le Kosovo, puis la Hongrie. CE JEU N'A PAS DE SENS !!!

column9:
It's already time for a review because this game is simply bad in its current state, and I can't continue playing it.
The trailer and screenshots were enticing; I was hoping for good mechanics and more interesting gameplay for a geopolitical simulation game. The possibilities for managing the country and international relations seemed promising, but unfortunately, they are either missing or buggy.

[h1]The Cons[/h1]

- No tutorial. Yet, for a complex geopolitical game, a tutorial would be welcome.

- The game offers interesting scenarios, but when testing the Ukraine-Russia conflict scenario, it became a mess within 5 minutes, with wars declared everywhere (except between Ukraine and Russia).

- The economic management doesn't seem to work. When trying to develop industries, nothing happens (even after a year), and even increasing taxes on a sector doesn't seem to impact revenue. On the other hand, ironically taxing the people works.

- International relations are very limited; they can basically be summarized as:

[olist]

[*]Conclude two purely symbolic or nearly symbolic treaties of good understanding (cultural and human development).

[*]Establish an embassy, â€‹â€‹impose an embargo, or obtain military access to a country.

[*]Give/Request money or troops (Seriously... Germany asking me for 7 billion at the start of the game like that, WTF!)

[/olist]
- Annexation! Annexation! Annexation! Seriously, Putin participated in the development of the game; the number of annexations in a single game is staggering. Why does the United States annex a region of Kazakhstan...? And my God, why does Algeria suddenly annex a region of Russia, then attack Italy without warning, then Kosovo, then Hungary? THIS GAME MAKES NO SENSE!!!

[h1] The Plus Points [/h1]
- There are Rafale fighter jets and the Charles de Gaulle aircraft carrier in the game.

column8:
La economÃ­a es un chiste. Recaudo casi los mismos impuestos con 46 millones de habitantes que con 110 millones.
Te anexionas un paÃ­s y el paro no deja de crecer. Es como si solo tuviera en cuenta las personas que pasan a formar parte de tu paÃ­s y como si todas las empresas del paÃ­s anexionado no existieran.
Pocas opciones politicas, se centra puramente en lo militar.
EsperarÃ© a que saquen algÃºn parche, a ver si merece la pena. 
De momento no te gastes los 30â‚¬.
column9:
The economy is a joke. I collect almost the same amount of taxes with 46 million inhabitants as with 110 million.
You annex a country and unemployment keeps rising. It's as if it only considers the people who become part of your country and as if all the companies in the annexed country don't exist.
There are few political options; it's purely focused on the military.
I'll wait for them to release a patch, to see if it's worth it.

For now, don't spend the â‚¬30.

column8:
Bis jetzt war ich ein Fan von Superpower und freute mich auf eine Fortsetzung. Aber was sie im dritten Teil abgeliefert haben ist sagenumwobend schlecht. Man kann das noch einmal als Spiel bezeichnen, eher nur ein Stromfresser mit ein paar Interaktionen.

Die paar Budgetregler, welche in Endeffekt das einzige sind, mit denen man sich im "Spiel" auseinandersetzen muss, sind ungenau und schwerfÃ¤llig. Sobald man in den negativen wirtschafsbereichen investiert hat, muss man nur noch abwarten, bis ein Ergebnis gezeigt wird. Gleichzeitig wartet man auf die militÃ¤rische Forschung, damit man nach ca 1-2 reallife Tage dann endlich mal Einheiten bauen kann um sein Territorium zu vergrÃ¶ÃŸern.

Sogar bei jedem einfachen Handyspiel hat man mehr zu tun.

-> Superpower 3 ist ein Spiel was eigentlich kein Spiel ist und unmengen an Power braucht.
column9:
Until now, I was a fan of Superpower and was looking forward to a sequel. But what they delivered in the third installment is unbelievably bad. You can barely call it a game anymore; it's more like a power hog with a few interactions.

The few budget controls, which are essentially the only things you have to deal with in the "game," are imprecise and cumbersome. Once you've invested in negative economic areas, you just have to wait for the results. At the same time, you're waiting for military research so that, after about one or two real-life days, you can finally build units to expand your territory.

Even a simple mobile game offers more to do.

-> Superpower 3 is a game that isn't really a game and consumes vast amounts of power.

column9: You're right, but *Superpower 3* is a brand-new open-world adventure game developed by THQ. The game takes place in a fantasy world called "Google Maps," where those chosen by a scam are granted the title of "ruling party," guiding the power of three major industries. You'll play as a mysterious "leader" whose language and religion cannot be preserved. During your journey, which requires a 10-second wait for each action, you'll encounter the useless Hofstede cultural dimension model and a mysterious army of paper dolls. You'll witness them use nuclear weapons to kill 100 million people, achieve re-election as president with a 7% stability rate, and recover the lost GDPâ€”while gradually uncovering the truth behind the rule that "products with excessively long playtime usually don't offer refunds."

En ce qui me concerne, superpower 3 est un ratÃ© comme on en voit peu, ne parvenant mÃªme pas Ã  Ã©galer SP2, lequel date quand mÃªme de 2004. Faut le faire.

L'Ã©diteur de personnage.

D'une part, il fonctionne bien, mais il pose plus de question qu'il n'en rÃ©sout. A mon avis, des mÃ©caniques de soulÃ¨vements ou de guerres civiles basÃ©es sur l'ethnie, la culture, la religion devaient Ãªtre prÃ©vues, mais ont Ã©tÃ© abandonnÃ©es en chemin.  C'est dommage.

La localisation.

Mal faite, mal finie. Certaines infobulles ne sont pas traduites, et d'autres n'ont aucun sens. Ainsi, on lira "si vous accumulez trop de dettes, votre pays deviendra insoluble". Oui, c'est prÃ©sent dans le jeu. Par ailleurs, plusieurs icÃ´nes sont manquantes.

Le tutoriel.

Il brille par son absence. On trouve cependant 3 ou 4 courtes vidÃ©os, en anglais, et non sous-titrÃ©es. Ca rejoint la localisation indigente.

La population.

Plein de donnÃ©es, mais dont ignore l'utilitÃ© dans le jeu. Je suis tout Ã  fait d'accord que l'on me parle de masculinitÃ©, d'individualisme  et de culture d'obÃ©issance, mais j'aimerais quand mÃªme avoir une explication sur son rÃ´le et sa finalitÃ©.

A contrario, au niveau de la politique intÃ©rieure, c'est le vide total. Aucun sondage sur l'opposition, ni sur son positionnement dans l'Ã©chiquier politique. Pas de campagne Ã©lectorale du tout. C'est simple, un pop up m'a informÃ© que j'avais Ã©tÃ© rÃ©Ã©lu. C'est une blague ?



L'Ã©conomie: 

D'une part, elle n'est pas trÃ¨s personnalisÃ©e. Par exemple, que vous ayez des cÃ´tes ou pas, nulle trace d'industrie de la pÃªche .. Elle n'est pas davantage informative. Pour dÃ©velopper un secteur, vous devrez investir dedans, ce qui est logique, et vous aurez donc un impact environnemental (pollution, dÃ©forestation, ou occupation de terres arables). Alors, si vous avez les donnÃ©es avant d'investir, vous ignorez l'impact que vos futurs investissements pourraient avoir: c'est la surprise du chef !!

Le budget

le mÃªme amateurisme rÃ¨gne dans ce domaine. Les curseurs sont imprÃ©cis au possible, et en prime vous ne connaissez pas l'effet, lÃ  non plus, de vos dÃ©cisions.
Je prendrai l'exemple de l'Ã©ducation : vous augmentez le budget, ce qui sur la papier est une bonne chose, puisque vous pourrez dÃ©velopper le recherche civile ou militaire, ou encore le secteur tertiaire. Sauf que vous ne savez pas d'oÃ¹ vous dÃ©marrez, ni oÃ¹ vous arriverez. Il n'y a tout simplement aucun graphique du taux d'Ã©ducation de votre population, que ce soit en fonction de l'Ã¢ge ou autre. Il n'y a rien pour le primaire, secondaires, supÃ©rieur, universitaire. Vous allez complÃ¨tement en aveugle. Vos investissez dans des secteurs sans mÃªme savoir si vous aurez assez de personnel qualifiÃ© pour le travail. Du grand n'importe quoi !
MÃªme chose pour les infrastructures, c'est la grande inconnue.

La dette, Ã©galement. Si vous avez des fonds propres, vous pourriez Ãªtre tentÃ© de faire des remboursement anticipÃ©s. dans le cas de l'amÃ©rique du sud, c'est crucial tant le remboursement annuel pÃ¨se sur le budget. Eh bien non, c'est impossible. Vous continuez Ã  rembourser pendant 20 ans, parce qu'il n'y a pas non plus d'Ã©talement. Et quant au taux d'intÃ©rÃªt, je n'en ai pas vu mention, je me dis donc qu'il doit Ãªtre fixe, que vous soyez vertueux ou pas .



Politique:

Quelques mots pour une grande absente. Vous ne connaissez pas votre place sur l'Ã©chiquier politique, ni celle de vos adversaires, d'ailleurs. Il n' y a du reste pas de reprÃ©sentation du spectre politique oÃ¹ que ce soit. Ce ne serait pourtant ni du luxe, ni bien difficile.

Du coup, pas de politique sociale du tout, et quant Ã  la politique Ã©co, je vous en ai parlÃ© plus haut. Dans les faits, il est impossible d'opÃ©rer la moindre dÃ©pense sociale.  Ce qui mÃ¨ne Ã  un autre Ã©norme problÃ¨me: le chÃ´mage. C'est simple, j'ai pu maintenir une croissance Ã  prÃ¨s de 3%, et le chÃ´mage n'a jamais cessÃ© de monter. Ce qui assez logiquement Ã  fait baisser mes revenus de faÃ§on drastique. Du grand n'importe quoi. 




La diplomatie.

Simpliste et peu ergonomique.
Pour ma part, je n'ai pas pu remarquer si mes traitÃ©s avec un pays donnÃ© pouvaient influencer mes relations avec un autre pays. Une alliance avec l' Iran pourraient-elles me valoir une mise au ban avec les USA ? MystÃ¨re.
Quant Ã  l'ergonomie, justement : si vous voulez faire un traitÃ© rapidement, vous avez un menu de sÃ©lection rapide pour les pays alliÃ©s ou en guerre. Pour les autres, vous devrez fermer les menus, chercher le pays sur la mappemonde, le sÃ©lectionner et ouvrir Ã  nouveau le menu diplomatique.
PrÃ©historique.

A ce stade, j'ai jetÃ© l'Ã©ponge sans mÃªme me lancer dans une guerre. Pour une guerre, il faut des alliÃ©s, une armÃ©e, des ressources, une industrie correcte, un ennemi qui ne vous tienne pas par les cou....es. Franchement, vu les problÃ¨mes en amont, Ã§a ne m'a mÃªme pas donnÃ© envie de m'y mettre. Le menu militaire est crade, en plus d'Ãªtre illogique. Vos chars du XXI eme siÃ¨cle ont pour icÃ´nes des chars de la 2nde GM. StupÃ©fiant, mais rigoureusement exact.


En conclusion, Superpower 3 est un jeu particuliÃ¨rement ratÃ© auquel je cherche vainement la moindre qualitÃ©, rÃ©alisme, ou encore aspect pÃ©dagogique voire sociologique. Il y a probablement de bonnes idÃ©es, mais aucune n'est implÃ©mentÃ©e comme il se doit, et l'ensemble n'a aucun sens. En, l'Ã©tat, y jouer relÃ¨ve du supplice. Les raccourcis clavier sont rares et insuffisants, il n'y a qu'une vitesse de jeu, etc ...

A ce stade, le mieux est encore que l'Ã©diteur le retire et rembourse tout le monde. Ensuite, Ã  lui de le reprendre de fond en comble et de le sortir Ã  nouveau dans un dÃ©lai de 6 Ã  18 mois. S'il espÃ¨re rÃ©soudre les failles et remonter la pente avec quelques patches, il se berce d'illusions. On ne revient pas de 8% d'opinions positives par un coup de baguette magique.

column9:
Let's be frank, I only bought this game to write this review, having spent 8 hours playing it at someone else's house. I was therefore able to test several matches with France, Brazil, New Zealand, and finally Brunei.

As far as I'm concerned, Superpower 3 is a flop like few others, not even managing to equal SP2, which is from 2004. That's quite an achievement.

The graphics.

From the title screen, you realize the limitations of the game: you choose between fullscreen and windowed mode. If you choose the latter, part of the menu disappears as soon as you want to play in 2K or higher. From then on, you're forced to play in 1024. In 2022, that's simply unacceptable.

The character editor.

On the one hand, it works well, but it raises more questions than it answers. The game emphasizes the importance of your character's language and religion, but in practice, this serves no purpose. So why even mention it? In my opinion, mechanics for uprisings or civil wars based on ethnicity, culture, and religion should have been included, but were abandoned along the way. It's a shame.

The localization.

Poorly executed, poorly finished. Some tooltips aren't translated, and others are completely nonsensical. For example, you'll read, "If you accumulate too much debt, your country will become untenable." Yes, that's in the game. Furthermore, several icons are missing.

The tutorial.

It's conspicuously absent. There are, however, three or four short videos, in English, without subtitles. This reinforces the poor localization.

The population.

Plenty of data, but its usefulness in the game is unclear. I'm perfectly fine with the talk about masculinity, individualism, and a culture of obedience, but I'd still like an explanation of its role and purpose.

Conversely, the domestic political aspect is a complete void. No polls on the opposition, nor on its position on the political spectrum. No election campaign at all. Simply put, a pop-up informed me that I'd been re-elected. Is this a joke?

The economy:

Firstly, it's not very personalized. For example, whether you have coastlines or not, there's no mention of a fishing industry. It's also not very informative. To develop a sector, you'll have to invest in it, which makes sense, and this will have an environmental impact (pollution, deforestation, or the use of arable land). So, if you have the data before investing, you're unaware of the impact your future investments might have: it's a complete surprise!

The Budget

The same amateurish approach prevails in this area. The indicators are incredibly imprecise, and on top of that, you don't know the effect of your decisions either.

Take education, for example: you increase the budget, which on paper is a good thing, since you can develop civilian or military research, or even the service sector. Except that you don't know where you're starting from, or where you'll end up. There's simply no graph of your population's education level, whether by age or otherwise. There's nothing for primary, secondary, higher, or university education. You're going in completely blind. You're investing in sectors without even knowing if you'll have enough qualified staff for the jobs. Utter nonsense!

The same goes for infrastructure; it's a complete unknown.

Debt, too. If you have equity, you might be tempted to make early repayments. In the case of South America, this is crucial, given how much the annual repayments weigh on the budget. Well, no, it's impossible. You continue to repay for 20 years, because there's no option to spread the payments out. And as for the interest rate, I haven't seen any mention of it, so I assume it must be fixed, whether you're being fiscally responsible or not.

Politics:

A few words about a major omission. You don't know your place on the political spectrum, nor that of your opponents, for that matter. Furthermore, there's no representation of the political spectrum anywhere. Yet, it wouldn't be a luxury, nor particularly difficult.

Consequently, there's no social policy at all, and as for economic policy, I mentioned it earlier. In reality, it's impossible to make any social expenditures whatsoever. Which leads to another huge problem: unemployment. Simply put, I managed to maintain growth at nearly 3%, yet unemployment never stopped rising. This, quite logically, caused my income to plummet. Utter nonsense.

Diplomacy.

Simplistic and clunky.

Personally, I couldn't determine whether my treaties with a given country could influence my relations with another. Could an alliance with Iran lead to me being blacklisted by the US? A mystery.

As for the user interface: if you want to quickly create a treaty, there's a quick selection menu for allied or warring countries. For others, you have to close the menus, find the country on the world map, select it, and then reopen the diplomatic menu. Prehistoric.

At this point, I threw in the towel without even starting a war. For a war, you need allies, an army, resources, a decent industry, and an enemy that doesn't have you by the throat. Frankly, given the problems from the start, it didn't even make me want to play it. The military menu is a mess, not to mention illogical. Your 21st-century tanks have WWII tank icons. Astounding, but absolutely true.

In conclusion, Superpower 3 is a particularly bad game in which I search in vain for any quality, realism, or even educational or sociological aspects. There are probably some good ideas, but none are implemented properly, and the whole thing makes no sense. As it stands, playing it is torture. Keyboard shortcuts are few and far between, there's only one game speed, etc.

At this point, the best thing would be for the publisher to withdraw it and refund everyone. Then, it's up to him to completely rebuild it and relaunch it within 6 to 18 months. If he hopes to fix the flaws and turn things around with a few patches, he's deluding himself. You can't magically reverse an 8% positive rating.

column9:
I only played for a few minutes and I can already say, the game STILL NOT WORTH BUYING. It's missing several things that were shown in the trailer: no parliament, elections, or lawmaking; the political aspect doesn't exist in the game; the economic system is very weak, lacking a lot of features; the UI is disorganized; diplomatic relations are very simple, not to mention the UI of the military system. Anyway, the game is far below SP2, and I would even say that even with its various bugs, the Q&A is better than SP3. When there are updates that will truly improve the game, I will buy it again.

I only played for a few minutes and I can already say, the game is STILL NOT WORTH BUYING. It's missing several things that were shown in the trailer; there's no parliament, elections, or lawmaking; in other words, the political aspect doesn't exist in the game; the economic system is very weak, lacking a lot of features; the UI is disorganized; diplomatic relations are very simple, not to mention the UI of the military system. In short, the game is far below SP2, and I'd even say that, despite the numerous bugs in the P&R mode, it's better than SP3. When there are updates that truly improve the game, I'll buy it again.

column9:
After reading reviews on Steam and various YouTubers, I was skeptical, thinking it was a waste of 30,000 won.
I bought it and played it like a madman, but...

Summary: Compared to the previous game, it's just a cosmetic change (graphics), but the rest of the system is a step backwards.

I usually avoid refunding games that I find boring or pointless, but this one is simply unacceptable. I'd be willing to give it a try, hoping for improvements in future updates, but that's for later.

It's better to just buy it again when it gets better.

For now, it seems best to just play the Redux version of the previous game (I'm not sure if this is a mod or a patch).

column8: This game is beyond broken and featureless at the moment. I hope they will add to the game soon and I will definitely revisit if they do but the game in it's current state is unacceptable please don't buy until further notice from the developers.

column8:
Superpower 1 was one of the first games i fell in love with. 
Superpower 2 expanded on that game and polished it up. 
    -it had its share of bugs, but it ended up being a fantastic game.
Superpower 3... it needs some serious patches. 

Here are the most problematic issues...
1. unresponsive military units... 
       -unit counts incorrect at times
       -no "occupy territory" option (like in SP2)

2. can't increase the game speed (like in SP2)

3. why can't we make treaties with multiple countries at once? (like in SP2)
    -also there's less options of what kinds of treaties you can sign

4. harder to navigate menus,
   -bring back SP2 smaller menus, where you could have all 3 up at once
    -less world view maps, "resource balance", "stability"  etc... and the ones you do have turn off as soon as you select a unit... 

5. it says the character creator has serious effects on your game. but it didn't seem like it made any difference to me.

just fix #1 and the game will be playable.
fix 2-4 and i'll enjoy the game.
idrc about the character creator thing, though i appreciate adding new layers to the game.

Sincerely, SUPER fan since 2002

column9:
After playing for a while, it felt like a war game completely disguised in the Superpowers name. The interface was extremely simple, the numerical adjustment bars were laggy, and there was practically no interaction with other countries. It's simply about making money as the ruling nation, developing your army, and conquering the world. They call it a geopolitical simulation game? Pshaw! While the optimization of the Nation Ruler series is terrible and often results in save file corruption, its gameplay is far superior to these three. Also, the handling of national relations in this game isn't as detailed as Earth Unbreakable, a game about fighting aliens. Earth Unbreakable, by extracting the alien invasion content and making it a nation-playing game, feels more like a sequel to Superpowers 2 than Superpowers 3. Honestly, Earth Unbreakable is a game with multiple gameplay options, which is worthwhile.

If this game doesn't get updates later, it'll be a complete flop. Isn't Earth Unbreakable better?

column9:
I couldn't wait until Victoria III was released, so I bought it as a stopgap, but you're kidding me lol (seriously)... Are you serious? There's not even a tutorial? Even Paradox has one. They're not even interested in adding new players, so they're not very motivated... There are a lot of bugs, you can't create a beautiful character, and you can't speed up the time, which is frustrating. It's a shame, considering there are various scenarios like restoring the Ottoman Empire or the Soviet Union.
Well, there's a lot more I want to say, but overall, I can't help but think that the Earth and space are beautiful. Thank you for making me buy this garbage, which is worse than the early smartphone games you were working on. I'm sorry, but I'll give it back. If the game gets better, I might buy it again.

column9: If you don't know how to make games, I suggest you learn from Earth Unyielding. Both are early access games where the other has 80% completion, while yours may not even have 5%.

column8:
Game resources are spent on pointless and aesthetic aspects of the game like 40+ avatar's feature customization, a new combat square that is equivalent to the old dust ball from an interaction perspective, and beautiful shadowing over the cute little cities. Even if the combat square did not glitch out units and become stuck for the rest of the game the combat square would still be a downgrade from the superpower II's dust ball since it can entrap more than just the region the battle is centered on but the battle plays out too fast to make any interactions or decisions meaningful. There are no consequences at the moment for almost any decision despite there not even being a choice of government type(update.1-you can now choose your government type) and every nation will accept a proposed war declaration on any other nation(update.2-Nations now won't accept wars but still accept all other forms of diplomacy if relations are equal to North Korea with Italy). I can not recommend this game to anyone who is not willing to be frustrated and patient with an unfinished product(update.3-they now instead of releasing patches created an open-beta that we are playtesting patches for them before release).

I continue to try and explore the game but each time a new downgrade exposes itself. No map layers for any country but your own, dead AI, deathball only functional wartime strategy, zero army differentiation across nations, I think there are more avatar facial feature options than there are base military unit designs across the entire world. Overall there is very little to even get excited about at the moment since added statistics that should be showing how decisions and choices pan out over your nation's timeline either do not work or are broken. While they reduced political choices with limited consequences they increased economic decisions across economic sectors but these gains are overridden by a dysfunctional trade system that is rooted in unique superpower III economic principles and not basic accounting or finance concepts. I could go on about how many downgrades and poor design choices they made, and I am trying not to complain too much about the "glitches" that can be hotfixed, but I will end here.

Thank you for attending my TED talk.
