column9:
Unfortunately, I played this game for over 12 hours and won't be able to get a refund.

I thoroughly disliked the game. I advise against purchasing it this year.

Cons:
â€¢ Bugs and severe freezes, lags on high-end computers. You won't be able to play this game smoothly, as you'll encounter freezes and various glitches from the moment you load.

â€¢ A lot of content has been cut. This isn't the same Super Power 2 as before, with the refinements and improvements of the new third installment. Unfortunately, the situation here is dire. You can't change the ruling party, you can't change the form of government, you can't exclude/leave/join/add countries to the alliance. You can't enter into other treaties between other countries. The system is very strangely designed in SP3. Also, the list of treaties is very limited.
â€¢ Uneasy gameplay with a ton of bugs. When you're at war with someone, it's impossible to play smoothly. On the battlefield, you see all this highlighted by some strange red square, where your country's troops and the AI's are simply slow, glitching, and freezing. For example, your million-strong army can be defeated by 1,000 infantry... Troop movement is also a problem; sometimes they simply don't move, because sometimes it's simply impossible to mark troops to direct them to a specific location; it's glitchy.
â€¢ A terribly huge interface that takes up the entire screen. My guess is that the developers were trying to borrow something from Geopolitical Simulator, but the SP3 developers did a very poor job of it. All the menus and interfaces are also laggy. It's impossible to press buttons, even the exit button sometimes fails to click the first time; you have to click a billion times before it works...
â€¢ Limited character creation options. Although, of course, the fact that the developers even implemented the ability to create your own character is already pretty cool. But I also didn't really like the proposed character creation options. The male ruler is always muscular, old, with a big, bulbous nose. The female ruler is a young woman with a bell-shaped body... In short, it's complete trash... And the character designs themselves are terrible. Totally dull.
â€¢ The actual game graphics are very different from what was shown in the trailer. On ultra settings, the graphics are complete crap. The graphics are a bit choppy, and when zooming in, details are rendered that are on the ground with very long and terrifying freezes and lags, again. Thematic maps are poorly designed.

These are far from the last few downsides to describe the accumulated mess associated with SP3.
I advise against playing this game right now until the developers fix the bugs.
I heard a rumor that the original developers were fired after the game's release. Therefore, I think the process of "updating" the game will be very long. Maybe a year, maybe two; don't expect an update anytime soon. Let's all return to the second part of the franchise and revel in the nostalgia and enjoy! This part is still in its infancy.

column8:
I'd never played a Superpower game before but heard the series was a good place to go for political simulators. Saw this was launching and decided to give it a go only to spend my time being confused as what to do.
You are only given control over half-a-dozen laws, and nothing is explained in an intuitive matter like when you start in Civilization 6.
I can not recommend this game, but will give Superpower 2 a try in the future.

column8:
Pretty disappointing.  I got to compare it to #2.  Longer load times (assuming it doesn't lock up on load which is over 50% of the time for me)  the menu is less intuitive.  The sliders worker poorly.  No improvement in graphics.  Less treaties you can do with other countries.  And if you manage to do a treaty, there's no actual list to show you your on going treaties.  Which is a major issue as they cost money and balancing a budget is a major part of the game.  Yeah you got character design but I haven't seen that character once I play the game, making the whole process a waste of time.  The menus show less information.

I had such high hopes for this game and it has no improvements over the 2nd.  Overall, all aspects of the game are either equal to or below the 2nd game.  So I see no reason to keep this on my PC and will uninstall it and reinstall 2 soon as I'm finished writing this review.

In a year, I'll comeback and check if the updates made it a better game like No Man Sky or Cyberpunk 2077 redeemed themselves.

column8:
Against my better judgement, I bought this on launch day.  I tried to play it for about an hour and found it glitchy and unresponsive on a fairly high end gaming laptop.  It's pretty bad if this was released in an unfinished state, but it's truly unforgivable if this is considered the final product.  Learned my lesson, and had the product refunded.

If you have SuperPower 2, you'll have a much more enjoyable experience.  It is a complete product with seemingly more features than this sequel.  Another disappointing example that newer is rarely better.

column9:
1. A ton of bugs that are annoying but don't disqualify the game. All the paths, clickers, etc. need fixing. However, they're so obvious at first glance that I don't know how the game was released without fixing these bugs, since they're so glaring. Plus, if you add tanks to a production run, close (not minimize, just close) the production window, and the production ends, when you go back in, the army being produced disappears instead of appearing in the army deployment tab.
2. No tutorial - that's a complete joke. Admittedly, I've figured out most of the details, but how can you release a grand strategy game and not include a tutorial?
3. Graphics - Firstly, there are graphical glitches (I don't know if he was drunk or what's going on), and secondly, the quality of the windows and interface graphics is a cheap joke.

After such a disastrous start, there should have been a patch the very next day that would at least fix these basic bugs, because THQ is shooting themselves in the foot with this release...

After almost six hours of gameplay, I'm even more frustrated.

Several hours of building an economy to quickly expand my army, and the moment I start expanding, I'm unplayable. Units don't react, or they react randomly, half the units die, and the army statistics don't add up. It's a disaster. A massive patch is needed here, quickly, because what Cyberpunk 2077 had at launch on PlayStation is nothing compared to what THQ Nordic did on PC with this game. In the meantime, I'm off to buy and play Terra Invicta.

column9: I was very disappointed, it felt like I'd played a cut-down SuperPower 2. I was prepared for the game to be unpolished since it was made by a small studio, but releasing a game this bad requires a lot of effort. What do we have now? Has the economy changed since 2004? No, it still has no impact. You just sit there tweaking sliders. The number of cards has been reduced, but at least we have the opportunity to create a character who essentially does nothing and has no impact. They've prioritized the game, and I got my money back. What's there to seriously talk about? The graphics are okay, it's playable, but it's become boring.

Warning: Do not buy this game!!!

What you saw in the ad is identical:

- You'll see the video at the beginning.
- The units are "Pac-Man" style, but they didn't show you that.
- Your character will be a thumbnail in the corner of the window.
- A globe with a blank map where you have to hover the mouse to reveal disappearing locations.

We warned you, it's practically a scam for a 2022 game.

column8:
Textures and icons commonly fail to load, some in-game menus and sliders randomly laggy, AI utterly useless. Can't queue military production or build more than one thing at a time, no clear indication of build time, and new units seem to deploy only to your capital. 

Played as UK. Declared war on, invaded, and annexed Ireland within 30 minutes. No consequences whatsoever.

Seems to be missing pretty much everything people enjoyed in Superpower 2. But hey, at least now you get to create an apparently pointless avatar.

Hot garbage. Avoid.

The game lags in the middle of a battle, and units freeze and won't move.
It's buggy, so even during a battle, the Earth moves on its own without me pressing anything, and the game crashes.
I can't even see where the previous game's speed was sold, and the unit graphics look like they're not from 2022. LOL.
This is Early Access, but it's not Early Access. This is a mess.
Sapfung runs well, and the game doesn't lag much.
This is just garbage, garbage.
Sell the copyright to some corporation, please.

column8:
nÃ£o me lembra a ultima vez que fiz analise de algum jogo que compre aqui na Steam.
Comprei esse jogo pois sou aficionado por geopolitca, economia e talz, e creio que depois de 8 horas jogando isso, o power & revolution parece uma obra de arte do lado do Super power 3.
O super power 3 Ã© um jogo bastante raso demais, o que nao seria um problema se e isso que vc procura mas o mesmo que apresenta lentidao extrema na interface UI do jogo pra praticamente qualquer aÃ§Ã£o que o jogador faÃ§a: aumentar subsidios, legalizar setores, alterar taxa de imposto , colocar celula de espionagem pra fazer missou ou treinar , qualquer coisa que vc faÃ§a na UI do jogos demora 4, 5 segundos. isso torna o jogo estressante e frustante....e uanto mais o tempo passa dentro do jogo pior fica... a diplomacia e extremaente rasa, a parte economica nao fica muito atras, nao me admira nao ter tido um preview de gameplay antes...senÃ£o esse jogo seria trucidado pela comunidade que estpera um continuam a altura de SP2..
Creio que caso vc esteja em  duvida de comprar. Dio com todas as palavras: definitivamente................................NÃ‚O VALE A PENA!!!!
guade seu precioso dinheiro pra algo que primiramente funcione e que te divirta....sem mas so resta alguar caso haja algum update que salve esse jogo de si mesmo
column9:
I can't remember the last time I reviewed a game I bought here on Steam.
I bought this game because I'm a fan of geopolitics, economics, and stuff like that, and I think after 8 hours of playing it, Power & Revolution looks like a work of art next to Super Power 3.
Super Power 3 is a pretty shallow game, which wouldn't be a problem if that's what you're looking for, but it also has extreme slowness in the game's UI for practically any action the player takes: increasing subsidies, legalizing sectors, changing tax rates, placing a spy cell to do missions or training, anything you do in the game's UI takes 4 or 5 seconds. This makes the game stressful and frustrating....and the more time passes in the game, the worse it gets... the diplomacy is extremely shallow, the economic part isn't much better, it doesn't surprise me that there wasn't a gameplay preview before...otherwise this game would be slaughtered by the community that expects a sequel worthy of SP2..
I believe that if you are in doubt about buying it, Dio, in all words: definitely................................NOT WORTH IT!!!!
Save your precious money for something that actually works and that entertains you....without further ado, there's only something left to do if there's an update that saves this game from itself.

column9: I don't know what I just played. It's far inferior to the second game. The military command and occupation systems are a mess. At least add a one-click occupation function. The economic and political systems are chaotic and unscientific. Some translations are also problematic. Don't disappoint consumers for nothing. After all, everyone has been waiting for so long for the third installment. I hope the developers can improve it and avoid a bad ending. I look forward to your quick updates and improvements. I'm giving you a thumbs up not because the game is good, but because I don't want a classic game to have a bad ending!

column8: I have been a fan since sp1. I prayed they would get it right this time. This is a huge step backwards, probably killed the franchise. I don't think they understand why this game was popular. Fundamentally they don't get it, they couldn't possibly because they have systematically removed all that was good with every iteration of the game. They took the aircraft carrier concept from sp2 and applied it to the entire game. It's 4 screens of funding levels on a recreated Google earth. It's not a game. You have no control. You can't build bases, airports nothing. You can only build 1 military unit at a time. Literally you can't order different unit types simultaneous. Moving aircraft is a joke. The game is trash. I requested a refund.

column8:
I have been playing this game for over 3 hours now and I cant agree with most of the negative comments on here.

I do agree that the game has a few bugs that need to be sorted, it is not impacting the game play much for me.  perhaps there has been an update in the past 24 hours, I am not sure, but so far I am somewhat enjoying the game. 

Only issue I have so far is that you cant change political party, and can only play the current political party in place at the moment.

column8:
This review was written 09.10.22 

I was given this game for free. The retail price as Im writing this review is about 30â‚¬ with a 10% sale making it about 27â‚¬. 

Before anything else I want to point out that this game only has 1 (fairly slow) speed setting. Meaning this turns out to be a fairly slow game to play. 

I want to start with the things I really liked about this game. Sadly there is not too much to like. Its a very flavourless game, with fairly little content and a fair few bugs and other issues which deduct from the fun I could have had. 

Alot of people dislike comparing it to SP2. However that was a 18 year old game which feels like it had roughly the same amount of content which this game does. Now SP2 was not a very deep game. However it had alot of flavour and it allowed you to have fun with that flavour.

 The roleplay servers of old on SP2 were so great because of the freedom you had withinn SP2. You wanted to play a theocratic communist UK which discriminates against English people ? Go right ahead there are ways to do that.  As of today playing a country i can choose between allowing elections and not allowing elections. And a very binary choice of Dictatorship or Democracy. Making a communist country and a theocracy more or less the same. 

SP 2 allowed you to discriminate/favour based on religion/ language.  SP3 downgrades that system. And meshes culture, religion and language all in one bloc. For example  you have Black/White South African. Demarking social group on racial grounds, while other places its Christian vs Muslim Tongoleese demarking social group on language grounds. In Serbia you have Serbs and Hungarian serbs... Well what seperates a Hungarian and a Hungarian serb if they live in the same country? This also removes flavour. 

SP2 had what felt like 200 diffrent economic sectors. Here we have maybe 16? Autarky still appears to be the way to go. They try to limit this with limiting the amount of farmland your country can have. Which does not really make the situation any better. It just means you have to invade other countires in a long game. 

Im still trying to figure out how to use the unit designer and how to purchase more army units. But this is probably because Im retarded. I dont think the UI is all that great. You can have bad UI which is functional. This appears just to be bad. 

War has had a rewamp which is... Not horrible but far from great. You now have to continiously occupy the provinces which you want to take over. Thats cool. Had it not been for the fact that some countires which are the size of a stamp have 1000 provinces and the USA has 50. There is no "occupy button" which there was in SP2. A feature I miss when we have to deal with continious occupation. 

All in all. Its just disapointing. It lacks a ton of features. It has no flavour to speak off. The servers were beyond fucked on release. All in all Im just disapointed. I dont know if its because the devs were rushed, or because the devs were lazy, If you can get it on a super sale. Sure go for it. If not stay clear.

column9:
No crashes for me, but a few issues. First, the zoom is useless; you can't see anything on the map. Units move, but there's no way to see close-up combat, which is really not great. There are no cities on the map; it's very abstract. You can increase investments in certain areas, but not decrease them. A few more economic and other options would be welcome.

The positives: The map is beautiful but lacks detail (missing cities, etc.). This would add more depth to the game. The multiplayer (not tested) is great if it works well. The interface is clear and visually appealing. The military aspect seems interesting but is hampered by the zoom, making wars impossible to manage.

In summary:
- Clear interface: a major strength in my opinion.
- Lack of management, economic, and political options.
- Lack of dynamic graphics to track political developments. For more gameplay depth:
-Lack of information on the map (city, roads)
-The map zoom is disastrous in my opinion, making the game difficult to play

I don't recommend this game in its current state, but I hope future updates will correct the flaws of this game, which I believe has potential.

column9:
It gets boring quickly because nothing happens. Multiplayer mode is unplayable. It's choppy and units don't move.

The user interface is confusing. Trading with individual countries is impossible. Time passes so slowly that all progress takes forever before anything happens. Research takes forever, even with a lot of money invested. Other countries do nothing, so boredom sets in quickly.

column9:
[h1] I'll try it out on your behalf. [/h1]
This review is updated in real time and is written for informational purposes.
(Resolved and fixed issues will be marked with a strikethrough.)
#Currently Confirmed Patch Count: 8 (23-01-16)

[b][Politics][/b]
01. Fewer treaty items than in SP2.
02. Political systems cannot be changed at will. (Ex. Military dictatorship, democracy, communism, monarchy, etc.)
03. The inconvenience of having to sign treaties with each country at a time. (In SP2, it was possible to sign treaties with multiple countries.)
04. AI from other countries suddenly demands money for no reason.
05. Friendship with all countries is low. Reason unknown. (Although treaties with the maximum foreign aid budget, embassies, human development, and cultural exchanges have been signed, relations have deteriorated over time.)
06. Politics - Information about the next election is not displayed properly in the domestic tab. (Ex. The current date is January 28, but the next election is displayed as March 22.)

[b][Military][/b]
01. Frame drops during combat.
[strike]02. I don't know how to develop nuclear weapons.[/strike]
ã„´â€» If you max out the nuclear research budget and wait, you can see that nuclear research is in progress. (Damage, range, area, accuracy)
03. You have to press the M key to move troops.
04. I don't know how to use the Air Force.
05. I can't design weapons to my liking. (The design changes depending on the weapon's performance.)
[strike]06. I don't know how to merge troops. (The splitting works fine, but the merge button doesn't activate.)[/strike]
ã„´â€» Now, only units with the same name can be merged. (Patch)
07. Military tab - Bug in the market section of troops (presumably).
ã„´07-1. The market number is increasing, but there are no purchasable items (items displayed). {A bug occurs in the later stages (after a certain amount of time has passed)}
[strike]ã„´07-2. The items I've listed are displayed, but the market number doesn't increase.[/strike]
[strike]08. Troop movement is not possible.[/strike]
ã„´08-1. Purchased units cannot move after arriving in the capital.
ã„´08-2. Troop movement is not possible.
09. Troops are not attacking. (Ex. Friendly and enemy tanks in the combat zone do not attack each other despite being within striking distance. Reason unknown. Possibly a bug.)
10. Troops still have a (green) afterimage after passing the intended route.

[b][Economy][/b]
01. Unable to recover investment in resource production.
02. Decreased resource production. (Unable to confirm whether this is a bug or functionally normal.)
03. The budget bar responds slowly when dragging within the budget section.
04. After selecting Economy-Sector-Resources and nationalizing, the list of countries involved in imports and exports (trade) is displayed in a page format, causing inconvenience. (A convenience patch is needed to automatically flip through the pages when the mouse cursor is moved.)
04-1. Deleting a country involved in imports and exports (trade) causes lag.
05. When privatizing resources, exports and imports do not function properly, resulting in inventory remaining.
06. The national treasury (funds) does not display a negative value (it does not go below 0).
07. The revenue from tariffs (taxes) and exports is not provided in detail.
08. During trade investment through nationalization, the other country may accept the request but not be added to the list. The export and import figures are still reflected.

â€» In this case, the app will likely crash after a short while, stating that the connection to the server has been lost. (Crashes 1 out of 3 times.)
ã„´â€» In this case, inventory and import/export figures for the other country are likely not reflected.
09. After selecting Economy-Sector-Resources, the Nationalized Status and the Countries with Import/Export (Trade) status are not displayed properly.
ã„´09-1. When adding or deleting countries for import/export, the entire list of countries disappears. (Going to Overview and then returning to the relevant resource item will restore the list.)
ã„´09-2. The countries for import/export of a given resource are not displayed properly. (Example: The "Meat" item is displayed mixed with the countries for import/export of the "Education" item.)
ã„´09-3. Even after the country for import/export of a given resource is destroyed, the country remains in the trade list. (Example: North Korea collapsed, but the export/import records were not deleted and trade continued.)
ã„´09-4. Even if the country for import/export of a given resource is insufficient, the country for import/export of the resource remains in the trade list. (Ex. Even if the inventory becomes negative after selling 10 units of gas, the transaction continues.)
In cases 09-3 and 09-4, trade revenue is reflected in the Economy-Budget. (Ex. Even if the exporting or importing country goes bankrupt or the corresponding resource becomes scarce, the transaction is considered ongoing and reflected in the revenue calculation.)
10. The government budget in the Economy-Budget is displayed as $0. (It remains $0 whether the budget is raised or lowered. However, there is an effect. If the budget is raised, corruption decreases, and if it is lowered, corruption increases.)
11. A bug that causes the GDP to become 0. (This bug occurred in 1942 in Angola. Presumed to be a bug.)
12. During automatic resource trading in the Economy-Privatization, if multiple exports or imports are made to the same country, the list of countries being traded is displayed abnormally. (Example: If you execute three (privatization auto) export transactions with the US, the US will appear in the list of trading countries three times. There should only be one, and it should be added to the existing transaction.)
13. In the Economy-Budget section, the private research results are displayed as "World Average Productivity -nan(ind) T." (version 1.0.6)
14. In the Economy-Budget section, the "Environmental Revenue Sources" section is displayed as "Agricultural Land -nan." (version 1.0.6)

[b][Other][/b]
[strike]01. Images that were previously displayed correctly are now broken. [/strike]
ã„´01-1. Images in the Military - Military tab are sometimes broken.
ã„´01-2. Leader faces are broken when loading.
02. Incorrect translation (e.g., "Net Income (eul)" is translated as "Balance (eul)").
[strike]03. Some untranslated information.[/strike]
ã„´03-1. Untranslated items were added due to ongoing patches. Therefore, the phrase "slightly" has been corrected to "untranslated."

04. An AI that doesn't fire a single nuclear weapon while North Korea's Kim Jong-un is falling apart.

05. A challenge that's hard to understand how to clear.

06. A user interface that doesn't understand why the demographics section includes network, budget, and policy decisions.
[strike]07. The mouse button occasionally doesn't work on the map.[/strike] â€» Patch
[strike]ã„´07-1. The right mouse button is blocked in the sea.[/strike] â€» Patch
[strike]ã„´07-2. The mouse button is blocked when hovering the mouse cursor on land. (It's assumed the mouse button is blocked by the UI of the country holding the territory, preventing clicks.)[/strike] â€» Patch
08. The people (AI) still love me even with 100% personal income tax.
[strike]09. No speed higher than 2x.[/strike]
ã„´â€» 3x speed added with patch.
[strike]10. Unfamiliar numbers. (Ex. 1T, 4.2M, 24B, etc.), (Note: 1B = 1,000,000,000) [/strike]
ã„´â€» Hovering the mouse cursor over the number reveals detailed information. (Patch)
11. Friendly nations are displayed in orange during diplomatic relations. (In SP2, high friendly nations are displayed in green during diplomatic relations.)
12. Unknown leader customization.
[strike][b][u]13. No auto-save function. [/u][/b][/strike]
ã„´13-1. Cannot set the auto-save point. (e.g., every few minutes)
14. Real-time timer malfunction (= severe lag) (e.g., instead of passing time sequentially from January 1, 2022, to January 13, 2022, it shifts slightly to January 13, 2022).
ã„´â€» Slow response times when pause/restarting due to this issue.
15. When loading, graphs do not display records from previous years. (e.g., when saving in 2020 and loading, records from before 2020 are not displayed.)
16. Population-related graphs in the population statistics are inaccurate. (e.g., the selected item is Korean, but the output shows North Korean.)
17. When clicking on a country in the Main Menu - Single Player - New Game, the profile does not display. (Demographics, Politics, Economy, Military)
18. In the Population Statistics - Support tab, crop saturation is displayed as -na%. (version 1.0.6)

column9:
I am Super Beggar King 3

The development team has a kind of beauty born from brainstem deficiency.

â€”â€”â€”â€”
The first patch is finally out! Although it barely fixed any serious bugs, I'll still give it a good review to encourage them. Let's see what the development team does next; who knows, a good review might turn into a bad one.

â€”â€”â€”â€”
Looks like we can call it a day now.

column8: Le Teaser ma donner envie, sur le papier il avait tout pour passer des bon moments, mais une fois le jeux tÃ©lÃ©charger c'est la dÃ©ception qui vous attend. Aucune vrais gestion Ã©conomique, la gestion militaire que dire ... ils ont juste oublie ce point au moment du dÃ©veloppement.   N'acheter pas ce jeux vous aller perdre du temps la meilleurs partie de ce jeux c'est la CinÃ©matique et c'est tout. Steam ne devrait mÃªme pas proposer cette daube dans son catalogue.
column9: The teaser made me want to play it; on paper, it had everything for a good time, but once you download the game, disappointment awaits. There's no real economic management, and as for military management... what can I say? They simply forgot about it during development. Don't buy this game; you'll just waste your time. The best part of this game is the cutscene, and that's it. Steam shouldn't even offer this garbage in its catalog.

column8: Es  ist furchtbar. Beworben als "die bislang umfassendste und genaueste geopolitische Simulation", was man bekommt sind 3-4 Excel Tabellen die ich in 5 Min selber erstellen kann. ES gibt keine, wirklich KEINE politische Tiefe in der Simulation, Es gibt lÃ¤cherliche 10-15  Gesetze zum Ã¤ndern, die lediglich zwischen legal, illegal und grauzonen unterscheiden. Wie blÃ¶d ist das denn???? Es gibt keine Tutorials, die AnfÃ¼hrer der Nationen sehen aus wie Gooblins oder Aliens, die Grafik ist aus dem Jahr 2005, Atombomben haben literally fast keinen Effekt auf iwas, so ziemlich alle Mechanics sind broken, das Subventionssystem ist absoluter Schwachsinn, es funktioniert einfach NICHTS in diesem Game. Nachdem GolemLabs bereits Die Gilde an die Wand gefahren hat, sollten sie sich ernsthaft Gedanken machen, ob Sie Ã¼berhaupt noch in der Lage sind Spiele zu programmieren. Am liebsten mehre Daumen nach unten, AUF KEINEN FALL KAUFEN!
column9: It's awful. Advertised as "the most comprehensive and accurate geopolitical simulation to date," what you get are 3-4 Excel spreadsheets that I could create myself in 5 minutes. There is absolutely NO political depth in the simulation. There are a laughable 10-15 laws to change, which merely distinguish between legal, illegal, and gray areas. How stupid is that?! There are no tutorials, the leaders of the nations look like goblins or aliens, the graphics are from 2005, atomic bombs have virtually no effect on anything, pretty much all the mechanics are broken, the subsidy system is utter nonsense, and absolutely NOTHING works in this game. After GolemLabs already ran The Guild into the ground, they should seriously consider whether they are even capable of programming games anymore. I'd give it multiple thumbs down if I could. DO NOT BUY IT!

column9:
1. Military units often freeze mid-battle; at least provide an explanation or tutorial.

2. The second generation had a speed-up function, but the third generation only supports 1x speed.

3. The UI is incredibly cluttered; I have no idea how to proceed.

4. I'll wait until it gets good reviews before buying it. I received the release notification at 1 AM and bought it immediately, but it's not as intuitive as the second generation.

column8:
I wanted to like this game. So bad. I even set my expectations to being glad if it was just Super Power 2 reskinned. I truly would have been okay with that. But no it somehow takes about 20 gb to install, for what? there is no content, the UI is broken, there's no way to improve your relations with other countries and if there is, there's no way of being able to tell. No international organizations like the UN or NATO. At least none that I could find. It took me almost 3 hours to figure out how to launch nukes all the while running terribly and decently intermittently making it extremely annoying to do anything, specially when you're trying to explore the planet. The graphics are okay, not being able to select your political ideology, but rather it be established based off your created character, was an interesting idea, but ultimately failed, it made it feel even emptier than what the game is, and its pretty bare boned. Like I said I really wanted to like this game, I set my expectations low and was still somehow extremely disappointed. I never write bad reviews, like ever, I am one of those weird xennials that was raised to not say anything, if there's nothing nice to say. 

But I was also raised to stand up for myself, and I legit feel robbed. I may come back in a few months and check on the game to see if its been updated and hopefully recieves some intensive updates like Cyberpunk to fix this game, but for now I could not in good faith recommend anyone to buy this game in its current state. I had hoped for so many years that there would be a sequel to Super Power 2 and when I saw there was going to be one, I can not even describe how excited I became, which probably attributes to the level of disappointment I felt after buying this. I really hope that I get the requested refund, if Steam denies it and sees how poorly rated this game is, I will never buy directly from Steam again, probably use Epic, GOG, Xbox Game Pass, EA, Ubisoft connect and any games on steam will be purchased from third party sites like greenmangaming etc.

column9:
I want to support the developers.

Yes, this is a meme-worthy game. Yes, it's not what everyone was expecting. But as long as I personally enjoy this game, my positive feedback will remain. There are some rudimentary good features. Considering that all modern games are pure early access, the start is okay. Yes, the game doesn't work as it should; the sliders are broken, absolutely everything is unclear, including where to click and what to do. For example, how do you nuke Israel as Palestine? I have a reactor! I think I have money too. How do you build a missile and launch it? But guys, Super Chef is basically a meme. Remember the second game! What a Unit Designer it was! Mmmm. Abrams on a LT chassis from Tanks Online. It's also a meme, for 899 rubles, but it's a meme! Come on, developers, did you get the development money? It's time to develop the game!

Last patch from January 16, 2023
- Refunds

column9:
This is the only review I've posted.

The concept is incredible, but unfortunately, that's the only incredible thing about it, along with the sheer number of bugs.

I'm extremely disappointed. I was going to play this game with friends, like I did with SuperPower 2, but I told them not to buy it. I don't know if updates will be enough, but I hope so.

A small selection of all the problems encountered in less than 5 hours of gameplay:

- The pause button doesn't work properly.
- The "merge" button (to gather troops) only works half the time and with a huge delay.
- You can't speed up time, so the game quickly becomes boring. I had time to eat, I left the game running, and nothing amazing happened...
- The data doesn't seem consistent. At the start of a game with Australia, I can max out almost all budgets and still have a surplus.
- The same goes for the country's production. At the start of the game, Australia is practically self-sufficient; we import nothing, and the trade balance is several hundred billion dollars in surplus (whereas in 2018, the same year the game started, Australia had a trade balance of 18 billion).
- The AI â€‹â€‹is useless. I played until 2026, and nothing special happened, just a few countries that developed nuclear weapons, but to no avail. To do this:
- No autosave
- There are missing queues for unit production and research
- I feel like the game consumes a huge amount of resources for a frankly mediocre result.

This list isn't exhaustive, but I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. It's not even finished. I found comments from the developers while searching through the game files:

"todo JR - must be done at the SRegion level, not the SCountry level"
"WAIT FOR THE BUILD TO TEST"
Obviously, there are many other comments, but these are just examples.

I found a line in the SuperPower3\Data\SP3.ini file that talks about the game speed, so I tried modifying it to speed it up, but it didn't do anything at all...

Don't buy it, or at least not until it's finished. At this stage, this game is unplayable.

For comparison, Power & Revolution is perfectly optimized compared to SuperPower 3.

column8: Ä°dare eder, geliÅŸtirilmesi ve bazÄ± optimizasyon ayarlarÄ±nÄ±n yapÄ±lmasÄ± gerekiyor. Biraz zamana ihtiyacÄ± var.

I rarely write reviews, and I hate to jump on the hate train for this game, but it really isn't great.  I played SP2, and when people started saying that SP3 wasn't fun because it lacked gameplay, I defended SP3 because SP2 doesn't really have gameplay and was clunky so it just seemed to sound like the previous one to me.  However, after giving SP3 a go, I can't recommend it, and have refunded the game.  There are bugs, like I couldn't hit the play button on the weird character creation screen (why this screen exists is beyond me because I never saw my character in game), some sliders seem useless, the menus are clunky, time has one pace (seriously, why this was done blows my mind), you can't choose your political party etc.
The last one is particularly confusing to me, in a political sim, that now has a full blown character builder, you can't select your political party.  Should your party have a big influence on how you play? Probably not, but it still would allow you the creative freedom to be you. I wanna like this game, but I just can't.  I hope they fix it and maybe in the future I will be willing to give it another go, but for now, I say wait.  This is probably the end to a series that I thought was already dead, but probably definitely will be now.

column8: AllahÄ±ma kitabÄ±ma bu ne boktan oyundur  Atooo.

The game is completely lifeless and many of the core features don't work or are poorly implemented. Likely bad priorities by the developers, alternatively lack of effort and/or funding. Should not sell for over 5 euros at this stage of development and ought to be considered early access. They have some good ideas, such as for the economy, but failed to capitalize or properly implement most or any of them. The choice to focus on character creation and customization and to market it as a game of conquest is telling of the possible lack of prioritization or interest on the part of the developers to actually make a decent simulation of geopolitics rather than something else. Time also runs at a crawling pace and the game has no tools for changing speed. It seems they don't really know their audience?

I actually fell asleep trying to play it, and I say that as an avid statistics nerd and veteran of playing drawn out, heavy-weight political simulators that sometimes run even slower than this. The game needs more work. Could be salvageable one day, but would likely take a long time, but if such a thing happens, I might give it a new chance.

column8:
Obwohl das Spiel sehr schlecht bewertet wurde, habe ich sehr lange darauf gewartet und aufgrundessen trotzdem gekauft. Ich dachte mir naja, sogar wenn es nicht das tollste Spiel des Jahres ist, kann es bestimmt nicht sooo schlecht sein, oder? Dieses Genre ist etwas schwierig, doll zu verkacken! Aber doch. So kritisch kann es doch sein. Die Benutzerschnittstelle ist viel zu groÃŸ, als ob sie eher fÃ¼r Mobilspiele gemacht wÃ¤re. Mit der Karte zu interagieren fÃ¤llt mir sehr schwierig, als ob meine Mausklicks nur ab und zu registriert werden. Das Spiel ist auch nicht besonders gut optimiert, und lÃ¤uft nicht so schnell, wie es auf meinem Rechner eigentlich sollte. Ich kÃ¶nnte es nur schaffen, so 10 Minuten zu spielen, bevor ich dieses Spiel einfach nicht mehr tolerieren konnte. Leider kann ich nichts Ã¼ber die tieferen Aspekte des Spiels sagen, da ich es wie gesagt einfach nicht spielen will. Trotzdem sieht es im groÃŸen und ganzem so aus, als ob der VorgÃ¤nger das bessere Spiel ist. Vieles von dem, was ich mir wÃ¼nschte, fehlt diesem Spiel, und sogar alte Features sind auch nicht ganz da - ich meine, man kann nicht einmal die Geschwindigkeit Ã¤ndern! Wirklich! Du kannst entweder pausieren oder laufen lassen, aber schneller/langsamer geht irgendwie nicht.

Hoffentlich wird das Spiel mit der Zeit besser werden, aber vom aktuellen Stand her bin ich nicht optimistisch. Wenn du irgendwie so ein Spiel wie dieses unbedingt haben willst, wÃ¼rde ich dir empfehlen, Victoria 3 auszuprobieren, sobald es rauskommt.

Saw the negative reviews but, having waited quite a while for this game, bought it to check it out anyway. I thought to myself, "Surely, even if it is bad, it can't be soooo bad, right? I mean, it's a map game!" Well yes. Yes it can be so bad. The UI is absurdly large, the game runs less than acceptably for my specs, and the map is super difficult to easily interact with. I only could stand to play the game for 10 minutes or so, so I unfortunately can't speak to some of the games deeper problems, but from the initial overview it's very possibly inferior to the last game by quite a large margin, having seemingly adding nothing, instead losing things - I mean, you can't even control the game speed! In a grand strategy game!

Hopefully this game will improve with time, but, having looked at it as it stands now, I am less than optimistic. If you really want something like this game, then check out Victoria 3.
column9:
Although the game received very poor reviews, I waited a long time for it and bought it anyway. I thought, well, even if it's not the best game of the year, it can't be *that* bad, right? This genre is pretty hard to mess up! But it was. It can be that bad. The user interface is far too large, as if it were designed for mobile games. Interacting with the map is very difficult, as if my mouse clicks are only registered sporadically. The game isn't particularly well optimized either, and it doesn't run as fast as it should on my computer. I could only manage about 10 minutes of play before I simply couldn't tolerate it any longer. Unfortunately, I can't comment on the deeper aspects of the game because, as I said, I simply don't want to play it. Nevertheless, it looks like the predecessor is the better game overall. Many things I wanted are missing, and even old features aren't fully present â€“ â€‹â€‹I mean, you can't even change the speed! Really! You can either pause or let it run, but you can't really speed it up or slow it down.

Hopefully, the game will improve over time, but as it stands, I'm not optimistic. If you really want a game like this, I'd recommend trying Victoria 3 when it's released.

In a grand strategy game!

Hopefully this game will improve with time, but, having looked at it as it stands now, I am less than optimistic. If you really want something like this game, then check out Victoria 3.

Rendimiento HORRIBLE tras avanzar unos aÃ±os, a pesar de tener un PC que supera con creces los requerimientos recomendados.
Los modos de mapa funcionan como quieren, por no hablar de la UI en general, que entre que es confusa y que los botones y sliders tienen lag se hace horrible.
Puedes literalmente hacer que la industria de madera sea ilegal (????) entre otras cosas sin sentido. Muy pocas leyes nacionales (6), y solo 5 tipos de tratados internacionales.
Con EEUU, la OTAN irÃ³nicamente se une si atacas a otros paÃ­ses sin justificaciÃ³n previa. Puedes subir los impuestos del 23 % al 50 % (que es un Ãºnico porcentaje, no hay tasas especÃ­ficas en nada) y declararle la guerra a medio mundo sin justificaciÃ³n, que subirÃ¡ la opiniÃ³n de los habitantes si gastas suficiente dinero en propaganda.

En resumen: Muy desbalanceado, confuso y falto de contenido. Claramente inferior a la anterior entrega, incluso aunque esta tuviera sus errores. Ya de por si la interacciÃ³n desarrolladores-comunidad era extraÃ±a: Q&As y 1 trailer a principio de aÃ±o seguido de meses de vacÃ­o hasta 1 mes antes del lanzamiento, donde lanzaron el resto de trailers, que eran bÃ¡sicamente las mismas animaciones repetidas durante 3 minutos.
No me extraÃ±a que se insista tanto en los modders y el soporte de Workshop: Pretenden que la comunidad les complete el juego

Edit: Prueba grÃ¡fica de los problemas con las polÃ­ticas internas: https://youtu.be/pCpcAD5XxUQ?t=2161
column9:
The performance is AWFUL after a few years, despite having a PC that far exceeds the recommended requirements.
The map modes are completely unreliable, not to mention the UI in general, which is confusing and has laggy buttons and sliders, making it a nightmare.
You can literally make the timber industry illegal (????) among other nonsensical things. Very few national laws (6), and only 5 types of international treaties.
With the US, NATO ironically joins if you attack other countries without prior justification. You can raise taxes from 23% to 50% (which is a single percentage; there are no specific rates for anything) and declare war on half the world without justification, which will boost public opinion if you spend enough money on propaganda.

In short: Very unbalanced, confusing, and lacking in content. Clearly inferior to the previous installment, even though that one had its flaws. The developer-community interaction was already strange: Q&As and one trailer at the beginning of the year, followed by months of silence until a month before launch, when they released the rest of the trailers, which were basically the same animations repeated for three minutes.
It's no wonder they're so focused on modders and Workshop support: They expect the community to complete the game for them.

Edit: Graphic proof of the problems with their internal policies: https://youtu.be/pCpcAD5XxUQ?t=2161

column8:
What a mess. Very few options. Broken sliders. Nothing seems to make any impact. Whatever country I choose, no matter what I do with the economy, it doesn't make a difference. I start losing money. Even if every sector (USA) shows green/positive. Just to see what would happen, as the US I nuked Russia with 78 ICBMs (the most it would let me select). Russia retaliated with like 6 ICBMs. Then I nuked China. It let me select 33 ICBMs. China retaliated with 20 or so. Other countries started attacking my resources around the world. I could see icons where battles were happening, but I had no idea the details. I understand the Superpower series is more about diplomacy and economics, but jeez I should at least be able to see battle details.

In summary: Superpower is a game that plays itself and only gives you a small glimpse of what it's doing.

I'm not going to ask for a refund. I supported Superpower 1. I believe in Golem Labs, but they have a lot of work ahead to make this one worthwhile.

column8:
very disappointed !! SP2 is more far better that this game... Please uptade SP2 with 2022 information and it will be OK Â§

update 11/2022 : 

I test it for free to avoid paying a high price for an unfinished game. Once the defects are corrected, I will buy it. Too bad to have only 2 hours of play to test such a game...

In short, I'm currently testing version 1.0.3 and it's a real disaster, the game is simply not finished, there is so much information missing:

- the comparison by map, it is colorful but very difficult to read, especially since there is no classification with figures. For example, I know that my HDI is high but how much exactly?
- Where is the GDP growth rate?
- Military units take too long to respond and the way to control them is not intuitive. It's simple though, left click to select and right click to move, this system has been around for 30 years...
- the data is sometimes inconsistent. I'm starting with a poor country that has 80 billion in aid. I think it's his budget/recipe but it bothers me that it's in foreign aid
- military ships absolutely do not correspond to reality. SP is in real simulation not approximations like GPS3
- during a war, countries have 30 allies when in reality not really (e.g. Morocco), it's absurd
- AgÃ©rie with FlorÃ©al ^^ class frigates, PT-76 tanks and only 3 submarines against 6 real.
- purchased units that remain blocked

in short, take SP2 as an example and add things instead of removing them.

I want to test the game and give you regular feedback on the condition of having it for free if I would wait until it is finished to buy it. maybe in 2030 lol

column8:
Unfortunately, I can't recommend this game at the moment, but I see clear potential for improvement here.
Hence my request to the manufacturer - sit down and work on it here.

Of course, many (including myself) were looking forward to the release of the game, but like many, I was hugely disappointed. I have never bought such an unfinished game. In the age of the Internet, it wouldn't be so bad if an open beta had been started and this development status had been published there.

What makes it nearly unplayable:
-Army movements to region, some troops seem to disapear or move along with troops passing by
-Thematic Maps: There is a lack of clarity and uniformity. Insteat of using colors from light blue to blue they should use green over yellow to red
Especially the empire map views you can't see the needed information - Enemy should be red, my country should white, allies blue...  

Things making it easier:
-posibility to occupy all the country with spreading (by splitting the amrys) to all the regions of the country

Wishlist:
-MODDING: Editor for Regions including Borders
-Sea borders, national and international waters
-Peaceful annexations of regions and states (via money, several goals like same culture and language, former belonging to a state...)
-Game speed: high, normal, low, pause
-if possible front lines
-deeper zoom in
-Borders around regions und states.
-Capital cities and government seat

Ethnicity:
-European complex, why no more nationalities? 
-Good idea whit social groups, but it should be more like this: 
Europeans->GermanicPeople->Germans->Bavarians
Europeans->Romans->Italian...
or, if too complex
European->Germans/Italians/...
-Better realtionships within ethnic groups and languages
-Social groups additional to nationalities or ethnic groups.

Popups:
-Not every message needs a popup box. The message should only show up in the ticker down below.

Known bugs:
-Social Groups pie diagram is buggy

Very Nice:
-Satellite view
-Highways (dispite the missing trains)

The game should be more like SP2 but with better graphics.

Please don't hesitate to comment my statements.

I will change my recommentation for this product as soon as it improves.

column8: DO NOT BUY. This game isn't even finished. There are literally pictures and icons missing, so there are just checkbox fillers. What a disgrace. At the least, this should have been early access so we knew what we were getting into, but instead, steam allows shit on their store, and then refuse to refund you. The only refund I've ever asked for on here, and I can't get it. Stay away!

column9: I'm giving it a good review, not because it's fun. I won't go into the flaws, everyone's already talking about them. I'm giving it a good review partly to make up for lost time with SP2, and partly because I hope the development team can learn from their mistakes and make the game better. The fact that so many people are criticizing it at least shows that many people like this type of game, so don't waste such a good IP. I hope the development team can take this seriously, not be discouraged, and make some improvements to the game.

Take SUPERPOWER 2 and...play that instead of Superpower 3!

Sorry, I've requested a refund. I was so excited when I heard about SP3, but...no, sorry, it's just awful.

They should have taken Superpower 2, improved the graphics, adjusted the data and scenarios, and released it as "Superpower 2.5." That would probably have been better.

This isn't even "Deficient," because there's something that could be fixed. It's completely "Inadequate."

column9:
I've been eagerly awaiting this game since its announcement last fall. Expectations weren't sky-high; they could have picked up the second installment, fixed its known bugs and features, refined the combat and diplomacy, beefed up the graphics, and that would have been enough.

Instead, the developers decided to ruin everything. There are no positive aspects here; everything is broken and glitchy. Furthermore, it's quite obvious that the game was originally designed for smartphones, but they decided to port it to PC, as evidenced by its uninformative interface with full-screen windows and giant buttons.

The game plays within itself, and not very well. It's not at all clear how the various parameters interact with each other, or whether they even interact at all.

Thematic maps are terrible, the combat has gotten even worse, though you'd think it could get worse. You can't choose the game speed, choose a political party at the start, or change the political regime...
In short, you don't need this, guys. This all looks like a scam: an unfinished piece of a mobile game is being handed to us as a sequel to a good old game that many of us have fond memories of.
Don't be fooled, maybe in a year or two it will be playable...although, I think they'll simply abandon the game after such a disappointing release, making a few bucks off those unlucky enough to stick with it for more than two hours.
Don't buy it, and I'll refund your money.

Mir fehlen einfach die Worte.
Ich weiÃŸ nicht wie ein Spiel, oder was auch immer das hier mal werden sollte, in einem solchen Zustand verÃ¶ffentlicht werden kann. 

Ich versuche dennoch kurz in Worte zu fassen was alles nicht funktioniert
- Einstellungen fÃ¼r Grafik sind kaputt. Man kann unter Vollscreen die AuflÃ¶sung nicht Ã¤ndern
- Einstellungen von Anfang an so eingestellt dass man nicht nah ran zoomen kann an Einheiten oder StÃ¤dte, man denkt das Feature ist einfach gar nicht da. 
- Alle Entscheidungen der Regierung wirken sofort. Demokratie einfach in Diktatur umwandeln in 1 Tag. Ã–ffentliche Medien privatisieren. KÃ¼he fÃ¼r 3 Billionen in 2 Sekunden einkaufen.. No Problemo! 
- Krieg ist erschreckend schlecht. Einheiten sind zwar nun visuell erfassbar, aber diese zu bewegen ist schrecklich und buggy. 
- Wenn Gegner aufeinander treffen wird eine Kampfregion abgesteckt wo sich KampfverbÃ¤nde, als Knubbel, gegenseitig anfahren und beschieÃŸen. Komischerweise kÃ¶nnen Langstrecken Waffen keine Schiffe attackieren und so viele mehr logische Fehler gibt es hier. 
- Es gibt nur eine Spielgeschwindigkeit und die wirkt manchmal zu schnell. Es wurde auch versÃ¤umt Pausieren auf irgendeine Taste zu legen. Oder eine sinvolle Taste zu legen. Leertaste fÃ¼r Stop/Go oder "P" sind es jedenfalls nicht..

Positiv an dem Spiel ist Ã¼brigens!
- Ich kann 100 Atombomben auf ein Land schmeiÃŸen und keinen juckt es
- Der Charaktereditor ist ganz nett

Beide Punkte machen ca. 15 Minuten SpaÃŸ und dann kann man nun 2 Jahre warten bis das Spiel vielleicht mal ein Spiel wird.
column9:
I'm speechless.

I don't know how a game, or whatever this was supposed to be, could be released in such a state.

Nevertheless, I'll try to briefly describe everything that doesn't work:

- The graphics settings are broken. You can't change the resolution in fullscreen mode.

- The settings are configured from the start so that you can't zoom in on units or cities; it's as if the feature simply isn't there.

- All government decisions take effect immediately. Easily convert democracy into dictatorship in one day. Privatize public media. Buy cows for 3 trillion in 2 seconds... No problem!

- Warfare is appallingly bad. Units are now visually identifiable, but moving them is terrible and buggy.

- When enemies meet, a combat zone is defined where combat units, in a cluster, drive towards and fire on each other. Oddly enough, long-range weapons can't attack ships, and there are so many more logical errors.

- There's only one game speed, and it sometimes feels too fast. They also failed to assign the pause function to any key. Or to assign a sensible key at all. The spacebar for stop/go or "P" certainly aren't options.

On the positive side, though!

- I can drop 100 atomic bombs on a country and nobody cares.

- The character editor is quite nice.

Both of these features provide about 15 minutes of fun, and then we can wait two years until the game maybe actually becomes a game.

column9: Well... it's not as crappy as others say. Compared to the shock of C&C4, it's worth it. Those who say the unit rendering is like a World War I weapon are just not good at it. The rendering changes depending on the level of technology applied. It's not something you can customize like in Part 2. Just character customization that I don't know why it exists, a sudden slowdown that makes me wonder if it's optimized, no time acceleration, Korean is officially supported but the translation is somehow sloppy, the map zoom is worse than in Part 2, why is the Andorran flag on Baekdu Mountain, the country that was completely merged and destroyed keeps appearing as an enemy and is constantly at war, you can't choose the ruling party when you start, the army can't be disbanded and spies can only do counterintelligence and training, the army deployment is like this, merging the same type is also like this, at least tanks and self-propelled guns should be differentiated but that's not there, in Part 2 you could select everything when concluding a treaty with a foreign country, but now when the hell did they sit down to do all those countries one by one?

column8:
Awful Game, Iam writing this in ENglish so more people get the message not to buy it.
I hope I get my money back even though I played it for too long, well playing is a strong word.

I basically sat there waiting a  long time for my units to be built, so I could invade countries and finally do sth since economy was in private hands meaning it was on automatic. But since u cant speed up I waited eons for my strong troops, I closed the game and looked into the commentrs just to find out, that I did experience the maximum of Gameplay. Hooray me.

Maybe if they would add events when sth changes in the system or you can do sth boost immigration  without jjust pulling dials.

column9:
If you're considering buying this game, be sure to check it out first!!

I'm one of the many Super Power 2 fans who've been waiting for this game for 10 years. However, I recommend against buying it just yet. However, the word "yet" is just my own vain hope, so I think it's better to wait for the Super Power 2 remaster. Here are the reasons I don't recommend it:

Decreased intuitiveness, decreased control, decreased realism, and optimization issues.

I'll list these four issues in detail.

1. # Decreased intuitiveness
The original Super Power 2 showed the player "what" and "how" they did it, as well as the "results", very directly and easily, using only text, numbers, and graphs. Super Power 3 makes it difficult for existing fans to even understand "what" and "how" the player should do it. Items that were previously simply listed have been replaced with icons, forcing you to click on them to invest. This makes it difficult to directly perceive the changes resulting from those investments.

Furthermore, adjusting policies with significant domestic impact, such as legality or illegality, requires individual adjustments to each item, unlike in the previous game. The politics menu only displays a very limited amount of information at a glance, making it feel like a significant step backwards in detail.

Furthermore, even if you want to conclude a treaty with a specific country, you can't "multiple selection"â€”you have to repeatedly select each country one at a time. For example, if you want to establish an embassy with France, the UK, or Italy, you can't request multiple selections from France, the UK, or Italy. Instead, you have to request France, the UK, and then Italy. While there may be other ways to do this, even for a first-time Superpower 2 player, it's incredibly easy to understand how to do this. It's a significant regression in intuitiveness.

Furthermore, you can't "bulk split" units that are clustered together. If you still insist this isn't a regression in intuitiveness, then you're the developer of Golem Labs. Just apologize.

2.# Regression in Controls
The slider's lag is... I'll address that during optimization, but the controls are seriously lacking. First of all, the map zoom isn't as smooth as expected. Plus, the icons representing units are larger than in the previous game. What I mean is, if two military units overlap, you can't select the hidden unit even after reviving. Furthermore, the lack of intuitiveness means it takes longer to "find the menu" to do anything compared to the previous game, making it difficult for existing fans to navigate. Existing fans should think of this game as a new title, "Super Power 3," not "Super Power" 3.

3.# Regression in Realism
This is the first thing you'll notice as a Korean... Yes, North Korea and the game aren't currently listed as "in a state of armistice," but rather "at peace." That's incredibly unrealistic.

4. # Optimization Issues
Seriously... I've never seen my monitor's refresh rate drop with such poor graphics. A while ago, Steam hosted an event where they collected "upcoming games" and offered early access... Well, I received a demo of that, and that game ran much better. I'm using an i7 and a 2070, so I haven't seen any drops in refresh rates in most games. So, even when I adjust the slider, there's a significant delay compared to mouse input.

I'm installing it for now as a "fan" and plan to play it for at least a few more hours today, even after writing this review. However, I'm thinking about deleting it and buying the Steam version of Superpower 2. Even for existing game fans, I recommend avoiding the game if possible. Even if you do buy it, get a refund within two hours and wait a year or two for it to be discounted by 70% or more before you buy it.

Imbarazzante; non trovo altro termine per definire questo chiamiamolo "gioco". Dopo aver aspettato quasi 20 anni da Superpower 2 ci troviamo una delusione totale. In tutto e per tutto. in prarica non puoi fare niente, solo attaccare altre nazioni e per di piÃ¹ con poche opzioni. On parliamo poi della grafica. Sembra un arcade. Sono molto molto deluso.

Pro: niente.

Contro: tutto.

Embarrassing; I can find no other term to describe this 'game'. After waiting almost 20 years since Superpower 2 we find ourselves a total disappointment. You can't do anything in the field, only attack other nations, and with very few options to boot. Not to mention the graphics. It looks like an arcade game. I am very very disappointed.

Pros: nothing.

Cons: everything.

column8: Honestly feels like an insult to everyone who waited almost 15 years for this. Controls are janky, sliders are unresponsive, scroll is broken, and thematic maps give the same color for almost everybody. Military and combat are a joke. There is no designer, some models are for a completely different type of unit, and there is a laughably small number of units. The character designer seems almost entirely unnecessary to me. The hardest part was getting it to remember my name, which it didn't anyway.

column8: While the Dev's have been updating the game with patches every week the patches have led to glitches happening often or all the time.  For example the economy, if you start with a GDP or 300 B, reguardless of what you spend in each sector the GDP stays at 300 B, plus you per capita drops continuously thus you never get to make tax rate believable.  also when you go to save the game will crash which means you have to play non stop.  Still issues with military but now when attacking a country your allies will move into first zone you attack and sit there which will not allow you to annex contry.  These issues have been going on for some time and many players have notified the company of them but they still have not been fixed instead company just keeps putting out corrupted patches, game is still long way off from full playable release

column8:
This is meant to be a relatively thorough review.

I waited so damn long for a sequel to SuperPower 2... I wanted to like this game so bad. But it's completely void of things to do. IT NEEDS AN EARLY ACCESS TAG! 

Basically the only goals at the moment in this game are to;

1. Increase GDP / Money by 'boosting' resources such as fuel or gas or plants or cereals. The assets here are really really limited. It feels like there should be tons more. Basically the economy UI exists entirely in two different menus, one of which has your taxes and budget, the other has sectors you can invest in. Very lackluster.

2. Increase your army size by buying or building more units. You can also research, but this is limited simply to new 'levels' of technology. Ie, you cant change your units weaponry or customise them at all, just make new unit designs with different tech levels affecting their cost to build. Again, lackluster and not much content around it. Far more development needed to make this system interesting, including unit customisation and research options beyond what is currently offered.

3. Invading other nations. This links in to the above. It feels very barebones. AI is slow. Nothing really, 'happens' per-se in the game-world. I played as Australia and my units were for some reason in the sea near the Phillipines (nearly all of my navy), I wasn't allied or even friendly with nations we are IRL. Was incredibly off. I declared war on and invaded New Zealand and Malaysia declared war on me. 

That is all that happened. No game events. No immersion. No world building. Even the combat and process of invading was boring. No 'occupy all' right click context command, so you have to manually split units and put them into individual provinces so the enemy nation 'loses control' of it, at which point you annex it through your national legislation and laws menu or whatever it is. 

It's all very, weird.

Some of the things in this game 'seem' appealing, such as the human development stat tracking but its all meat and no bones. There is nothing backing all these flashy looking things to make them worthwhile.

You can't build anything. No new airbases. No nothing in that form of gameplay. 

The world map looks a bit unfinished in my opinion, too.

Also, bugs. When launching, the game forces full screen 7680x1440. I changed to windowed 1920x1080 and now upon opening the game again the next day, it forced full screen and stretched 1920x1080 instead so now the UI is messed up and only two buttons are visible, none of which are the settings to fix it. That's great.

Overall, not impressed. I didn't refund it though. Potential is there, and it was only $30.

column8:
This game sets in the year [current year].
You play as a young game tester on a quest to test a very early version of a newly released game resembling Superpower 2. 

When you press download, steam contacts some storage servers to download all the files from a game build.

The game is made in Unreal Engine 4 and captures every aspect of an early access V0.01 beta demo game. The mouse is working and can be moved freely over the entire resolution of the screen, and there are menus like 'multiplayer' and 'settings'. There is no doubt that this is a game project files download. Music has been added.

Is is also possible to start a game, and you can test the various active elements. The game is a view of planet earth which can be rotated, and it is partitioned into countries which are clickable. Clicking a country will open up a set of rough looking menus.

Clicking the elements, rotating and sliding stuff is fun for a while, then it gets boring. But maybe it will be fun if you play the game after a pause. I am not sure about this. 

That's all. This is the review. OK
column9:
This game sets in the year [current year].
You play as a young game tester on a quest to test a very early version of a newly released game resembling Superpower 2. 

When you press download, steam contacts some storage servers to download all the files from a game build.

The game is made in Unreal Engine 4 and captures every aspect of an early access V0.01 beta demo game. The mouse is working and can be moved freely over the entire resolution of the screen, and there are menus like 'multiplayer' and 'settings'. There is no doubt that this is a game project files download. Music has been added.

Is is also possible to start a game, and you can test the various active elements. The game is a view of planet earth which can be rotated, and it is partitioned into countries which are clickable. Clicking a country will open up a set of rough looking menus.

Clicking the elements, rotating and sliding stuff is fun for a while, then it gets boring. But maybe it will be fun if you play the game after a pause. I am not sure about this. 

That's all. This is the review. OK

Long story short, this game is entirely horrifically ludicrous. If you have ever dreamt to make Jamaica or Gabon super power in 4-5 years, this game unprecedentedly convenient for you.
I firmly believe that they had started to develop this game as a mobile game then they turned into develop PC game otherwise there is no explanation of this game. As a fan of SP2, This game just debases SP2's legacy. 

Besides of the numereous amount of bugs and crashes the gameplay solely rubbish. After spent an hour in this game I thought I just scammed then I am enlightened and starting to enjoy the awfulness of this game and I wanted to enlist them:
[list]
[*] They added angel investor to the game disguised as a USA. You can easily demand billions of dollars from the USA as a fiscal aid.
[*] Most of the countries undoubtedly share with you their military technologies.
[*] You can ban every political parties and even elections without any consequences. In my experience, they boosted my approval though.
[*] Regardless of which country that you control, you can increase the taxes 100% and give incenvtives billions of dollars to every sector. This will be skyrocketed your economy and you already know that where you are going to find enough cash at the early stages. 
[*] You can nuke and obliterate every country that have bothered you. Most of the cases nobody cares. 
[*] You can perform stress test to your computer whilst playing this game which is a brilliant idea.
[*] Most importantly, this game is very didactic. If you do not know the Earth's shape or existence of the moon, the game literally engrave this information into your brain. 

[/list]

column9:
[h1] The Shame of Simulation. [/h1]

The concept is so appealing, the teaser presents a complete game, and we naively assume that THQ has looked to the competition to see what's out there (Paradox Interactive or Creative Assembly...). We already dream of leading a great nation, then we launch the game and become the leader... of a virtual turd.

My assessment might seem a bit biased at the moment, so I'll elaborate a bit. The character creator is brief. It's a dispensable step in which you choose your appearance, language, country, and religion. That's it. You won't see your character again, and these characteristics are as few as they are useless.

Then, the game starts (after a relatively long loading time), and that's where the trouble begins. The first thing to know is the complete absence of a tutorial or dynamic interaction with the player (which is [b]ESSENTIAL[/b] for any grand strategy game). You're on a world map, adrift in a void with a UI that, despite its "decent" appearance, lacks depth (no highlighting, no animations, no pop-ups). Time passes in days, and there's no fast-forward or shortcut to pause.

The options are numerous, and you'll start to get curious, adjusting parameters for your economy, diplomacy, politics, and army, but nothing really happens. The numbers change, sure... that's about it. Nonexistent immersion. Nonexistent interactions.

I've spent thousands of hours on Knight Rider, Civilization, Hearts of Iron, Total War, etc. This game doesn't even come close to any of them. It's empty, poorly optimized, ugly, and misleading. These days, publishers can churn out these monstrosities with a pretty, presentable teaser without even letting us play them. I actually tried to dig deeper, but all I found was a waste of time and money. I would have preferred to spend those few hours [strike]sculpting a phallus out of polymer clay[/strike] sleeping; that would have been much more productive.

Some hope that "updates" will improve the current state of the game, and this is the very first time in my life that I'll tell you: No, no update can ever fix this burning house. [b]The carnage is profound, and the scam is undeniable.[/b]

column8:
Golemlabs has returned with a successor to the legendary game, Superpower 2, and they have definitely gone for something special this time. 

In superpower 3 you are playing as a QA tester, fighting your way through a non-functional alpha-build, managing data through a broken UI, exploring game breaking bugs, and enjoying epic battles with the low framerate.

The aesthetics are heavily inspired by early 2000s video game prototypes. You will be playing in 1024x768, and while It's not for everyone, it truly makes the experience authentic.

It's amazing how some people can play a game for less than an hour and write a horrible review, I hope that anyone reading these will check the play times before reading the review. This version reminds me of the original Superpower, It plays very similar, with few exceptions. One being, this game is no longer a turn based game. 

This is a Geopolitical game. One picks a country to be the leader of, and it is their job to either stay in power, become a superpower or take over the world. I would highly recommend buying this game and playing it for more than an hour. I've played all of the Superpower games and other geopolitical games. Superpower III has major potential. This version runs like a beta. Give it time, this game will be worth it. 

To be perfectly honest, I didn't like the second version of Superpower, but the first one, I would love nothing more than to play it again. it was spectacular.

column8:
It's disappointing in every sense of the word. To use an analogy - if games were like meals served to you in a restaurant, this game is just the plate on which the meal should have been.
Also, regarding the price, it doesn't really seem fair to charge 30â‚¬ for what is essentially a Google Earth with some barely functioning sliders slapped on top.
I hope this game gets some much need love because, despite its current state, I think it has potential, and I will gladly change my review if it does improve. But right now, I can't in good conscience recommend it.

(18.04.2023)
Well, it seems that the game has been abandoned for good. While there have been some bug fixes, the game isn't anywhere near a "fixed" state. And it is light-years from an "enjoyable" state.
Quite frankly, this game is easily one of the worst disappointments I have ever experienced in all my years of being a fan of strategy games. It didn't even begin to improve before it got abandoned, like, for example, Imperator: Rome did. I deeply regret my decision not to refund this game when I had the chance.

column8:
Is this early access? Because it looks like it!
I was a fan of Super Power 2. That game was detailed (not for all countries, but in general). This part came without a lot of details from previous one and also more simple and casual. It's looks like demo or preview for something better. You can see graphical gliches and conrols bugs from start. Captions on main screens with question marks - are there places for future cntent or regular bugs?

Submarines are still divided into nuclear and common, and the rest of the types have been cut down - where is cannon artillery as a class? transport helicopters, APC, military vehicles? I was sure that drones will be added - it itmportant part, but no, there isn't. Where is the world military market at all?!!

Contracts? Where is autobalance option or fixed prices? How much does it cost? Try to by for 1M then 10M then 100M! Got! So, maybe its cost was 11M or 99M.

What was added after part 2? El Presidente customization! Tropico fans will be glad.

Advantages:
+ More modern graphics
+ In some places map is more detailed
+ (not checked) Mods support
Disadvantages:
- Bugs, glitches
- Primitivisation of economics
- Great primitivisation of warfare
- The whole system of contracts

column9:
3 hours of playtime, refunded.

This game is ready to completely ravage your memories.

Dia 3 is still a game where you can see the cracks while you're playing, but this one makes you fall asleep the moment you see the globe...

The UI is unbelievable for a 2022 game...

And I can't even fathom why they added leader customization so early in the game...

It's completely useless... And for newbies, is there a tutorial?

Don't expect that.

It's like putting a StarCraft newbie on a Hunter map with 1 (user): 178 (PC) free-for-all mode.

column9: I was waiting for this game, hoping that a new, good game about modern geopolitics would finally come out and I could have some serious fun. Why put off tomorrow's nuclear winter when I can have it right now? I didn't expect the game to come out so early, but now I understand why... The game is terrible, very rough, more like an early access or a demo than a finished product. I don't see the point in describing it in detail, because everything about the game is absolutely pathetic, a sort of geopolitical simulator for a phone.

column9:
I was excited because the credits proudly included photos of the development team, but...
SuperPower 3 has been rebuilt with modern visuals and game systems, adding everything that made the franchise a success over the past 20 years. -> karma, graphics upgrades complete.
An improved tutorial has been introduced to help new players quickly adapt to the game. -> Nothing like that.
A realistic recreation of international politics, centering on 194 countries around the world -> Not exactly.
Extensive strategies and dozens of scenarios based on real-world events -> 14 scenarios.
Gameplay implemented by analyzing and converting real-world data -> I don't know if they converted and implemented it, but it's virtually impossible to verify in-game.
Createable characters with nearly every nationality, religion, and representative outfit in the real world -> Small appearance in the upper left corner. No effect.
No real end, allowing for continuous replayability -> I wish there was an end...
