column9:
There are just too many things to complain about regarding Supershit3. After waiting for half a year, this is the thing they released; I have to rant about it.

1. First of all, the developers' economics is at least a century ahead of human civilization. Because, with the tax rate the same as at the start, there are instances where GDP increases fivefold while income remains the same. If that's the case, why would countries bother developing their economies? Since GDP increases but income doesn't rise accordingly, and might even fall, it seems only players experience this bug. Previously, I used a game where China's GDP was 77 trillion USD and the US GDP was 24 trillion USD, but even with 100% taxation, my income wasn't as high as the US's. If this isn't a bug, it can only be explained by the US tax rate already being higher than 100%. And this bug is a common occurrence; it happens in almost every game.


2. Secondly, the political system and capital city cannot be changed. The game hints that monarchies can be changed to democratic systems, but none of the countries I tried were monarchies. For example, China cannot be democratized in this game. Even if you make Chinese politics more open than the US, and fully enable online protests, you still can't change the political system (actually, there's a similar problem in point 2, but it's a bug; North Korea and Iran can be changed to multi-party democracies, while point 3 doesn't support changing the political system). So, according to the developer's bizarre theory, Taiwan and South Korea should still be under a party-state system, and World War II wouldn't have broken out because that art student couldn't change Weimar Germany. (Incidentally, there's another bug with the political system: there's only one election, and after that, no country seems to have the will to hold elections, even resulting in a bizarre situation where there are -6 months until the next election).

3. The military aspect is a precipitous decline. First, the interface is extremely cumbersome; air force units need to be manually moved to the airport one by one. The movement of the army and navy is not only much more cumbersome than in version 2, but also riddled with bugs, often getting stuck in place. Conquering territory is also extremely frustrating. In version 2, anyone with eyes could clearly see where they had occupied territory, but in version 3, it's practically impossible. Furthermore, perhaps out of a mischievous sense of humor, the developers removed the original territorial conquest function. This means that to conquer a country, you need to manually manipulate troops to occupy each territory bit by bit. I experienced this firsthand when attacking Taiwan. Compared to the dire situation in version 2, China's economy and military in version 3 are second only to the US. After deploying troops at the start, I could quickly cripple the KMT army. However, while attacking the KMT army was easy, conquering Taiwan required manually manipulating troops to occupy areas, and this process took much longer than the actual fighting. After spending four years finally conquering the entirety of Taiwan, I looked at the remaining hundred-plus countries and their densely packed territories, and silently gave up on the grand ambition of unifying the world.

4. Like the military aspect, diplomacy is a complete collapse. The rich international organizations of the second game, like NATO and the UN, have vanished, replaced by an extremely rudimentary diplomatic interface and a bunch of ridiculously poor nations. Simple diplomacy between countries seems limited to two-way communication, with no third party allowed. And after playing for a short while, a poor nation will come begging for moneyâ€”sometimes offering money in exchange for certain conditions, sometimes simply asking for money outright. I don't know where they get their confidence; their shamelessness is so extreme that even Taiwan's diplomatic allies would have to call them "daddy." If I had that kind of shamelessness in begging, I could probably achieve financial freedom as a beggar.

5. Meanwhile, the developers' color-coding ability, like their economics, is at least a century ahead of current human capabilities. In the second game, it was easy to observe resource output, inter-state relations, and population density because the differences in color were very clear. But in the third game, for some reason, this was abandoned, using almost uniform colors. So when you try to see differences between different regions, you'll find they're basically all the same color.

6. Character creation is utterly useless. I was puzzled when this feature was first released. It's not like The Sims; why would a game simulating a nation need a character creation system? My guess was correct. This feature is indeed useless. Once you create your character, you never see them again, and their impact on the nation is almost zero. Furthermore, the developers went to the trouble of creating a useless character creation system while removing the option to choose your starting party (it seems you can't choose your initial party), eliminating any chance for smaller parties to rise to power.

7. Most of the newly added features are also useless, even more ridiculous than point 2. For example, the almost useless immigration system. I simply can't understand why an upgraded version of China, with a per capita income roughly equal to that of the US and a more politically open stance, can't attract any immigrants. Does China not even want to be a melting pot of races? Even in the real world, Guangdong has illegal immigrants. How come China, which is more developed than the US, can't attract immigrants? Is it only Americans who are qualified to absorb immigrants? As for the racial classification that replaces language and religion, it's utterly ridiculous. The developers have once again brought theories from at least a century into the present. In all my years, this is the first time I've ever heard of the existence of "Taiwanese" and "Hong Kong" races. This bizarre theory is something even Tsai Ing-wen wouldn't dare utter. The Taiwanese government itself says that 96% of its population is Han Chinese. Moreover, South Korea and North Korea are two sovereign states, both composed of Koreans.

8. Returning to the basic gameplay, besides the rampant bugs, Supershit 3 suffers from extremely severe lag. This has a unique characteristic: I don't know if my computer is too weak, or if the game is so advanced that it's beyond the capabilities of modern computers. Anyway, even with the graphics settings at their lowest, it still lags frequently, often accompanied by bugs, giving players a surprise. But I think my computer doesn't lag this much even in the late game of Stellaris. Is this game really that advanced?

9. Of course, I wouldn't agree that it has no merits at all. After all, this game has been in development for over a year, and someone like Kun Kun could play basketball after two and a half years of practice, so some progress is normal. First, the newly added pollution, arable land restrictions, and internet and media control are quite good. Second, the industrial development patterns and types are much more reasonable than in game 2. Compared to the direct investment model of "black technology" in game 2, the subsidy-based upgrade of the industrial chain in game 3 is clearly more scientific. After all, factory expansion and upgrades take time; they can't be done in a second. Also, compared to game 2, game 3 fully demonstrates the importance of science and technology in production. For example, the US's per capita productivity is several times higher than China's at the start, so it seems unlikely that there will be a situation where people blindly rush into economic development or blindly invest in industries to build up the economy. Furthermore, the ability to trade resources with other countries is a more realistic setting than in game 2.

In conclusion, SuperShit3 is a pile of shit. Just like Lu Xun said, a flawed warrior is still a warrior, and a perfect fly is still a fly. If SuperShit2 is a warrior, then SuperShit3 is a fly. By the way, here's a suggestion for the developers: if you really don't know what to do, just copy SuperPower2 exactly, optimize the UI and graphics, add data from various countries, and finally delete some bugs. The finished product will definitely be much better than the current one.

column9:
Absolute garbage.

The only gameplay this game currently offers is moving sliders.

But even for a "slider-moving simulator," this game wouldn't be any good, since even this simple function lags like crazy.

Sure, you could also pump massive amounts of money into the military, legalize drugs, and ban all other political parties.

But the population doesn't really care.

For an early alpha phase, it might almost be acceptable with a lot of goodwill.

BUT: It's clever that you can't speed up time; I'm sure many people will spend an extra hour or two in the game (for a refund).

I thought maybe there was some kind of gameplay hidden among all the sliders and lag.

Refund requested, complaint filed ;)

column8: Was tue ich da? Ich bin wirklich ein Freund von solchen Spielen. Einmal ein Land regieren und schauen was draus wird. Hier kann ich Geld in ein anderes Land z.b. schicken. Was passiert? Keiner weiÃŸ es. Ich lasse Panzer bauen, und? Es ist fÃ¼r mich nicht ersichtlich, welche Folgen meine Handlungen haben. Habe mir auf Youtube ein paar Folgen anderer Let's Player angeschaut. Es bringt leider nichts. Am interessantesten ist noch die Charakter erstellung. im Moment kann das Spiel leider nicht empfehlen. Vielleicht macht ja mal einer ein Tutorial damit ich das kapiere. :-(
column9: What am I even doing here? I'm really a fan of these kinds of games. It's about ruling a country and seeing what happens. Here, I can send money to another country, for example. What happens then? Nobody knows. I have tanks built, and so what? It's not clear to me what the consequences of my actions are. I've watched a few Let's Player videos on YouTube. Unfortunately, it doesn't help. The character creation is the most interesting part. At the moment, I can't recommend the game. Maybe someone will make a tutorial so I can understand it. :-(

I've already gotten a refund. I hope future updates will include new content.

column9:
Here are the game's pros and cons:
Pros:
1 - Well, can you create your own al-president?
2 - Well... that's about it :)
Cons:
1 - Lack of optimization, it lags a lot at first speed... although there's no such thing as first, second, or third speed. This crap just lags... and it has high requirements.
2 - No time acceleration in the game
3 - No choice of ruling party
4 - Lack of proper control over policymaking, etc. Apparently they wanted to make it easier for people... but apparently it didn't work. Plus, everything looks like it's made for a mobile game... flat interface, etc.
5 - Lack of proper control over troops, and there are also bugs that don't close the view of troops and aircraft, meaning movement and flight zones... a laggy mess that closes itself over time. 6 - The banal lack of control transfer for the AI â€‹â€‹like in the second game.

There are still some downsides to the game that you only notice while playing... and I couldn't play for a long time, so I'm refunding my money. The same nationalism... As was said, there are 3 nationalities living in Russia... (Chechens, Russians, Siberians, if I'm not mistaken). If they really wanted to create a detailed geopolitical simulator where all the nationalities in each country would be listed and what percentage they represent... then they screwed up here, and also gave Crimea to Ukraine. A bunch of downsides, and the game feels like it's in early access... but even early access can't be this bad.
I had hopes for the game... but the second game with mods is still better than this piece of crap.

column8: After having played way too much of this game, i am changing my review. the game should have been released as early access. its clear that GL haven't learned anything since their prior releases. what a crap show. the game is slow and buggy, far too much micro management, combat is still broken and wonky. the only way to make the economy work is to use a memory editor to fix some of the bugs that can happen in the game. now the devs are working to improve the game, i just refuse to waste my time being their QA tester.

column9: An absurd disappointment. The game has zero depth. People talk so much about Geopolitical Simulator, but that game has the most depth in terms of geopolitics, and it's infinitely better than this one. This game has nothing, not even a parliament to make the game more realistic and challenging. You are simply a sovereign who does everything without any hindrance. The economy and the political aspects are very weak, quite simplistic. I don't recommend it; the game has absolutely no depth.

column9:
[h1]A touching game, on par with Clementine[/h1]

Children who have longed for this type of game since elementary school are finally seeing this game again after decades. I was one of those people, too.

And then, with a pounding heart, I opened it and realized the beautiful UI, the stunning Earth graphics, and the AI, which is even smarter than humans. This game itself is a godsend, on par with Clementine. I'm reliving the same excitement I felt after Clementine for the second time.

To everyone reading this review, I highly recommend buying this game. Superpower 3, a Clementine-level masterpiece that will take care of your nostalgia.

I'm not the only one feeling this grace and emotion. Let's feel it together.

[spoiler] I can't be the only one who's been affected. This fucking game is beyond crap. It's filth. Get a refund and run away before the two-hour mark.

And some gays might think, "What did I see after only 25 minutes?" Think about it the other way. I saw all sorts of crap in those 25 minutes, so I quit after 25 minutes...[/spoiler]

column8:
Lets call it what it is. The game isn't nearly finished, and the publisher wants to capitalise on the current global turmoil, because everyone wants to see what happens if X Country Nukes Y country.

There is virtually nothing in the way of additional content added compared to SuperPower II, and although the graphics have been upgraded, I would almost call it a downgrade, because the menus take up the entire screen. In some ways, there is less features here. You can't pick your political party, so when I'm Canada, I have to be a bloody Liberal. And your decisions as a leader other than controlling your military seem to revolve around who can marry, and whether or not women can have an abortion. 

No Tutorials, and everything is considerably different from SuperPower II in terms of how you use military, adjust your sliders, etc.

So much missed opportunity for Greatness, and its buggy as hell. For those expecting this to be fixed with patches, keep in mind that SuperPower II is still a mess. But at least its enjoyable to play.

column8:
This game is so bad it feels like its main purpose is money laundering. I submitted a request for a refund and I can guarantee that you will do the same if you purchase this. 

It looks and feels like an alpha, yet there is no disclaimer stating this. The UI is bloated, there is no tutorial, there is hardly any content. To add on the UI, when a territory is taken over by your enemy's army the notification fills up the entire screen and the button to dismiss the notification is relatively small. I loved Superpower 2 and even that has more action and content than Superpower 3 despite being nearly 20 years old. If this gets fixed in a year or two I'll be back, but until then I'll be playing the Millennium Dawn mod for HOI4.

column9:
Disappointing! Utterly disappointing!

The grain textures are all pixelated; the character creation screen even crashed my game the first time I played it.

The game lacks a tutorial system. Even though I played the second game, I was completely lost with this one. For example, I had no idea where the money for investing in goods came from, and there was no feedback on the effects of investments; whether there was a surplus or deficit was entirely based on guesswork.

Also, why did they remove time acceleration? Why couldn't they design multiple acceleration levels for players to choose from?

The game's interactive system is also terrible. The economic interface lacks sufficient line graph statistics; GDP, unemployment rate, goods profit and loss growth, and land use are completely devoid of statistical charts. Conversely, the less important political interface has line graphs for stability and approval ratings. Adjusting the budget slider requires dragging the mouse bit by bit; adding small left and right arrows would make fine-tuning much easier.

The diplomacy system is also completely simplified. All the international organizations present in the second game are gone. Even designing a special UN meeting and voting system or a Security Council military intervention mechanism would have been quite interesting. The current diplomacy options are even worse than in the second game, and the number of diplomatic treaties that can be signed is extremely limited.

Only the political system gave me a slight sense of novelty. Different ethnic groups have different personalities, and approval ratings are divided into public and media ratings. It even uses Hofstede's cultural theory to describe a country's cultural characteristics, which is very interesting, but unfortunately, that's about it.

I really hope you can, like with *The Scroll of Taiwu* or *No Man's Sky*, immediately start working on improving the game after receiving such disastrous feedback. Otherwise, I can only say thank goodness.

Kein ranfÃ¼hren an das Spiel, kein how to , kein Intro.
Spiele das Land und klicke dich durch alle MenÃ¼s und verstehe nicht worum es geht...

GrÃ¶ÃŸte Kritikpunkte bislang :

1. Komplett fehlende Einleitung. 
Die MenÃ¼s sind an sich ganz okay und Ã¼bersichtlich, aber es fehlt in vielen Dingen die Tiefe. Das fÃ¤ngt schon damit an , dass man nicht versteht warum man sich beim handeln erst kompliziert durch jedes Land durchklicken muss, statt einer Liste mit potenziellen Handelspartnern. Export / Import klingt erstmal easy, aber es hat kaum bis nicht nachvollziehbare EinflÃ¼sse auf die Gesamtwirtschaft, 

2. Budgets.
Es steht per Mousover zwar dabei was fÃ¼r was sein soll, aber man merkt nichts davon. Man klickt sich munter durch und regelt hoch und runter bis man einigermaÃŸen im Plus ist. Das hat mal mehr oder weniger Einfluss auf StabilitÃ¤t und Zuspruch, aber man checkt einfach gar nicht was mit was zusammenhÃ¤ngt. Es wird nix erklÃ¤rt. Man kommt sich total verlassen vor.

3. MenÃ¼s.
Komplett lieblos und keine Bindung fÃ¼r den Spieler. Man hat zu keinem Zeitpunkt das GefÃ¼hl man ist wirklich der Leader eines Landes. Es kommt gar kein Feeling auf. Nachrichten super klein und kaum erkennbar, der Rest der Welt still . Man bekommt eigentlich gar keine Hinweise oder Dialogfenster. Niemand spricht mit dir , anybody out there?! 

4. Trailer vs. Spiel.
Der Detaillierungsgrad ist 0,0 erreicht. Das Spiel zwingt dich in eine hÃ¤ssliche AuflÃ¶sung und lÃ¤sst dich dann in einer kalten Spielwelt mit kaum bis gar keinem Einfluss zurÃ¼ck und du stehst da so... ehm ja. column9:
Ugh, this is really bad... No introduction to the game, no how-to guide, no intro. You just play the country, click through all the menus, and don't understand what it's all about...

Biggest criticisms so far:

1. Completely lacking an introduction.

The menus themselves are okay and clear, but they lack depth in many areas. It starts with the fact that you don't understand why you have to click through each country in such a complicated way to trade, instead of having a list of potential trading partners. Export/import sounds easy at first, but it has little to no discernible impact on the overall economy.

2. Budgets.
While it's shown on mouseover what each item is for, you don't really get any sense of it. You just click around, adjusting things up and down until you're somewhat in the black. This has varying degrees of impact on stability and popularity, but you simply don't understand what's connected to what. Nothing is explained. You feel completely lost.


``` 3. Menus.

Completely uninspired and offers no connection to the player. At no point do you feel like you're truly the leader of a nation. There's absolutely no sense of immersion. Messages are tiny and barely legible, the rest of the world is silent. You don't get any hints or dialogue options. Nobody talks to you, anybody out there?!

4. Trailer vs. Game.

The level of detail is nonexistent. The game forces you into an ugly resolution and then leaves you in a cold game world with little to no control, and you're just standing there... well, yeah. The trailer shows armies, people on the streets, recognizable cities, etc. You'll search in vain for any of that.

Conclusion: A complete rip-off. The game isn't worth a single euro. A truly terrible sequel. Shame on you... seriously...

column9:
As a longtime Super Power 2 user and network administrator, I've been waiting for the game to be developed for over a decade.
But the actual game is so shoddy that it looks like it hasn't even been completed for a year or two. Even the simple UI is so cluttered and frustrating that it's impossible to understand. Even map changes and other controls are incomprehensible.
Furthermore, considering the high system requirements compared to the graphics, optimization seems far from perfect. In short, this game is a lousy, shiny mess.

After seeing the company's previous game, The Guild 3, I was skeptical, hoping it wouldn't be as bad as its predecessor. However, it ended up following the same path. Some companies hate releasing 3s, but this company is the only one that's going to fail if it does.

They say you should leave when the applause arrives, but this company has tarnished my memories by releasing a crappy game while I'm still applauding. I don't want to see it again.

Summary: A crappy game. If you buy it for more than 5,000 won, you're a retard.

GolemLabs, ce petit studio qui se targue de faire des jeux poussÃ©s, avec une IA avancÃ©e, nous rÃ©gale d'un jeu bÃ¢clÃ© Ã  un point tout juste hallucinant.

Il est tout bonnement infect: il a Ã©tÃ© expÃ©diÃ© en quatriÃ¨me vitesse sans aucune pensÃ©e pour les joueurs :
- pas d'option pour accÃ©lÃ©rer la vitesse du jeu

Des trucs aussi simple que faire tourner la camÃ©ra autour du globe est bancal ; saccadÃ©, suit un axe improbable et dÃ©rive vers le Nord ou le Sud lorsqu'on essaye de faire un simple mouvement horizontal...

SP2 Ã©tait bloquÃ© dans une rÃ©solution d'un ancien temps et Ã©tait parcouru de bugs infÃ¢mes (souvenez vous des fameuses provinces au Belize ou en Afrique de l'Ouest qui faisaient instantanÃ©ment disparaÃ®tre les armÃ©es qui y rentraient) mais il tenait debout. Lui.
column9:
Golem Labs, this small studio that prides itself on making sophisticated games with advanced AI, has delivered a game so sloppy it's almost unbelievable.

It's simply awful: it was rushed out with no thought for the players:

- no option to speed up the game
- map filters disable themselves
- impossible to create your own military presets (by the way, hello WWII vehicle models from 2018)
- a simplified UI worthy of a mobile port
- military units that are arbitrarily stuck in place

I didn't even try the multiplayer, but I imagine it was rushed like everything else. Even something as simple as rotating the camera around the globe is clunky; Jerky, following an improbable axis, and drifting north or south when you try to make a simple horizontal movement...

SP2 was stuck in an outdated resolution and riddled with infamous bugs (remember those provinces in Belize or West Africa that instantly wiped out any armies that entered them?) but it held together. This one.

Global-Strategiespiele-Fans sollten bei den etablierten Titeln von Paradox bleiben.  
Hier mal ein paar Punkte:

Auch gibts keine MÃ¶glichkeiten Kartelle o.Ã¤. wie etwa eine OPEC zu bilden.
- Die Haushaltsbilanz scheint verbuggt zu sein. So erwirtschafte ich laut BudgetÃ¼bersicht Ã¼ber Jahre einen Ãœberschuss im zweistelligen Milliarden Bereich. Gleichzeitig steigt aber weder mein investierbarer Kontostand in gleichem MaÃŸe, noch sinken meine Staatsschulden, sofern man voraussetzt, dass die ÃœberschÃ¼sse zu 100% in die Tilgung von Schulden flieÃŸt (obwohl die Schuldentilgung schon ein fixer Punkt im Haushaltsbudget ist und dementsprechend die ÃœberschÃ¼sse als tatsÃ¤chlich verfÃ¼gbares Guthaben zÃ¤hlen mÃ¼ssten)
- Die komplette Diplomatie ist einfach nur ramsch. Anders als in Super Power 2 gibt es keine deutlich sichtbaren BÃ¼ndnisse wie NATO, Afrikanische Union oder Freihandelszonen als internationale Vertragswerke, denen man beitreten bzw. austreten (BREXIT) kann.
-Sobald es um militÃ¤rische Konflikte dritter Staaten geht, wird angezeigt, dass es Konflikte um Regionen gibt. Die jeweiligen Staaten befinden sich dann jedoch bei anklicken deren Staatsansicht nicht miteinander im Krieg?! Auf der Weltkarte ist gleichzeitig schwer nachvollziehbar welche Regionen durch welchen Staaten besetzt gehalten werden usw. 
Auch hier war Super Power 2 deutlich besser!

FAZIT: Ein unfertiges Spiel, das so viel mehr kÃ¶nnte, wenn man es anstÃ¤ndig entwickelt hÃ¤tte bzw. einfach Super Power 2 als Basis genommen und etwas aufgewertet hÃ¤tte. Wirklich schade.
column9:
Unfortunately, I can't recommend this game. In my opinion, it's worse than Super Power 2. If they had remastered Super Power 2 and fixed some of the bugs from back then, it would have been much better than this game, which feels like an Early Access title. Fans of global strategy games should stick to Paradox's established titles.

Here are a few points:

- Despite a high-end PC, the game doesn't run smoothly - (it probably doesn't use more processing power than EU IV, which runs smoothly)

- As many reviews have already mentioned, the sliders for budgets and investment amounts in some sectors are unclear and not sensitive enough (for example, if I want to reduce a budget by just 1 billion to balance the budget)

- Many aspects of the economic system are simply not fully thought through. While I can see my market share in global trade in each sector, I can't find an overview of global trade anywhere. Who holds monopolies? Where are espionage missions worthwhile for economic sabotage? There are also no options to form cartels or similar organizations like OPEC.

- The budget balance seems to be bugged. According to the budget overview, I've generated a surplus in the tens of billions for years. However, my investable account balance doesn't increase to the same extent, nor does my national debt decrease, assuming that 100% of the surpluses are used for debt repayment (even though debt repayment is already a fixed item in the budget, and therefore the surpluses should count as actual available funds).

- The entire diplomacy system is simply awful. Unlike in Super Power 2, there are no clearly visible alliances like NATO, the African Union, or free trade zones as international agreements that one can join or leave (Brexit).

- When it comes to military conflicts involving third-party states, it displays that there are conflicts over regions. However, when clicking on the respective states' state views, they are not at war with each other?! The world map makes it difficult to understand which regions are occupied by which countries, etc.

Super Power 2 was significantly better in this regard!

CONCLUSION: An unfinished game that could have been so much more if it had been properly developed, or if they had simply used Super Power 2 as a base and improved upon it. A real shame.


```

column8:
I played Superpower 2 for years and I absolutely loved it. However, Superpower 3 is BIG DISAPPOINTMENT! I was expecting a Superpower 2 with up to date data, bugs fixed and maybe a couple of added features, what we got was: 
-More bugs
-Less features
-Less Information
-Slowest game ever
-Nonexistent game play

A LOT of the things you could do or check in the previous one are not there anymore

That is the first review I've ever done on Steam, because I was maybe the biggest fan of Superpower 2 and I was really excited when I saw that we were getting a Superpower 3. But this game is so mediocre compared to the previous one that I couldn't not make a review. It could have been something great, but instead it is maybe the biggest disappointment I've had in video games.

column8: Unequivocally one of the absolute worst games I have ever played. The bugs are numerous and insurmountable, the AI is bad and clearly is only scripted to react rather than to actually play the game like the AI in a normal game, it has online only DRM, and it runs abhorrently on any graphics settings on modern hardware. Rather than rant the reasons this is atrocious I will simply say that the many, many negative reviews are all merited. This game is unfinished and THQ is an absolute disgrace for allowing this game to be released in this state. I would compare the current state of the game to a pre alpha build rather than something worth your time and money. I wanted a refund even sooner but I had to "play" this waste of time for this long to even get the ability to leave a review. Spend your money in anything but this.

column9:
I wasn't surprised by the game's raw, unfinished, and essentially empty nature. I was mentally prepared for this. The studio isn't very large; they'll release the game in Early Access, show off some established mechanics, and we, fans of the series, will appreciate it and wait for further updates. But it's sheer impudence on the developers' part to release a zero-quality game at the price of a stock Hokkaido, for example, without having accomplished a single thing!!!

How could the third game, 17 years removed from the second, manage to underdevelop the military aspect, or even worsen it, because it's just nonsense. Everyone has research, it's developing quickly, the models are incomprehensible, and the combat itself is completely uselessâ€”meaning a strategy game from 2022 has combat from 2004. And on top of that, they've ruined the highlight of the SP2 seriesâ€”nuclear war. How clumsy do you have to be to make a nuclear firefight between powers in a game from the early 2000s look more realistic and exciting than in this one?

Okay, the army, but maybe the economy has changed? Was that dysfunctional economy from the second game fixed? Not really. And in my opinion, not only hasn't it been fixed, it's been simplified and once again operates according to its own unknown rules. Changing sliders and setting taxes was fun in 2004, so couldn't they have developed this aspect? And besides, compared to SP2, there's no Central Bank, no inflation, and far more banal indicators? (Maybe I missed something, of course.) There's nothing more to say about the economy; it's as if it doesn't even exist in the game... although why as if!

Let's return to the game's trump cards, that is, what the developers boasted about so much â€“ demographics and politics. A whole new window has been added over the past 17 years. We were promised that demographics would have a strong influence, but in reality, nothing! There are some numbers and data, but what's the point? They don't convey any important information and don't affect gameplay. You can ban media and regulate freedoms, but who needs that? It doesn't change anything! There are no revolutions or civil wars, so the new window is pointless.

Of course, they managed to destroy the mechanics that people liked in SP and SP2. I'm not talking about trivialities, namely, that even thematic maps have become inconvenient. I don't know how they could screw this up, but they've hit rock bottom here too. Firstly, there are fewer maps, about six, and secondly, they've become less visually understandable.

They were asked throughout development to add major international organizations, like the UN. They added a "Demographics" tab, but there's no such thing as a UN-type organization. I haven't figured out the agreements at all; as far as I understand, there's no NATO here, just allies, not NATO. Diplomacy is also at a standstill; it's never been improved. They managed to make the AI â€‹â€‹even dumber after 17 years. PROGRESS!! (no)

Speaking of politics, you can't even change your party now, but you can create a crappy character. The developers insist that character and demographics are interconnected, so all these mechanics are useless and pointless.

Bottom line: save yourself some money; these developers don't deserve a single penny from you, with such a disregard for players. Maybe great modders will fix this with their painstaking work, but that's unlikely, because I don't even want to touch it! Yes, oddly enough, SP2 is better than SP3 in every way. And it's better to reload your old SP2 save than waste money on this!

column8:
I had about half an hour in-game but I never even got to the game itself. 

Load times are absolutely brutal. The worst I've ever seen. 

Apparently you need to be online in order to play a singleplayer game. Or at least, there was a server window open in the background and when I closed it after several minutes of waiting for the game to start once I picked my options I got kicked out of the game. 

There's no tutorial whatsoever.

SP2 was really good once you got past all the bugs and patched it, but this takes it to the next level. It's totally unplayable.

Now if you don't mind I'm going to read the other negative reviews because I can tell from the score that they're gonna be doozies.

column9:
Did you know that Russia is populated by only three ethnic groups? According to the game, they are Russians, Chechens, and Siberians.

Well, that's one of the game's most insignificant problems. The game's main problem is how it positions itself: it positions itself as a (geo)political simulator. However, there's absolutely nothing political about it, other than beautifully drawn tables. It's more of a wargame, where your goal is to seize as much territory as possible by force.

One might ask, what's missing from the game to be a geopolitical simulator? The answer is simple: pretty much everything. Essentially, it completely lacks any mechanics whatsoever: diplomacy, economics, and domestic policy regulation. Yes, playing as a third-world country, you can forge an alliance with the US or Russia, but there won't be any significant consequences. Just as you can ban abortion in your own country, there won't be any significant consequences. This applies to everything, basically. You can do whatever you want, or rather, whatever the game allows you to do, and it's not a very long list, but there won't be any consequences. And this applies to absolutely every aspect of the game. Let's take this game's main competitor at the moment, Power & Revolution. Yes, it's also very unfinished and has a lot of bugs, BUT it does have some diplomacy mechanics, like the UN and NATO. Joining NATO or declaring war on someone will, one way or another, affect the game landscape, and the consequences of your actions will be immediate. The economy, while not the best and with its quirks, is much more sophisticated, and raising or lowering taxes will significantly impact the state.
The most frustrating thing at the moment is the lack of an answer to the question of what to expect from the game. Will it remain unfinished and simply die? Or is this still early access without the early access tag, and will they add the necessary mechanics? My current answer to this question is this: it will die. I don't think they'll add the necessary mechanics, because that would require essentially creating a new game. But even if I'm wrong, I can confidently say it won't be revived for at least a year, because the amount of work that needs to be done is so enormous.

Technical: I haven't encountered any bugs, but perhaps I didn't realize something wasn't working.

Bottom line: the game isn't finished, there are no consequences for your actions, and I don't recommend buying it as a GEOPOLITICAL simulator.

Well, it's definitely dead.

column9:
It's sad. I thought the reviews were exaggerated, but this release was really rushed, and it shows. There's no depth to the gameplay, the UI is basic, images sometimes fail to load and then reload in what are supposed to be very simple interfaces, and the sliders lag...

To give you an example, I increased my savings budget, and after a month the unemployment rate jumped from 13% to 50%! The explanation is that when you increase the education level, citizens become over-educated, which I understand, but in just one month? Impossible. My country was in recession because of that.

Even for those who prefer the military aspect, I don't see the point of this game... Hopefully, they'll improve with free updates like in New Machines, but in its current state, it's very disappointing.

column8:
sorry but i dont really like the game and that is a real shame since i liked superpower 1 and 2 and really look forward to the new game and was so to speak very positive about it and even watch streamers play.
I would have liked to play more and dig deeper into the game but honestly 
it just feel a bit like a thin cup of tea and i dont want to risk not being able to refund it.
Yes the graphics is nice. Yes you can level up your military gear and so on, but it just feel like superpower 2
with a little better graphics but not really with many new features that i would expect.

Well as a test i play as denmark and declared germany war, and instant norway attack me but germany did nothing.
hmmmm i had expected another response. To be fair i like to say it was a very fast test that took 2 minutes and i did not experience how the game behave  and how your economy changes and diplomacy ect.
I did like the UI interface and how you easy can see what nations like you and such information.
The war that i see was just a box with statistics of how many troops you have and i click it to see more but nothing happen.
Well what i see just a weak slim experience.
I did not yet see the buildings on the map like you do in the videos or my troops in 3d, i just see some small icons on the map and i dont know why, but i could see my armys and move the around and research and make a new tank.. But it just feelt kind of weak somehow.
I dont know if the reason could be that i started a new game before the new patch was released.
During character creation i was not able to choose my own political party so you play as the most populare party ( currently in power ). From a game design point of view this is the easy way to make a game since the largest party give the player a good foundation to start from and if you could choose a less populare party it would be uphill and no gurantee that the player did not loose the next election.
Honestly maybe it would be better to not use real life partys OR at least let everyparty start out equal so the player could choose what he she want and then from there shape their nation. In general politics and religion is always a hard thing in games since the players are different and have different believes and values.

The positive things is the graphics, the big world and the user interface is easy to use.
But it just feel a bit slim and to simple for my liking.
There for i ask for a refund and honestly i dont think i will buy it again not even on sale
i will go play supreme ruler instead.

PS. several of the reviews of this game is wrong.
Yes you can play singleplayer.
Yes you can design units/tanks ect.. you just have to research the units first and after a few times you have researched something it will unlock the ability to assign "skill points" for a new unit.
Yes you can build units BUT they the infantry group i build dissapear once build.
In general i think many reviews was written to fast ( including my own )

column8:
I cannot express just how disappointed and sad I am about this game... I have been playing SuperPower 2 since 2005 and even to this day I consider that game one of the best games ever created (even if it did have a few bugs). So having waited 17 years for SuperPower 3 I had high hopes for this game. However SuperPower 3 is a real, real let down... I dont know where to start... 

1) It looks like a game (if you can call it a game) which was put together in a complete rush with not much time or energy invested into it.
2) The game is extremely boring, there is literally nothing to do. Once you set your budget sliders (which are also awful as they are clunky) theres not much else to do but sit.
3) There is only 1 set game speed and its super slow.
4) You cant even zoom in to the ground as show in their videos, the camera stops zooming in at a certain point.
5) You cant tilt the camera.
6) The military is full of bugs.
7) There are hardly any internal laws you can effect.
There are so many more things I can say but I would be here all night trying to list them...

This game should not have been released in its current state, even if it was an Alpha testing game I would say it would be too soon, never mind actually releasing the game...

I have tried so hard to love this game but I just cant, ITS BORINGGGGG!

The sad thing is, the developers didnt actually need to make drastic changes to SP2, they could have just tweaked it added in a few more features and sorted the bugs out, called it SP3 and I would have loved it. But what they have mashed together here is just awful...
Best thing the developers could do now is close the game, refund eveyone and just go back to SP2 and focus on releasing a DLC or something for that... We dont need better graphics we need better gameplay. SP2 graphics were perfect.

Perhaps the developers will engage more with us fans of SP2 before they make a SP4 in 20 years time...

So disappointed... Moral of the story to anyone reading this is dont waste your money on this game as it currently is. Buy SuperPower 2 instead.

column8:
A game with so much potential in an untapped and woefully under-populated genre... falls.

Really hurts to say, but this is not worth it yet. It has a vast quantity of potential, but it just isn't there; it feels like an early Alpha and nowhere near viable for release.

Maybe in a year or so (yes, I think it will take that long) it will be worth it, but right now in its current state I can't recommend. Such a shame.

Devs: please don't give up. Keep working, - it CAN be a great game eventually, just not yet.

column9:
This is a total piece of crap.

If they spent 18 years making this, then the developer is a total idiot who shouldn't be making games again.

If they made it in a short period of time to suck up money and then pretended it took a long time to make, then they're a total piece of crap developer who's preying on Super Power 2 fans.

The quality is seriously worse than a mobile game, lol.

I thought it was too strong when they released no information, no gameplay videos, and didn't even take pre-orders and rushed to sell it. lol.

Those of you expecting mods, don't get your hopes up. Mods only exist when people play them, but this crappy game doesn't meet that demand, so it can't produce high-quality mods. lol.

This game, like True O Politics 2, should just be relegated to the garbage dump.

column8:
General Impressions: Its a fun little sandbox game that serves its purpose of providing you a world to run a country, it has some bugs, mainly graphical bugs from what iv noticed and does run a little slow at times. If you are expecting this to be a super crazy simulation of modern-day politics then you're not going to get what you want, this is an arcade-style sandbox that has linear and easy-to-learn mechanics. The UI can use some work but there's nothing from my perspective thats game breaking, my only complaint is the price tag, this is at most a 15-20$ game, not a 30$ game. 

My background: I generally play alot of Paradox strategy games, and my only experience in this specific sub-genre is Supreme Ruler and the Democracy franchise. I do not know the intentions of the devs or the promises they made, so I am judging the game purely off of a blind first impression with very little background information on the studio and the series. 

TLDR: Its not worth the price, it has alot of promise, needs some patching, come back in a few months and see what the situation is if you cant stomach bugs

column8:
Extremely buggy and doesn't seem notably different than Superpower 2.

Others mentioned the sliders being an issue. They're very difficult to select, and only pick up about half the time and lag on movement. I had some trouble switching between countries. I encountered two visual glitches during my brief 40 minute game as the UK (probably about 20 minutes of actual gameplay, the rest was loading screens).

The fact that the President's lips don't start moving until a few seconds after when he is talking in the promo video should give you a good idea into the quality of the game. Just play Superpower 2 until this spends some more time in the development oven.

column8:
Short Version: I played hundreds of hours of SP1 and SP2 and have been waiting for this. Given my admittedly limited game time, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game in this state. Avoid it, at least for now. 

Long Version: When the best the positive steam reviews can manage is "it has potential" it should have been a red flag. Almost as much of a red flag as how quickly it went from "coming soon" to "Oct. 7 release." It does have potential but I don't buy games hoping for them to one day be worth playing. 

Some of it is minor bugs like flag textures going missing. Some of it is design decisions like not being able to queue military units to be built or ridiculous taxes on commodities, less than 1% on US energy? For real? 

The simple fact is, the game seems not only rushed but dumbed down from previous versions. It's got a fancy new interface with no guidance on where things are. I cannot imagine how players who haven't played previous versions are even trying to figure out what to do given the only thing resembling a tutorial are 3 Youtube videos linked on the opening splash screen. 

This might pass as an early access, as a full release it's insulting.

[b]ITA[/b]
[list]
    [*]Nessuna presenza di un tutorial o qualunque forma di introduzione alle meccaniche di gioco.
    [*]La personalizzazione del personaggio non ha alcun senso, dato che nemmeno lo vediamo e poi si tratta di un simulatore 
    geopolitico non di The SIms.
    [*]Non Ã¨ possibile scegliere il partito di appartenenza e tanto meno capire cosa fa l'opposizione (se almeno esiste).
    [*]Mappa totalmente miserabile dove a fatica si capisce la differenza tra uno stato e l'altro.
    [*]NESSUNA organizzazione internazionale!!! un simulatore geopolitico dove non esistono ONU, NATO e EU non si puÃ² vedere.
    [*] IA inesistente, o almeno non si capisce se sta facendo o no qualcosa dato che non c'Ã¨ modo di capirlo.
    [*]Scelte di politica interna ridotto all'osso, nell'arco di una settimana puoi passare dall'essere una democrazia ad una dittatura 
        senza che nessuno batta ciglio.
 Gioco totalmente sconsigliato non trattandosi nemmeno di un accesso anticipato, esistono letteralmente giochi per cellulare gratis con meccaniche molto piÃ¹ complesse. 
[/list]
[b]ENG[/b]
[list]
    [*]No tutorial or any kind of introduction to game mechanics.
    [*]Character creation dosn't make any sense as you can't even see him, also this is a geopolitical simulator not The Sims.
    [*]Can't choose starting party and you don't even know what the opposition does (if it even exist).
    [*]NO international organization!!! a geopolitical simulator without ONU,NATO and EU is  unthinkable.
    [*]IA awol, or at least we have no way to see if it's doing something.
    [*]Essentailly no political choices, in a matter of a week you can go from democracy to dictatorship simply by a click.
I absolutely not recommend this game, there are literally mobile games with more complex mechanics that are also free.
[/list]

column8:
Im putting a positive just because ive had contact with one of the devs and he has been very pleasant and reassuring about the game. I will list a few legit issues below to make this a constructive post for the devs to look over.

1. We need an actual treaty system. Nations should not start off in all single alliances. NATO members arent in an organizational treaty, instead they are all in single treaty alliances say as USA you cant leave NATO you HAVE to end treaty with every single nation instead of leaving the organization. They NEED to add or incorporate the treaties system from SP2 so say as china if i wanted to make the shanghai pact i could create a organization treaty and have multiple nations invited and join at once and i could add others, they could try to join, or they could leave at will. 

2. Performance and UI needs slight work it can stutter and be kind of laggy but im sure this is an easy fix the sliders just need slight work as well

3. ICBM system needs work only being able to launch 33 at a time feels like a limitation and also the pathing needs work they should not only go from east to west or west to east they should take the shortest route possible to the target and you should be able to launch from multiple sources at once

4. You should be able to choose your party at start and ban parties as well

5. AI needs some work they can be very passive

6. Certain contested and occupied regions need to be added in northern cyprus, kashmir, a few more 

7. Military information needs a slight rework and maybe add experience for nations like the UK that have small but highly trained militaries 

8. You should be able to see your avatar a lot more in the treaty system maybe have you and your leader standing there like in the civ games

9. If possible add new models for military equipment and tech

EDIT: For the last major recommendations id like to have a speed timer x1 x2 x3 etc, anti ICBM research, and unit type rework, include drones especially since they are essential to modern and near future warfare.

NATO members arent in an organizational treaty, instead they are all in single treaty alliances say as USA you cant leave NATO you HAVE to end treaty with every single nation instead of leaving the organization. They NEED to add or incorporate the treaties system from SP2 so say as china if i wanted to make the shanghai pact i could create a organization treaty and have multiple nations invited and join at once and i could add others, they could try to join, or they could leave at will. 

2. Performance and UI needs slight work it can stutter and be kind of laggy but im sure this is an easy fix the sliders just need slight work as well

3. ICBM system needs work only being able to launch 33 at a time feels like a limitation and also the pathing needs work they should not only go from east to west or west to east they should take the shortest route possible to the target and you should be able to launch from multiple sources at once

4. You should be able to choose your party at start and ban parties as well

5. AI needs some work they can be very passive

6. Certain contested and occupied regions need to be added in northern cyprus, kashmir, a few more 

7. Military information needs a slight rework and maybe add experience for nations like the UK that have small but highly trained militaries 

8. You should be able to see your avatar a lot more in the treaty system maybe have you and your leader standing there like in the civ games

9. If possible add new models for military equipment and tech

EDIT: For the last major recommendations id like to have a speed timer x1 x2 x3 etc, anti ICBM research, and unit type rework, include drones especially since they are essential to modern and near future warfare.

column8:
Well I wouldn't recommend this game normally. I would recommend Superpower 2 (SP2) with HDM Mod +geopolitics or mr mondays etc

but I believe, Golemlabs will make SP3 a good game.

So my Review about this current game is(be aware this is first patch of the game and %90 of games are changing a lot after first release);
Current SP2 with mods is better than this game... I'm no programmer but it shouldn't be that hard to not to remove features from SP2 and make a worse UI than 2004. You made SP2 in 2004, take SP2 as a basic game with his HDM mods etc and add current SP3 features to SP2! Problem is solved! It's a PERFECT game! it would be SP<3!! and I would love it. But lot's of things from SP2 is gone and new features is not enough and last UI is really bad, Original UI in SP2 was way more better and realistic..

column8:
I actually feel mocked by this game. It is easily the worst thing I've disgraced my computer with, and if Gary Glitter were to download this I'm sure he'd say the same.

Almost two decades of my life hoping this would see the light of day.

The character creator has more options that The Sims and is absolutely arbitrary. The vast majority of options make no difference beyond cosmetics - something I can't imagine anyone who would download a political simulator cares much about.

You can literally make homosexuality and cannabis illegal in Holland and nobody seems to mind.

The graphics are a bit overwhelming. I have a decent computer and it managed to slow everything down.

I actually can't be bothered to write much more.

But my analogy would be to the new Lord of the Rings series on Amazon.

Many fans of it were angry. They felt it strayed from the lore. That it was too ideological and "woke". That it didn't resemble Tolkein's style. But at the same time they couldn't argue the storytelling was great, the cinematogrophy was impeccable. It created a conflict because there was a clear effort behind it.

To me, the equivalent of this would be if the new LOTR was just two hours of a Hobbit sat on the toilet. And not having a particularly eventful bowel movement. 

It is probably the worst game I have ever played.

Global Power and Superpower 2 were my childhood.

I feel like the people who made this should spend time in prison.

Except whoever developed the character creator. You should definitely make a Barbie dress up iPhone game for teenage girls.

column8:
Wow...all I can say is complete and utter HOT GARBAGE

Superpowers 2 was one of my all time faves

This is just a complete joke.  My brother and I were amped to play this...nostalgia was hitting hard.  We counted down the hours and bought it the moment it released.

We have no idea what anything does...actions have ZERO consequences...the only notifications I've seen from other countries are things like "sudan is moving politically to the right"....I invaded and annexed Mongolia with zero repercussions or any kind of murmur from the rest of the world.

The combat is a complete joke...you have no idea whats going on...shit glitches all over the place and there's no way to tell what's going on in a battle.

Finally we realized the game was just completely stuck on a day and not moving forward...it wasn't paused.  So I tried to save and backout but the game wouldn't let me save...then it wouldn't let me back out...

wtf?  How can a developer release a game like this?  This has to be some kind of scam...

Never been this disappointed in a title.

column8:
Bueno...

Es un juego en pura alpha.
-No puedes acelerar el tiempo
-PodrÃ­an hacer una mejor interfaz
-No puedes modificar el PIB por sector.  (solo invirtiendo en aquel sector)
-Mal sistema de combate
-Los efectos grÃ¡ficos de las"nukes" al parecer son de una potencia similar a Goku ultra instinto dominado (literal parece que la tierra va a dejar de existir xD)
-Mapa mal texturizado
-Al parecer enero comienza por 0 en vez de 1.
-etc.

En resumen, de momento el juego esta muy verde y va a necesitar tirar de un par de actualizaciones importantes y meses. 
Antes de que sea jugable (espero)
Ahora mismo no lo recomiendo excepto si eres un aficionado haya tu.
column9:
Well...

It's a game in pure alpha.

- You can't speed up time.
- They could make a better interface.
- You can't modify GDP by sector (only by investing in that sector).
- Poor combat system.
- The graphical effects of the "nukes" seem to be similar in power to Goku in mastered Ultra Instinct (it literally looks like the Earth is going to cease to exist xD).
- Poorly textured map.
- Apparently, January starts with 0 instead of 1.

- etc.

In short, the game is very rough around the edges and will need a couple of major updates and months of development before it's playable (hopefully). Right now, I don't recommend it unless you're a hardcore gamer.

column8:
Monatelang darauf gewartet, dem Release-Termin entgegen gefiebert und dann so eine EnttÃ¤uschung! :-(

Man sitzt davor, Ã¤ndert etwas und beobachtet dann, ob und welche Zahlen sich verÃ¤ndern. Man hat das GefÃ¼hl, vÃ¶llig alleine zu sein, keine aktive Interaktion, keine politische Aktionen und vor allem kein Feedback zu den eigenen Aktionen! Was hat meine Ã„nderung bewirkt? Worauf nimmt was in welchem Umfang Einfluss?

Ich habe mal 1.000.000 Dollar in Getreide investiert. Was passiert damit? Was bringt das?
Eritrea leidet Hunger. Ich wollte 10.000.000 Dollar (warum eigentlich nicht Euro?) an Fleisch exportieren - wurde als "nicht benÃ¶tigt" abgelehnt.

Dazu einige Bugs (Dollar statt Euro, Grafiken werden nicht korrekt angezeigt) und Framedrops, wenn ich im Wirtschaftssektor die Schieberegler verÃ¤ndern will. Feinjustierung ist so nicht mÃ¶glich.

Das Spiel kann nicht beschleunigt werden, es gibt nur Pause oder Spiel lÃ¤uft.

Aber mir sind auch ein paar positive Dinge aufgefallen:
- Ãœbersichtliche GUI
- Zusammengefasste Sektoren, kein Mikromanagement
- Umfangreiche Tooltipps zu fast jeder Anzeige
- HÃ¼bsche Grafik der Welt
- Umfangreiche BevÃ¶lkerungsmerkmale (Ethnie, Religion, Eigenschaften von BevÃ¶lkerungsgruppen etc.)
- Mein erstellter Spieler-Charakter hat Einfluss auf die Politik bzw. auf die Wahrnehmung der BevÃ¶lkerung

Dennoch: Zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt leider ein Totalreinfall! FÃ¼r mich ist und bleibt "Power & Revolution" nach wie vor die Branchen-Referenz.

Refund & Deinstall.
column9:
I waited for months, eagerly awaited the release date, and then such a disappointment! :-(

You sit there, make a change, and then watch to see if and which numbers change. You feel completely alone, no active interaction, no political action, and above all, no feedback on your own actions! What effect did my change have? What does it have, and to what extent?

I once invested $1,000,000 in grain. What happens to it? What's the point? Eritrea is starving. I wanted to export $10,000,000 worth of meat (why not euros, actually?) â€“ it was rejected as "not needed."

On top of that, there are some bugs (dollars instead of euros, graphics aren't displayed correctly) and frame drops when I try to adjust the sliders in the economic sector. Fine-tuning is impossible.

The game can't be sped up; it's either pause or it's running.

But I also noticed a few positive things:

- Clear GUI
- Grouped sectors, no micromanagement
- Comprehensive tooltips for almost every display
- Attractive world graphics
- Extensive population characteristics (Ethnicity, religion, characteristics of population groups, etc.)

- My created player character influences politics and public perception.

Nevertheless: At this point, it's a complete flop! For me, "Power & Revolution" remains the industry benchmark.

Refund & Uninstall.

column8: Words are not enough to describe how disappointed I am. It hurt me deeply that a game that I had been waiting for a long time came out like this. It's good that I can get my money back but I wish you could take back my disappointment as well. Can you feel my heart being shattered? Interest rates are gone, all the fun elements of the game have been removed from the game. The old superpower 2 game was much more exciting and better than that. I still play that game, I even played it a bit before it came out today. I hope you realize how much you hurt me.

Very unintuitive and there is little information about what is going to change when you do something. Units take multiple clicks just to issue a single move order, the responsiveness in the UI is lacking. Overall, I think the experience is a let down. It looked really fun in the trailer. Will have to return again in a few months. Hopefully the developers polish the experience vs feeling like another unreal asset dump.

column8: bu ne lan

I'm asking for a refund.

1) Countries strength/equipment/budget is way off. I believe that in 2022 these informations are easily found online and could have made the game way more interesting. 

2) Lacking so many options. I am still trying to find out how to do a multi-country treaty per example. Very hard to upgrade military or tu purchase equipement. after 1 hour still haven't found the options to do it. Only thing I could figure out so far is to toggle the budget up or down. Very far from being intuitive 

3) The player personalisation was a nice feature. However it is impossible making anything but a 50 yo man/woman

4) Graphics (except zoomed-in scenes) is worst than superpower2

5) UI is way too big and you cannot see anything at a glance.

6) My PC runs terribly hot for nothing.

column8:
Super Bummed to have to say this, The game feels really unfinished. 

Very little Features and just feels broken. I only played 32 Mins, Canada doesn't even have proper military units and game play just felt shallow and boring. I really hope this can be salvaged and be re-purchased later if ever fixed. I grinded hours on Super Power 2 well before it was ever on steam and It felt more complete then this. Super Power 2 was actually solid and a great game and should have been expanded on instead.

column9:
No, this is a disaster. My first impression is that my eyes are dazzled by the sheer number of indicators. Is this some kind of Excel simulator?

It all looks like a beta, not a release. The interface is so complex that it's impossible to figure out where or how to move. The combat system is simply awful, the political system is pitch black, the choice of actions is incredibly minimal. The economic systemâ€”you can't figure it out without a case of beer. I don't even understand how the internal political processes work; I just won the election without doing anything, jacking up taxes. The game speed is a bit too slow: 6 years in 2 hoursâ€”well, that's a bit too fast. How to trade properly is completely unclear. The government's income and expenses are also poorly laid out. The world map is a whole other level of mockery...

Oh, and yes, the game's graphics are underwhelming, and the graphics card (3060) heats up to 70-75 degrees (that's the highest I've ever seen in a game). Come on, is it going to outer space or something? It feels like they installed a miner on me, using my own money.

The only interesting positive is the annexation of certain regions during the war; that's a neat touch.

Overall, I'd give it a 3/10, no more. This game's main competitor (I think everyone already knows which one), even with its ton of bugs, is much more interesting and successful.

Absolute crap.

So far, I don't even know if there is some kind of diplomacy.
The economic facet is... mysterious.And crappy.
The military aspect is like your worst nightmare of micromanagement.

Deserve the company to go bankrupt. Period.

UI is confusing and big.

column8: Noooo ho chiesto il rimborso prima di subito, simulatore geopolitico? dove? costruzioni di industrie o altro inesistenti, le uniche azioni permesse sono lo spostamento di qualche parametro, lontano da simulare la politica, il sistema di guerra da riscrivere, sembra un gioco NON FINITO. molto confusionario, lontano anni luce da un HOI4 per esempio. DELUSO.
column9: Noooo, I asked for a refund right away. Geopolitical simulator? Where? Construction of non-existent industries or other things. The only actions allowed are to change some parameters. Far from simulating politics, the war system needs rewriting. It seems like an UNFINISHED game. Very confusing, light years away from a HOI4, for example. DISAPPOINTED.

column8:
I wanted to say: This game doesn't seem to be finished ... but that would be too nice.
It's not even a game, it's a completely useless world map simulator stuck in Alpha. There's no tutorial, there's no interaction with other countries. 
I played with France, attacked Andorra... and the whole world was just like: "Well, okay, you do your thing, France." At least I think that's what they said because I didn't get any reaction at all. 
The menus are just decoration, nothing you change seems to have any consequence.
I really hoped this would be something like a well-made "Power and Revolution", but it's sooo much worse than P&R .
Save your money and DON'T BUY IT!

column8:
Even if they eventually fix all the bugs the problem with the game is that everything that is happening in the world is almost hidden from you - a world war could take place and unless it's nuclear you wouldn't notice. The number 1 issue with SP2 was that there wasn't much to do when you weren't at war and this game makes that feeling of emptiness more prevalent. 

The covert actions menu has delay, the success percentages reset to the low complexity ones despite it keeping whatever you had last there. I couldn't seem to lose diplomatic relations for hundreds of attacks on North Korea. Nor did their approval rating shift in the slightest (even though stability went from over 50% down below 10%). Coup's didn't even work at 84% likelihood when stability was below 10%. If you have multiple coups queued up but fail one they all get depleted.

The nukes are so boring compared to SP2. The DEFCON / Wargames inspired nuke menu was so special and ominous. It's like all personality has been stripped from this game.

The military can't seem to move half the time. If you want to give units to another nation well you have to go through 30 pages of units with only a few items each page and then you'll find your latest purchase doesn't even show up anyway.

This is not acceptable even if it were early access. Do yourself a favour and avoid.

column9:
I can't recommend the game at the moment; I'm refunding my money. I played the second game specifically before the third one came out, and now I'm writing a review, and I'm literally going crazy... What the hell is this I just played? I had some doubts even while watching the trailer, but in reality, it turned out to be even worse:
- Graphics. The downgrade makes the game look like [spoiler]something[/spoiler] for mobile devices. Unironically, the second game with the Our Blue Marble mod looks, and even feels, much better in terms of controls.
- Thematic maps. They had to try to ruin what [b]already existed[/b], and the developers succeeded. A smooth color transition from red to yellow to green or blue to red, depending on the negativity/saturation of the indicator? Now [spoiler]at least the mode showing attitude towards your country[/spoiler] has a very informative transition from [strike]shit[/strike] brown to [strike]piss[/strike] yellow. Not to mention that the map mode is now reset by default by clicking anywhere. Maybe I haven't figured out how to make it stay on after playing for a short time, or maybe it's a [b]feature)[/b]
- P[b]e[/b]rformance is top-notch. Maybe the developers will fix this (I really hope so), but at the moment the game has random lags during gameplay, as well as half-second delays when moving sliders, zooming, clicking, etc. 
- Character creation. F**k, and most importantly - why? Right now, it only looks funny - creating a character in the editor. [spoiler]not[/spoiler] Not to mention that the notorious guy often looks like a character from a 1910s game... Why this is in the game is unclear.
- Nuclear strikes and what they look like. That really does look like a mockery... Well, you had an example of how this could be done, in your own game. In the second game, despite all the simplicity, my jaw dropped at the sight of a nuclear exchange between two or more powers. Hundreds of missiles slowly moving towards their target, the explosions from which slowly covered the entire country. Every city of even the slightest interest got hit, and it looked quite reasonable on a global scale. Now... a limit of 25 missiles per strike? 3D models the size of several stadiums, soaring upward and diving back down? Explosions reminiscent of the Tsar Bomba, making the screen shake for 10 seconds? This clownery reminded me of First Strike, but at least there it was a feature from the start, within the style.
- The interface and overall design are unintuitive. Minimalism and information have been replaced by cartoonishness and excess. Buttons are at the bottom of the screen, occupying a third of the screen; thematic menus (politics, army, etc.) now open full-screen. The detail of the second game, where even small towns and roads are visible? That's not here.
- The inability to speed up or slow down time. Only pause/unpause. I really hope it's fixed.
- Rounding of indicators. If my profit is 2T, is that 2 trillion, 1.5, or 2.49?
- The military system and everything related to it. The same [spoiler]something[/spoiler] as in the second game, only worse. Select units and want to send them somewhere with a mouse click? No way, first move the mouse to the corresponding button and click, and then you'll be able to select an area. The 3D models are absolutely mind-blowing. The second game wasn't exactly a game of variety, but at least it had some realism. A Katyusha, for crying out loud, as rocket artillery? A WWII-era tank as a tank? Someone else in their review also complained about unit production, but I confess I didn't get to that [spoiler]and thank God, I guess[/spoiler]. The incredibly slow technological progress of the second game has been replaced by incredibly fast progress, where in just a couple of years you get a whole new set of unlocked unit technologies.

And that's just the tip of the iceberg, what I noticed in 50 minutes of play...
The developers will undoubtedly fix some of this. There are certainly some positives, such as the steps taken to improve combat [spoiler]at least instead of the single-player brawl from the second game, they've introduced a fight for regions and some semblance of microcontrol[/spoiler]. The new population stats are also encouraging, as is the ability to view your top importers by category. It's nice that there are now more scenarios and you can choose your side in the conflict. There's clearly more that I didn't manage to discover in 50 minutes. Mods will fix some of them. I don't want to condemn the game right away, but at this point, the cons far outweigh the pros, and I can't say anything about it other than "I don't recommend it." Especially for the $25 the developers are asking for it.

column9:
I've been waiting years for this game. I wasn't expecting it to be perfect on launch day, but I was hoping for something decent... at least playable. But it's terrible, literally unplayable. It's far from finished; it's full of bugs. The systems don't work. For example, in my playthrough, I raised taxes to 100%, declared war on the entire world... God, I even committed war crimes across half the globe! All this with the United States, supposedly a democracy... My government's public approval rating? 80% and rising. That's what I mean when I say the systems don't work.
Don't be fooled by the photos and videos; they look great. On launch day, it's literally a rip-off. I don't know who thought releasing this in its current state was even worthy of being called a video game. What a huge disappointment.

column8:
Great idea, stupid game.

I thought the studio learn something from Paradox's stupid works and Geopolitical Simulator 4...Unfortunately, the game even do not show the charm of SuperPower 2 so far.
I am not sure how much players counted down to SuperPower 3's debut, at least I did. Then problems followed: Why I can't have drop-down list? Why I can't control the speed? Why I found rare demography elements in the game? Why there are no random events for choose, technology tree?
I will not ask for refund, I suppose you spent times, and you are not as lazy as Paradox. Still, I can not totally accept the work worse than Realpolitiks2 (actually it is a good game).
It's 4 a.m., I can not believe what a terrible game I just played yet. You ruined it firstly, but never again please!

I noticed mentioned Victoria 3. If the latter sucks too, I will feel like 2022 is the worst year I experience ever.
PLEASE FIX IT AT ONCE.
I was preparing for license exam, you destroyed it for giving me unrealistic expectations.
I am here to recapture her lost youth with the game, but find I am a useless guy in the 30s.

Well, someone asked me why I mentioned notorious Paradox here.
Firstly, because their major games are basically colouring games. Yes, you coloured the world map with your owned colour, simple but cool. At least I did it when I was playing SuperPower 2. But I suspect if I can have such fun in SP3. So setting a hollow victory goals is really important for the players.
In the second place, Paradox's games did debut with several bugs, but these bugs are tolerant, only if the hollow victory goals exist. Why Gandhi's nukes rather than game itself became a joke among CIV players? Think twice.
Last, some games (including SuperPower 2) changed players' appetite, If you can not cater for picky players, then curses come.

How the developers matter the avatars, but turn a blind eye to players' main need? Gosh, why I do not play the Sims instead? I beg your reconsideration. Wish your repair could make the game great again.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I can not help to try again since the first fix released, then my happiness paused to find I can not restart the game within 3 min.

I am here to recapture her lost youth with the game, but find I am a useless guy in the 30s.

Well, someone asked me why I mentioned notorious Paradox here.
Firstly, because their major games are basically colouring games. Yes, you coloured the world map with your owned colour, simple but cool. At least I did it when I was playing SuperPower 2. But I suspect if I can have such fun in SP3. So setting a hollow victory goals is really important for the players.
In the second place, Paradox's games did debut with several bugs, but these bugs are tolerant, only if the hollow victory goals exist. Why Gandhi's nukes rather than game itself became a joke among CIV players? Think twice.
Last, some games (including SuperPower 2) changed players' appetite, If you can not cater for picky players, then curses come.

How the developers matter the avatars, but turn a blind eye to players' main need? Gosh, why I do not play the Sims instead? I beg your reconsideration. Wish your repair could make the game great again.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I can not help to try again since the first fix released, then my happiness paused to find I can not restart the game within 3 min.

column8: Its clear from the get-go that this game wasn't ready for launch. As much as I want to like this game (I've been desperate for a game like this for a while), I cannot recommend anyone buy this at this time. Maybe when (or if) the game gets patched into a properly complete form, then I could say its worth the money.

column8:
Usually I am a "quiet buyer", if I buy and like a game - I don't write about it, if I buy and don't like a game - I don't write about it. But this game forced me to write my first ever review as I cannot stay quiet after investing 26,99 â‚¬ for an absolutely broken software...I really cannot even call it a game at the moment. It seems unfinished, or it is just scam, because it is not what the trailers show. It is incredibely full of bugs and glitches which you encounter all the time as if nobody ever tried to test it before release, there are even problems with simple functions like clicking on a country. I have waited for this game a long time but unfortunately I can only confirm all the other negative reviews.

If it wouldn't be enough there is also a lack of knowledge about some countries. Slovakia does not speak Slovenian, it speaks Slovak, when you create a character in Slovakia you cannot even choose Slovak, for Slovakia it chooses Slovenian... If you bring out a geopolitical game you should at least know the differences between countries that sound similar for you. 

Dear developers, please change my mind about this game, because at the moment it's absolutely unplayable and not worth the download even if it would be freeware.

Update 04.03.2023:
After 5 months there are no real fixes, so this game is a scam! GolemLabs and THQ Nordiq took my money for a broken software.

column8:
Edit: Looks like the game is being updated, but there doesn't even seem to be an apology, just the "Game is released" and then "Patch Notes" articles. The fact that there was a bunch of talk before release, hyping up the game, and then once it releases in a broken state, not even an apology?! Awful.

Build #27642

This is a release that absolutely needs an immediate PR note from either developer or publisher - this is an absolute joke that the game has released in this state. Someone on that team needs to explain how and why the game is in the state that it's in.

Here I was, thinking this was supposed to be a great competitor to the Power and Revolution series, turns out, it's even worse than that. How did absolutely no one even remotely double check the game version that was supposed to release?! If this IS the version that was supposed to release, then that's just a massive disappointment and shouldn't be on Steam, or even near $30 USD at all.

- Got stuck on the splash screen when starting the game.
- Main menu didn't even load properly the first time.
- No fancy cutscenes as shown off in the GIFs on the Steam page - which is really misleading.
- Creating a character feels pointless when you don't see them in any cutscenes - if those even exist.
- No tutorial? Seriously?
- AI countries don't do anything until you do something (eg. nuke them, and they nuke back instantly)
- Combat is confusing to figure out (see also, no tutorial)
- Can't target specific cities if you want to attack them, nukes just go across the whole country
- There's no message system compared to P&R, just... full screen messages, and nothing else
- I did the absolute opposite of the USA starting states (made everything illegal, locked down the internet, etc.) and yet my approval was somehow 55% - after nuking Russia it was 84%??? It's like anything you do to your own country just doesn't matter at all. No riots because of your decisions, no tensions, nothing.
- Can't even zoom into the city areas, so if there's another button instead of just... zooming in all the way, then what's the point?

Game overall feels very lackluster and leaves a LOT to be desired. Very embarrassing that the effort of Power and Revolution couldn't even be matched, and that game series has been copy-paste for the past few years.
