column8:
Neubewertung nach 30h Spielzeit.

Ich weiÃŸ ehrlich gesagt nicht wo ich anfangen soll. Es ist noch schlimmer als ich zu Beginn dachte.
Das Wichtigste vorweg: Ich kann nicht mehr ruhig schlafen in dem Wissen das Spiel empfohlen zu haben, also ziehe ich die Empfehlung zumindest bis da ordentlich nachgebessert wurde zurÃ¼ck. (Immerhin gabs schon mal nen kleinen Patch - nicht das es was geholfen hÃ¤tte - aber scheinbar wird noch was dran geschraubt.)

Fangen wir mit dem Interface an:
Ich empfinde die Fenster als zu groÃŸ. Das ganze wirkt unÃ¼bersichtlich und man verliert den Blick auf die strategische Karte. Es kommt mir vor, als wÃ¤re das Spiel fÃ¼r ein Tablett entwickelt worden. Grausam. Der VorgÃ¤nger hatte kleine Fenster, die man rumschieben konnte und die man auch wÃ¤hrend Kampfhandlungen offen lassen konnte. Die Infos waren auf einen Blick sichtbar und fertig. Ja, man kann das Fenster einklappen, aber dann ist das Fenster quasi weg und nur der Rahmen bleibt zu sehen. Man kann nicht mehrere Fenster gleichzeitig geÃ¶ffnet lassen. Das stÃ¶rt mich ungemein.

Forschung und Einheitendesign:
Ich erwÃ¤hne das zusammen, da man in diesem Teil der Reihe keine Einheitendesigns wÃ¤hlen kann. Im Laufe des Spiels ist mir aufgefallen, dass das Design einer Einheit sich mit dem Fortschritt der Forschung automatisch Ã¤ndert. Das nervt mich! Ich will selber bestimmen, wie eine Einheit aussieht, unabhÃ¤ngig von Ihren Kampfwerten. 
In diesem Zusammenhang muss auch das Fehlen der Spielbeschleunigung erwÃ¤hnt werden. Liebe Entwickler, ich weiÃŸ was ihr damit erreichen wollt. Wir sollen mÃ¶glichst lange beschÃ¤ftigt werden, indem wir auf sich fÃ¼llende Balken starren. Aber a) macht das keinen Spass und b) hab ich das Umgangen. Ich wÃ¤hle Irland, mache BÃ¼ndnisse mit 4 oder 5 groÃŸen LÃ¤ndern, stelle mich gut mit der USA und kaufe von denen sÃ¤mtliche Forschung (ja ich hÃ¤tte auch die USA nehmen kÃ¶nnen, aber dann hÃ¤tte ich die Entwicklung nicht beobachten kÃ¶nnen). Nach EWIGEM Geklicke (man kann nÃ¤mlich immer nur ein einziges Forschungsdingens einzeln Handeln - fÃ¼r alle Waffengattungen und bis man auf dem Stand der USA ist vergeht ne Weile), sieht man wie sich die Designs Ã¤ndern. Irgendwie macht das noch weniger Spass, als darauf zu warten, bis sich der Balken fÃ¼llt. 
Ach und wenn wir schon dabei sind: Obwohl ein ZerstÃ¶rer ein "Ã¶" im Wort hat und das auch angezeigt wird, wird es durch "??" ersetzt, wenn ich die Einheit KÃ¶ln-Klasse nenne... echt merkwÃ¼rdig.

Warum kann ich eigentlich nur einen Bauauftrag fÃ¼r eine Einheit einstellen? Warum keine Bauschleife? Ich habe mir mal den Spass gegÃ¶nnt und 50 sehr fortschrittliche Zerst??rer gebaut und dabei mal auf die Uhr geschaut. Grob zweieinhalb realtime Stunden hat das gedauert. 2,5h in denen ich mir einen Balken angeschaut habe, der sich langsam fÃ¼llt. WÃ¤hrend der Zeit passiert, wenn man nicht gerade iwo Krieg fÃ¼hrt und damit beschÃ¤ftigt ist die Einheiten zu steuern (dazu gleich mehr) nichts! Was zur HÃ¶lle soll das?

Einheitenbewegung:
UnprÃ¤zise, unÃ¼bersichtlich, langsam und kontraintuitiv. FÃ¼r ein Tablett auf dem ich mit meinem fetten Finger irgendwo auf der Map hintatsche mag das reichen aber mit einer Maus? Die Reaktion der Einheiten nimmt mit steigender Forschung zu aber trotzdem ist das eine Frechheit, wie die Einheiten sich steuern lassen. Teilweise bleiben auch Artefakte der Pfade sichtbar bis man neugeladen hat. Zusammenlegen von Einheiten ist richtig schlimm. Da tut sich minutenlang gar nichts und man denkt der Befehl kam gar nicht durch und man beginnt schon an der Funktion der Maus zu zweifeln.

Richtig witzig wird es wenn man ein Land annektieren will. Liebe Entwickler. wenn die gesamten militÃ¤rischen Einheiten eines Landes vernichtet wurden und meine nicht, habe ich die militÃ¤rische Kontrolle Ã¼ber das Land und nicht nur Ã¼ber die Region in der meine Einheiten stehen. Wenn man das schon so doof machen muss, dann doch bitte mit der MÃ¶glichkeit mit Rechtsklick auf meine Einheit und "Gebiet besetzten" drÃ¼cken (wie bei SP2) anstatt das ich nun jedes Gebiet einzeln manuell besetzen muss (bei der eben erwÃ¤hnten suboptimalen Steuerung ist das richtig spaÃŸig) bevor ich die Annexion starten kann.

Politik oder so Ã¤hnlich:
Das Schiebereglerproblem wurde nun schon in etlichen Bewertungen erwÃ¤hnt, also versuchen wir mal etwas mit mehr Tiefgang. Leider kann man Ã¼ber oberflÃ¤chliche Dinge nichts tiefgreifendes erzÃ¤hlen. Auswirkungen von Einstellungen oder Geldinvestitionen (btw immer in Dollar egal welches Land) sind zumindest fÃ¼r mich nicht ersichtlich. Ich habe keinen Plan was da passiert und trotz vieler Tooltipps habe ich keine Ahnung was ich da mache und ob das wirklich was gebracht hat oder noch bringen wird oder nicht.

Ich habe mal Kuba annektiert und seit dem stieg meine Arbeitslosigkeit auf 100%, ergo keine Einnahmen mehr und nachdem ich Stunden benÃ¶tigt habe die Schulden meines Landes abzubauen (weil auch wenn man das Geld hÃ¤tte, kann man die Schulden nicht sofort tilgen sondern muss warten bis die sich nach und nach abbezahlt haben) mache ich wieder Schulden ohne Ende. Ich habe Null Ahnung, wie ich das auffangen soll. Auch Investitionen im 11-stelligen Bereich in die einzelnen Zweige scheinen nichts zu bringen oder man sieht es einfach nur nicht. Keine Ahnung was da los ist.

Warum bekomme ich eigentlich von meinen VerbÃ¼ndeten ca. alle 2 Minuten ein Handelsangebot, bei dem ich ohne Gegenleistung meinen gesamten Barbestand an die Ã¼berweisen soll? Das nervt halt richtig. Super gut wirds wenn man das Spiel neulÃ¤dt. Da hab ich dann etwa 30 solcher Anfragen. Mehrere von jedem meiner VerbÃ¼ndeten. Ganz toll!

Kampfsystem: 
Kein Plan welche Einheit da gegen welche Einheiten kÃ¤mpft, geschweige denn welche zusammenarbeiten und sich eventuell gegenseitig stÃ¤rken, nicht sicher wer, wann, wieviel Schaden macht und warum das Ganze in einem quadratischen Bereich stattfindet, welcher Gebietsgrenzen komplett ignoriert, sodass man teilweise LÃ¤nder in den Konflikt reinzieht, die man eigentlich nicht reinziehen wollte, ist mir vÃ¶llig schleierhaft. Kampfsystem unter aller Sau. Da sind mir die kleinen WÃ¶lkchen und diese lustig animierte EinheitengegenÃ¼berstellung aus SP2 lieber.

Ãœbrigens klingt meine Graka (RTX 3080) bei dem Game wie ein Triebwerk im Nachbrenner. Warum? Da passiert schliesslich gar nichts. Keine Einheitenbewegungen seitens anderer LÃ¤nder, miese AuflÃ¶sung und wenig Details. Trotzdem klingt meine GraKa als hÃ¤tte ich vier mal Elden Ring auf Ultra offen. wtf!

Ganz ehrlich: Ich hab nu nicht alles erwÃ¤hnt, was mir komisch vorkam oder mich genervt hat, aber das Spiel hat trotz all dem viel Potenzial. Es gibt viele gute Elemente (Charakter erstellen, was Auswirkungen auf die Beliebtheit hat z.B.) die ich aus PlatzgrÃ¼nden nicht alle erwÃ¤hnen kann. Wenn da ordentlich nachgebessert wird, kann das noch ein guter dritter Teil der Reihe werden. Im aktuellen Zustand ist das eher ein Early Access. Lasst die Pfoten davon, bis das fertig wird.

PS. Habe die ersten 3 Teile der Bewertung (nach 2h, 3h und 6h Spielzeit) aus PlatzgrÃ¼nden cutten mÃ¼ssen. Sorry dafÃ¼r.

Nachtrag zum Nachtrag: Es gibt ein Game Manual! 

https://superpower.fandom.com/wiki/Game_Manual_SP3

Nicht das ich wirklich scharf drauf wÃ¤re das zu lesen, aber da echt viele Fragen offen sind, werd ich das wohl machen...

Bye
column9:
Re-evaluation after 30 hours of gameplay.

Honestly, I don't know where to begin. It's even worse than I initially thought.

First things first: I can no longer sleep soundly knowing I recommended this game, so I'm withdrawing my recommendation at least until it's significantly improved. (There was a small patch, at leastâ€”not that it helped muchâ€”but it seems they're still working on it.)

Let's start with the interface:

I find the windows too large. The whole thing feels cluttered, and you lose sight of the strategic map. It seems like the game was designed for a tablet. Awful. The predecessor had small windows that you could move around and leave open even during combat. The information was visible at a glance, and that was it. Yes, you can collapse the window, but then the window is practically gone, and only the frame remains visible. You can't have multiple windows open at the same time. This bothers me immensely.

Research and Unit Design:

I'm mentioning this together because you can't choose unit designs in this installment of the series. During the game, I noticed that a unit's design changes automatically as research progresses. This annoys me! I want to decide what a unit looks like myself, regardless of its combat stats.

In this context, the lack of game acceleration also needs to be mentioned. Dear developers, I know what you're trying to achieve. You want to keep us occupied as long as possible by having us stare at filling bars. But a) it's no fun, and b) I've found a workaround. I choose Ireland, form alliances with four or five major powers, cultivate good relations with the USA, and buy all their research (yes, I could have chosen the USA, but then I wouldn't have been able to observe the progress). After endless clicking (you can only trade one research item at a time â€“ for all weapon types, and it takes a while to catch up with the USA), you can see the designs change. Somehow, this is even less fun than waiting for the progress bar to fill up.

Oh, and while we're on the subject: Even though a destroyer has an "Ã¶" in its name, and that's displayed, it's replaced with "?" when I name the unit Cologne-class... really strange.

Why can I only set one construction order for a unit? Why isn't there a build loop? I decided to have some fun and built 50 very advanced destroyers and timed it. It took roughly two and a half real-time hours. Two and a half hours of watching a progress bar slowly fill up. During that time, unless you're actively fighting a war and busy controlling your units (more on that later), nothing happens! What the hell is going on?

Unit movement: Imprecise, confusing, slow, and counterintuitive. For a tablet where I'm just tapping around on the map with my fat finger, this might be sufficient, but with a mouse? The units' responsiveness improves with increasing research, but even so, the way they're controlled is an outrage. Sometimes, artifacts from the paths remain visible until you reload. Merging units is truly awful. Nothing happens for minutes, and you think the command never even registered, and you start to doubt the mouse's functionality.

It gets really ridiculous when you want to annex a country. Dear developers, if all of a country's military units have been destroyed, but mine haven't, then I have military control over the entire country, not just the region where my units are located. If you have to make it this stupid, then please include the option to right-click on my unit and select "Occupy Territory" (like in SP2), instead of having to manually occupy each territory individually (which is truly fun with the aforementioned suboptimal controls) before I can even begin the annexation.


Politics or something like that:

The slider issue has already been mentioned in numerous reviews, so let's try something with a bit more depth. Unfortunately, you can't really say anything profound about superficial things. The effects of settings or investments (always in dollars, regardless of the country) are, at least to me, invisible. I have no idea what's going on, and despite numerous tooltips, I have no clue what I'm doing or whether it's actually made any difference or will make any difference at all.

I once annexed Cuba, and since then, my unemployment has skyrocketed to 100%, meaning no income. After spending hours paying off my country's debt (because even if you had the money, you couldn't just pay off the debt immediately; you have to wait until it's gradually paid off), I'm racking up debt again without end. I have absolutely no idea how to cope. Even investments in the eleven-figure range in various sectors don't seem to be making any difference, or maybe I just can't see them. I have no idea what's going on.


I've spent hours trying to reduce my country's debt (because even if you had the money, you couldn't pay off the debt immediately; you have to wait until it's gradually paid off), and now I'm racking up debt again like crazy. I have no idea how to deal with this. Even investments in the eleven-figure range in various sectors don't seem to be having any effect, or maybe I just can't see them. I have no idea what's happening.
... Why do I get trade offers from my allies about every two minutes, asking me to transfer my entire cash balance to them for nothing? It's incredibly annoying. It gets even worse when I reload the game. Then I get about 30 of these requests. Several from each of my allies. Fantastic!

Combat system:

I have no idea which units are fighting which other units, let alone which ones are cooperating and potentially strengthening each other. I'm not sure who does how much damage, when, or why the whole thing takes place in a square area that completely ignores territorial boundaries, sometimes dragging countries into the conflict that I didn't intend to involve. It's all a complete mystery to me. The combat system is absolutely terrible. I much prefer the little clouds and the amusingly animated unit comparisons from SP2.

By the way, my graphics card (RTX 3080) sounds like a jet engine in afterburner while playing this game. Why? Because nothing's actually happening. No unit movement from other countries, terrible resolution, and a lack of detail. Despite all that, my graphics card sounds like I'm running Elden Ring four times on Ultra settings. WTF!

Honestly, I haven't mentioned everything that struck me as odd or annoying, but despite all that, the game has a lot of potential. There are many good elements (character creation, which affects popularity, for example) that I can't all mention due to space constraints. If they significantly improve these aspects, it could still become a good third installment in the series. In its current state, it's more like an Early Access title. Leave it alone until it's finished.

P.S. I had to cut the first three parts of the review (after 2, 3, and 6 hours of playtime) due to space limitations. Sorry about that.

Addendum to the addendum: There's a game manual!


https://superpower.fandom.com/wiki/Game_Manual_SP3

Not that I'm particularly keen on reading it, but since there are so many unanswered questions, I guess I'll do it...

Bye

column9: I've already played for a few hours, and I've identified some minor bugs that can be fixed over time! I must agree that the game looks beautiful, I loved the graphics quality, and the combat mechanics are very good in my opinion! But I was disappointed in one aspect: where is the Portuguese interface? Okay, I'm lucky to know a little Spanish, but let's face it, playing a game in your native language is much better! I sincerely hope that GolemLabs will pay some attention to the Brazilian community, because like me, there are many fans of the SuperPower franchise.

column8:
What is the point of positive balance if you're going to hemorrhage money in a ghostly fashion. Makes zero sense.

Income per year as Peru  + $3 Billion
Yet losing money the entire calendar year. Totally makes sense.


While the game seems to be on the verge of fun, it just feels everything went wrong from a behind-the-scenes logic.

Also, how the eff is America not selling weapon systems?! That's the most non-American thing I've ever seen in a game.

0/10 would not see weapon systems for purchase from the worlds largest arms dealer.

*EDIT* Spelling is hard.

column8:
EDIT: to hell with waiting  for two weeks, they don't deserve it. Refund requested.

Bought the game immediately upon release notification. 

Well... nothing is working in this game. I just set a refund reminder before two weeks would pass; that is how unplayable, unfinished and disappointing a mess this is. Dear devs, either let us know *exactly* what improvements, patches, corrections, etc. you are planning to release within the next two weeks to make the game playable otherwise I (and I do not believe only I!) will ask for a refund and won't ever bother even looking up where the "game" is headed in the future.

Having waited for this game for quite a while, I feel worse than disappointed.

column9:
Don't even think about buying it now.
The game is incredibly rough; it feels like they started working on it right after it was announced, and they did it half-assed.
The interface is crap for a mobile phone;
The music is completely unsuitable;
The economy is complete garbage;
The politics are so bad I can't even choose a ruling party at the beginning;
The graphics are cartoonish, completely unsuitable, in my opinion.
Wars - WHAT IS THAT? HAVE YOU EVEN PLAYED THIS?
Optimization - There's none...
They've cut everything. They've ruined everything...

I was expecting only that they would polish and improve SuperPower 2, but in the end, not only did they unfinish the game, they also cut everything that was in SuperPower 2. And I remind you that the game was released in 2004 and had a clear interface, pleasant music, and even the war was much more interesting than in SP3.

After playing SuperPower 3 for an hour, I became disillusioned. As I played, I became increasingly tempted to play SuperPower 2.

You had the foundation of SuperPower 2, why not just take it and polish it instead of reinventing the wheel, as happened...

DON'T EVEN THINK OF BUYING IT UNTIL THEY FIX THE GAME. IT'S EVEN WORSE THAN THE CYBERBUG!

I'm issuing a refund...

column8:
Hello SP3 developers,

We are writing to you to ask that you please fix our game. We have been playing it for a while and it is really fun, but there are some issues that need to be fixed.

First of all, the game keeps crashing. We have tried everything to fix it, but it still happens. It is really frustrating and we hope you can fix it soon.

Secondly, the graphics are not the best. They are not terrible, but they could be better. We would love to see some updated graphics in the game.

Lastly, the controls are a bit wonky. They work, but they are not as responsive as we would like. We hope you can fix this so that we can enjoy the game even more.

Additionally, we feel that the character creation feature is unnecessary in this game. It takes up time and adds nothing to the gameplay experience. It would be great if this feature could be removed or streamlined.

Thank you for your time and we hope you can fix these issues soon. We really enjoy playing your game and we appreciate your hard work.
column9:
Hello SP3 developers,

We are writing to you to ask that you please fix our game. We have been playing it for a while and it is really fun, but there are some issues that need to be fixed.

First of all, the game keeps crashing. We have tried everything to fix it, but it still happens. It is really frustrating and we hope you can fix it soon.

Secondly, the graphics are not the best. They are not terrible, but they could be better. We would love to see some updated graphics in the game.

Lastly, the controls are a bit wonky. They work, but they are not as responsive as we would like. We hope you can fix this so that we can enjoy the game even more.

Additionally, we feel that the character creation feature is unnecessary in this game. It takes up time and adds nothing to the gameplay experience. It would be great if this feature could be removed or streamlined.

Thank you for your time and we hope you can fix these issues soon. We really enjoy playing your game and we appreciate your hard work.

column8: SP2'nin yanÄ±na yaklaÅŸamaz bile resmen osurttu negatifi basÄ±yorum osuruk pawa

The UI is absolutely awful, big and giant and is significantly less information than the previous games. The speed in which the game moves is so slow, in single player and especially in multiplayer. Frankly the Dev's know this just as much as I do, this is an early access product pretending to be a full release.

Super Power 2 is a significantly better product released in 2004.

I am requesting a refund luckily under my 2 hours.

Dev's if you want me to try this again in the future you need to not make this game for casuals, SP1 and SP2 were quite niche geopolitical simulators that had a very high learning curve which might push away your casual crowd but they are not showing up at release to buy your game. Turning SP3 into what looks like a mobile game is not your best call

Waited years for this to release and all I can say is my disappointment is immeasurable and my day is ruined.... 0_0

column8: Ã‡Ã–P KELÄ°MESÄ°NÄ°N ANLAMI BU OYUN.... REZÄ°LLÄ°K

First and Foremost if you want to see some REAL gameplay and take a legitimate look at this game then check out the review I put up on my YouTube channel (link below).

But this game is pretty bad. I know that a bunch of other people already gave this a bunch of awful reviews and that's because the game deserves it. This is my first entry into the SuperPower games and it was not a good one.

The game is broken in so many ways it's hard to list them all. It's missing in so much content that it feels empty or super Early Access.

Scroll up real quick, look at the advertisements for the game? See those? Don't they look cool? They're not in the game at all, and the game is NOTHING like the advertisements. It's basically like a boardgame without turns. Half the time your commands don't work, half the time nothing you do matters at all. I conquered Mexico and no one in the world cared. IT was a pointless, nonsensical invasion with no real reason and my approval rating actually went up by 3 percent and the rest of the world didn't notice or care.

The game wouldn't let me use nukes. When I scrolled in I only got a vague shadow picture of my troops and couldn't see cities at all. Apart from the cutscenes there are no sound effects and no other voice acting. The only thing you get is simple background music. THe game doesn't let you choose which political party you belong to. The game doesn't let you make a lot of choices and even then you're choices seemingly don't matter to anything. I was able to get america out of debt, increase my approval rating, and  completely take over another country and there were ZERO consequences for any of my reckless actions to get us that far. And...it only took a couple of clicks to completely improve my country in every way possible.

The game is missing so much, and it's so buggy that it's more annoying than fun to play. Pass on this one. Either pass on it completely, or come back in a year or two after some serious updates. If you're new to the series then just run away as fast as you can. This super complicated confusing game offers no tutorials and no teaching to help you learn how to play.
If you're a fan of this title, come back in a year when it has more content and less bugs. Okay everyone?

Thanks so much for reading and I hope I helped some of you out there to spend your money wisely.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Opfc1C80rxw

Are you kidding me ? 
What is this supposed to be. Unplayable, unclear. Sliders don't work. Game runs like I had a 90's PC (spoiler : I don't). There is no explanation of anything. No diplomatic possibilities. No political possibilities. 

It is a HUGE deception. But it was obviously going to be a disaster given the absence of gameplay content before launch. 
Refund asked. 
DO NOT SPEND ANY MONEY ON THIS "GAME".

Absolutely terrible.
We were sold a game that has absolutely no redeeming qualities, graphically speaking (it looks like something from another era of video games).
The management system is completely incoherent, and the displays are truly antiquated.
A major, and I mean major, update could (and I mean COULD) save the game, but it would require starting from scratch.
Right now... RUN AWAY

column9:
I hope there's an update to improve the game. The graphics are quite ugly, the war gameplay is very bad, the economy is somewhat difficult to manage, and the economic indicators in the game are practically useless. I set the military investment to 200% and nothing changed. I really hope it improves because R$50.00 is a lot of money.

Note: As it is, GPS4, even with its countless bugs, seems like a dream.

Edit: I requested a refund. I prefer to wait for another, more promising game than to waste 50 reais on something as weak as this.

column9:
I was a fan of SP1 and SP2, but this game seems to have been botched.

Unlike SP2, you can't speed up or slow down time. There are fewer simulation features overall compared to SP2, for example, regarding taxation, treaties, espionage, language laws, religion, etc. The user interface is inefficient and looks like a clunky Android app running on a 2K screen.

On the plus side, you can control your character's beard length, nose size down to the millimeter, and skin color with 48 different shades.

Plus, this thing really pushes my RTX card to its limits, even though nothing particularly impressive is actually displayed on the screen.

I'll see after the patches, but it seems like a failure for a game that was supposed to be the successor to SP2.

column8:
Superpower 2 was an extremely fun game to play, with the community and in-general, it was a game to enjoy and sit back to relax. While the developers of that time (2003 - 04) are not longer with us in working towards the new SuperPower, I can't get the feeling of having that same level of game-play in SuperPower 3.

1. For starters, the game has stabilization issues on some windows PC's. Crashing and freezes during load-up is common, and unfortunate. It's hard to get into the game without having issues as mentioned above.

2. The game-play is really slow, like reaallly slow, and the absence of fast-forwarding time makes SP3 really boring right at the beginning, it's hard to get into tense moments without having to get up from your chair, or do something else while you wait. The fact that SP2 has a fast-forwarding option, while SP3 doesn't is confusing and frustrating.

3. Having a R7 5800x, and RX 6650 XT, theres no reason for SP3 to having FPS issues, the game will occasionally stutter from troop build-up on multiplayer, or battles that are near by, and the budget bar for whatever reason is unresponsive during multiplayer, performance is lacking.

4. The AI behaves very strangely in SP3, I don't know if its because of Server lag, but conquering or nuking nations you'll expect the AI to behave accordingly, but it doesn't, and thats the issue, the AI doesn't respond to these scenarios. The AI needs serious improvements, and is, in my option, the core of the game-play.

Overall, I'm left disappointed, having waited for a very long time until it's release, SP3 doesn't offer on what it was promised, and the feedback the fans gave to developers (Discord) felt ignored. I don't know if SP3 will continued to be worked on or if the developers will try to fix the game, but at the current state, the game is a disappointing mess.

Sadly it's just SP2 but with less content and more bugs. No tutorial, military seems clunky and complicated. Tried to buy some destroyers from the USA, offered a billion, they didn't like it. It's just bad on the whole, in a lot of ways.

Not angry, disappointed.

column9:
I wouldn't recommend it at least for now; it's completely different from the second generation.

The UI is both simple and complex. The main menu options are hidden in the upper right corner, which is very unfriendly to new players.

The character creation system is rather useless. The only useful aspect is that the character's language and beliefs affect the game's difficulty. The female character creation interface seems unfinished; the hairstyle and clothing previews are copied from male characters, so you have to try them one by one, which is very inconvenient!

The game loads slowly; it took about 5 minutes to get into the game. This might be because I was using the highest graphics settings, but even those aren't very high quality. Zooming in and out to a specific point results in noticeable lag.

The game time is only paused and resumed; a day in the game is about 5 seconds.

There's no tutorial like in the second generation. Even as a veteran player, I was a bit confused. I know there are official videos, but they can't replace a direct tutorial.

Viewing map categories is also inconvenient. Previously, right-clicking was easy, but now you have to go to the lower right corner, where a dense UI makes it easy to click the wrong thing. The legends are also quite decorative. For example, when viewing the map of national relations, the legends are all yellow, ranging from light to darker shades. Distinguishing between colors would be a nightmare for art students. Some relationship values â€‹â€‹from the second game are also missing. Playing one game, I think I'll become colorblind. Most other legends have the same problem (only the nuclear power map is clear and intuitive, for reasons everyone understands...). The various panels have very few new additions. Compared to the second game, there's internet control, media control, establishing embassies, choosing importing countries, airports, and primary and secondary industries. However! Many more things have been removed from each panel: laws, religion, language, capital city, political system, interest rates, trade, import/export controls, etc., halving the replayability.

These are my findings after 40 minutes of gameplay; there may be omissions. In short, it's very awkward to play. If I weren't a veteran of the second game, I would definitely request a refund. Waiting for the next update.

column8:
[b]Falling Far Short of Expectations[/b]

Rating: â˜…â˜†â˜†â˜†â˜†

Superpower 3, the latest offering from GolemLabs, sadly fails to rise above the disappointingly low expectations set by the developer's previous track record. Despite being the successor to a series with some potential, this game stumbles and falls, unable to reach the basic threshold of what constitutes an engaging gameplay experience.

The game feels woefully incomplete, more reminiscent of a student project or a pre-alpha build rather than a fully-fledged game ready for commercial release. It's like the skeleton of a game, with bare-bones mechanics and an unfortunate lack of fleshed-out content. The gameplay, or rather the lack of it, is startling, leaving players navigating through an empty shell that promises much but delivers little.

In retrospect, the absence of gameplay showcases in their promotional material makes more sense. There's simply not enough substance to the gameplay mechanics to create engaging and exciting moments for the players. What is presented is so minimalistic and underdeveloped that it gives an impression of an unfinished product that was prematurely rushed to the market.

GolemLabs, unfortunately, seems to have taken a significant step backwards with Superpower 3. Instead of building upon past experiences and rectifying issues from previous entries in the series, they seem to have regressed, delivering a game that is even less polished, immersive, and enjoyable than its predecessors.

In conclusion, Superpower 3 is a massive letdown. It feels incomplete, lacks engaging gameplay, and doesn't offer any semblance of the depth or complexity that one would expect from a game in this genre. Sadly, this game might very well be the final nail in the coffin for GolemLabs. Unless there's a significant overhaul and a multitude of improvements made post-release, it's hard to see any redemption for this title. A disappointing outcome for a game that had the potential to be so much more.

column8:
As someone who played the predecessor SuperPower 2 for over a thousand hours...

This game, whilst impressive in some regard visually, is very poor.

The map looks like a Paradox game with all the 3D buildings, a large deviation from the previous game which just used dots on the map, which I significantly dislike.

The controls are incredibly clunky, I couldn't even defeat Taiwan's military after nuking it with 16 ICBMs as China and fully occupying and annexing the country, what? Why are random helicopters and submarines still alive? Makes zero sense to me.

The UI is exaggerated and too large, SuperPower 2 was very quick and even dare I say simple compared to this, the layout is just too confusing here.

You can only build one unit design at once, China, which has one of the largest shipbuilding industries and largest steel industries in the world, can only build 10 destroyers (and nothing else, not tanks, not missiles, not infantry at the same time) at once.

There is no actual content, AI actions and decisions seem to be random, there's no event feed like in SP2 so you can't really tell what's going on.

Lots of world leaders are (no joke) just named John and Jane Doe, why do so many cultures lack names? This game was marketing itself on its character creation and demographics.

SuperPower 2 is significantly stronger gameplay wise and design wise than this hollow corporate money grab shell of a game.

I'm not developing mods for this, not until it gets significant patches.

column9: I'm buying SuperPower 2 now. I remember over a decade ago, a friend and I would squeeze into one computer, racking our brains trying to figure out how to retake Taiwan, and struggling to develop advanced fighter jets. Even when the domestic situation was stable, we wouldn't turn off the computer at night. Later, my friend even came up with a plan to invade other countries and then give away land to the US and Russia for free in exchange for goodwill. Giving away even a small piece of land would instantly give them 99% goodwill... That's how we conquered three powerful nations and divided the spoils, ultimately achieving world domination.

column8:
Unplayable. Maybe it will be fixed in the future, but definitely avoid the game now. 
Pros: 
- The whole cultural stuff (each culture has a bunch of affinities that make them like certain laws and ways of governing more or less) is pretty cool, I don't think any game tried anything similar before.
Cons: 
Everything else. Playing this game is like calling someone when you got poor connection - you barely can hear them, they barely can hear you, so the whole experience is just frustrating. The game is very poor at telling you what's going on and how your actions impact everything (or what is going to happen if you do change something), but from the bits you get back it seems like most of the things you do have no impact at all.
The only subsystem that works is your approval rating and stability (and budget, somewhat - balance does change when you change spending or tax level). Everything else feels static, like it's a placeholder. Visualizations are severely lacking: for example, you get time graphs of your population, approval and stability to track their dynamics, and... that's it. Where is GDP? Unemployment? Anything else? Prepare your paper and pen because you will need to draw your own graphs for anything other than population, approval and stability. Or actually don't because they don't seem to change, no matter what you do. Is it because I did something wrong? What can I do to make my GDP grow? Don't know, the game won't tell me. 
There are also things that just don't make sense. Like, why have a detailed character creation at the beginning of the game? What's the point of that? None of the other countries have characters, other parties in your country don't have characters as leaders, you don't have any kind of RPG elements where your avatar gets better at governing as time goes on. The game doesn't have any cutscenes or event pictures where your character appears. So WHY HAVE IT IN THE GAME?

Edit: even the achievements seem to be bugged. I started as Uruguay and immediately got "Breadbasket of the world", really?

column9:
I wanted to buy Super Power 3. I bought a cut-down version of Super Power 2.

With Super Power 2 as a base, they couldn't even make a copy with decent graphics.
1) They cut resource management (it's just remnants of SP2)
2) Political system (you can't interact with parties and governments, languages, or religions)
3) Terrible designer (few models, awkward stat-setting interface)
4) Bad interface (mobile game-style interface, large and awkward, sliders move slowly.)

The game is crude. It looks like it was made by some Vietnamese guys in a basement. I hope they improve it, but for now, I just dislike it.

column8: its like they took Superpower 2 and just made it worse and dumbed it down, practically nothing to do besides war, the war system is convoluted, tons of missing QOL features, game is slow, little to no influence over your nation, no cities anymore, bad UI, world looks bad, graphics are bad, pointless character system, no UN, limited diplomacy system, bugs out the ass, simple economic system, and more and more and more. Don't buy the game until its either been completely revamped or its less than $1. Seems like they rushed this to cash grab before Vicky 3 comes out. I encourage people to either wait for Vicky 3 or check out World Warfare and Economics.

column8:
No

SP2 had more content and that was very limited simulation.

1.  You don't get to change the sim speed.
2.  You don't get to make many economic choices.
3.  You barely get to change any laws.
4.  You do not get to pick a political party in your chosen nation.
5.  The world map is buggy sometimes it doesn't zoom all the way at all.
6.  Playing small nations is unplayable unless you like sitting around for days waiting on the one speed setting, some small 
     nations are impossible to do anything.
7.  The UI is just so unnecessarily big takes up 1/4th of the screen, looks like a mobile game.
8.  If you have wide screen prepare to play in only a window because you cannot change the resolution in full screen.
9.  Combat is a mess if you have a lot of units it can be nearly impossible to tell them apart.
10. Map themes to see demographics, resources, or nations doesn't work as soon as you click away it reverts back to 
      player borders only. Maybe I want to see all the nations in different colors the whole game so the earth doesn't look  
      like a black and white ball all the time.

I would not recommend this game till they fix these issues. Maybe they can contact the people who made Terra Invicta on how to optimize a simulation that game runs smoother and has the entire solar system.

First time playing this type of game and i have 95% approval on hard and i am making tons of money without using any guides. There is a severe lack of difficulty and things to do other than start wars. You can easily improve relations with other countries and get into an alliance with almost everyone and so far i have not seen any conflict in the game without starting it myself.
When Territorial.IO is a more realistic representation of the world than your management/wargame then you must have seriously dropped the ball.

Didnt know this series existed until 3 days ago and i was still disappointed.

column9:
It's just garbage when a game series resurfaces after years.

Returned Superpower 3 after 11 minutes... They took all the good features from the second game and turned it into a game without any depth. Every customizable section from the predecessor was removed, and only the military area has become slightly more customizable. The game feels like a tablet game where a developer threw together the settings in two hours...

Thumbs down and don't buy it.

column8:
Well this is sad
I was looking forward to this title as i'm a fan of the previous game but at launch this game sadly doesn't hold up due to performance issues, bugs and general lack of content.
i'm also disappointed at the lack of accessibility options like color blind modes.
while it is nice to see a series get a new entry after over a decade and a half this game is sadly not worth the price until some major updates come out

column9: The diplomatic interface is overly complex. It's unclear whether the area is completely controlled during the war. Troops are difficult to control and tend to mix with the airfield. The number of controlled troops is enormous and cannot be subdivided. There's currently no tutorial for beginners. It's a half-finished product (or even worse than a half-finished product). This game could be improved, although I haven't played its previous games.

column9: It's hard to believe this is the third installment in nearly 20 years. Some parts of the translation are incomplete, there are missing tutorials, the negotiations and battles are childish, the UI looks gorgeous but is actually shallow and meaningless, at least the second game reproduced many international organizations and agreements but they are not here, the time is only at 1x speed and pause, error pop-ups... Compared to the second game, it is an overstatement to call it a half-finished product, it should be 1/4 of the finished product.

column8:
This makes cyberpunk look great and even ignoring all the glitches, the political bias is real. For example; only 2 Irish socialist parties and no communist party... in Ireland, a country where 20% of the votes go to such parties. Absolutely pathetic reflection of political bias on a video game. The leader you create is a CIV 6 style immortal deity that rules the country for thousands of years if you played for that long, no one can replace him as head of the party. Speaking of the party; YOU CANT EVEN CHOSE WHICH PARTY YOU START AS!!!

The game itself is broken. It runs like crap and there is no way to limit FPS, so my gpu runs like crazy and the game runs slow. The AI just doesn't work, the game has no tutorial and it came out with ZERO information on the game or how to even play it. The features that do work slightly are just copy/pasted from super power 2, so I'm unimpressed there, but yet somehow Superpower 2 still works better. Also the camera constantly glitches out and you cannot move units unless you are at war, so when war happens you just have to let the enemy occupy your land before your units get to the border. Also, when you play Egypt and start as a white guy with Asian clothes and a french military hat named "john doe" by default, it kinda breaks the immersion and tells you not only how unpolished the game is, but how basic it is right away. the devs straight up lied about their "advanced mechanics", which don't even work. how was this released??????

When I said cyberpunk had a better release, I genuinely meant it. This game is PRE-ALPHA at best! That's what it feels like honestly. Just play superpower 2.

column8:
Well, where do I start? The game feels slow, military units barely move properly, city and town names won't appear, camera controls are really weird, the AI is weird, moving troops into a region with no troops of another country still starts a war even though it shouldn't, and many other issues. The game just feels broken and buggy. Is it terrible? Well, not exactly, but right now it feels below average. The new features are great, problem is they don't really work. A ferrari is great unless it has no wheels, then it's obviously not. SP3 has a lot of potential and could be great but it has way to many serious bugs that must be fixed within the next WEEK, otherwise this game will flop. I won't refund it, but I think the devs have some explaining and fixing to do.

One positive at least for now is the game looks pretty and they kept the globe. If they genuinely apologise and fix all these game breaking bugs and the lag, then I'll make this review positive and recommend this game. I can't do that now though, honestly. I hate to say this because I have so many great memories from SP2 and started playing it back in 2014 when I was 13 years old. I really hope they fix things and improve the game because it has SO MUCH potential to be even better than SP2.

column8:
My first time buying a game on release, also my last time buying a game on release. This game is beyond trash. I've never seen a game so empty, they couldn't even be asked to add in different speed timers. You have one speed time and that's it. I only played 23 minutes and the best part of the time spent was in their good character creation but that's it, Nothing else is good, every promotional pictures or video that doesn't showcase the character creation is a lie. Can't zoom into cities or anything else. You're stuck seeing one map, which is bland beyond believe. I know superpower 2 was like this but cmon, you gotta keep up with the tech of today. No excuses.

Don't buy this trash game, wait till I or someone else updates our reviews to give you better understanding if anything has changed.

column9: I've rambled on a lot; this game is worthless. The sequel might be a half-finished product but still playable, but this thing isn't even half-finished. It's incredibly GPU-intensive, the character models are horribly ugly, and it's riddled with bugs. Sometimes, for no apparent reason, your GDP just keeps dropping, no matter what you do to try and salvage it. Unemployment skyrockets, even when the population is growing and immigration isn't enabled, it just keeps declining until it reaches zero. Also, here's a little trick/bug: when playing as a small nation, you can ask a large nation for 60% of their funds unconditionally. Taking 1% of their funds will guarantee unification. When their funds exceed 30T, you can even ignore the relationship and directly ask for 20T.

column8: Game is broken. No tutorial whatsoever to explain how the game even works.  The UI is a complete mess and makes no sense whatsoever at times - whoever designed it really needs to go back and think again.  I could understand, and look past some of the issues, if the game were in Early Access, but for a full price game on full release it is a complete joke tbh.  I cannot fathom how this "game" even got through a testing phase and was deemed in an acceptable state for release.  So disappointed.  Do not waste your time or money.

column9: Expectations exceeded the content offered by SuperPower3. If we expect something like Supreme Ruler in terms of micromanagement of the country, we will be disappointed. The game is typically geared towards war, we manage the country politically and economically, but it's so, hmm, shallow in my opinion. I read that the second one is like that too, so the negative may be exaggerated, but these are my feelings about this game. I had too high expectations for it and I was hugely disappointed. For the money, Imo, it's not worth it, not at all. At half the price for multiplayer, it's probably fine for a purely military game.

column9:
My reunion with the Super Power series after 20 years was the worst.

There's no tutorial, which is considered a fundamental part of the game.

The UI on the main screen looks clean, but once you delve into each tab, it's cluttered to the point of being difficult to understand.

Even the combat, which could be considered an improvement from Super Power 2, is mediocre.

I'd rather have the one-hit-wonder combat of Super Power 2.

I was also deeply disappointed by the game's regressive gameplay in The Guild 3, a recent game from the same developer, and this one is no different.
I don't think there will be a sequel to The Guild 2 or Super Power 2, so I'll just relegate them to the distant past.

I don't think I'll ever buy another Golem Labs game again.

column8:
I would love to play this game. Shame that the stability of the game is straight up broken at release, I've been having constant crashes just by trying to get through the beginning of the menu. Even when I managed to avoid crashing by shrinking my window as small as it could get, I had to deal with confusing menus that straight up refuse to cooperate with you, some buttons don't even work and I'm left banging whatever keys are on my keyboard to make anything function. I could also tolerate the lack of tutorials and the lack of any semblance of help for me to know what i'm supposed to be doing, if the menus did not bug on me every chance it got. I kept fighting with the game to try and make it work instead of actually playing it, which as you can imagine makes this an unbearable experience. I gave up quickly in frustration.

Honestly, if you came for the sequel to SuperPower2, just stick with the old game. You'll just end up throwing your money away if you spend money in this game. You wan't a different society simulator? Check out Paradox's about to release game called Victoria 3, launching October 25th. Want a FUNCTIONAL society simulator now? Get Victoria 2 for cheaper instead of this sad excuse of a game.

column8:
this game is clunky and boring. the tabs are far to large and i cant have all of them up at once like i did in super power 2. Information is too hard to acquire (and most of it is just plain confusing) and there should be an information tab like in superpower 2 that gives you all the basic information. its also really hard to tell what certain things are happening. in super power 2 you had bars that would tell you if the population, infrastructure and other things were going up or down. in this game is just gives you numbers. the player creator is also dumb and doesn't make since in a game like this. who cares what i look like. it should not affect the game. the game also is just boring. it feels like nothing is actually happening. this is not superpower. this is a complete different game that is a buggy mess. 

Do not buy this.

El juego es un cofre que se ve muy bonito por fuera pero que estÃ¡ jodidamente vacÃ­o por dentro, espero que lo actualicen porque esto es una vergÃ¼enza, yo por mi parte he reembolsado el juego, mejor compraros victoria 3
column9:
I was hoping this game would be decent, a good geopolitical strategy game that might not be as deep as Power & Revolution, but at least wouldn't be a buggy mess. But no, they had to release a game with far less content than its 2004 predecessor! Budget sliders that don't even work, an economy you can't understand (though that was already the case in SuperPower 2), and riddled with bugs. The first time I opened the game, it wouldn't even let me select whether I wanted to play solo or in multiplayer because the damn menu hadn't loaded properly, and on top of that, it was terribly optimized.

The game is a treasure chest that looks beautiful on the outside but is completely empty on the inside. I hope they update it because this is a disgrace. I've already refunded my money; you're better off buying Victoria 3.

column9:
This is my first time playing this series, so I didn't have the expectations of a veteran player. Aside from a bug where dragging the globe causes lag or UI model errors, I haven't encountered any issues yet. I think I should give it a neutral rating, simply to acknowledge its relatively low price (compared to Paradox Interactive) and encourage future development.

However, it's clear this game is currently an unfinished product, much like Paradox Interactive, which seems to have learned from industry leaders. It's not just the lack of an effective tutorial; some details clearly indicate the developers' inadequate research. For example, China's nuclear capabilities are depicted as having a strike range that doesn't even extend beyond East Asiaâ€”I felt like I was going to stay in Bengbu looking at those three small circles. Then there's the classic map bias: Taiwan is practically a country, and South Tibet is unsurprisingly an Indian state...

Besides the sovereignty issue, the biggest problem is: where is the tutorial? Who's going to tell us how to play? As a new player to this series, all I could do was mechanically adjust various budget constraints, explore things like granting assembly rights and LGBT marriage recognition, check domestic support for the game to increase or decrease, and see if I could pressure smaller countries into signing treaties... Given the lack of clarity in various mechanics (and even with some updates, there's no speed-up function), I ultimately gave up and came to the comments section, only to find a sea of â€‹â€‹"not worth it."

I still have high hopes for this game's potential. If the publisher and development team can communicate with players promptly and take remedial measures like they did with *Earth Unbreakable*, I'll continue playing. My only fear is that the developers and team will simply disappear without a trace. I'll wait and see how things develop before deciding whether to revise my review or request a refund.

I suspect today is a rehearsal for the 25th; V3 might just repeat everyone's anger from today...

column8:
Edit edit: The devs haven't updated the game since January and the Discord has gone cold. The game is dead, do not buy.

I have been really excited about this game since it was announced, but I did my best to keep my expectations in check. Turns out, nothing could have prepared me for this release. The game is basically Super Power 2 Re-skinned, which I actually do not think is a bad thing in the slightest. Being able to get the Super Power 2 gameplay on a modern engine is great. However, the game is so immensely bugged that the game is unenjoyable.

* After concurring all the regions of a nation, they still exist and you are put in a permanent war with them in the diplomacy tab
* Every new year starts at 1/0/20XX
* Troops Randomly Appear and Disappear
* SEEMS FIXED - Troops sometime don't move
* FIXED - Many logos and icons are missing and are replaced with just a checker board
* You can only take one territory per treaty (meaning you have to make many separate treaties to conquer a nation)
* Even at low settings the game seems to lag (might be a hardware problem on my part)
* FIXED - The lack of speed controls is really annoying
* FIXED - The most units you can build at a time is only 10,000 which is basically nothing
* You can't tell your troops to occupy a country's territory (like in SP2)
* Trades in Pending Trades menu are missing text
* Thematic map reverts back to standard after clicking another nation
* SEEMS FIXED - Previous troop movement lines remain after troops finish moving
* KINDA FIXED - (Now they show your flag instead) Capital flags of conquered nations persist after their downfall
* Multiplayer is extremely laggy
* Investing the in economy causes GDP to decrease (might be intentional to show the lowering of profits, not sure)

Things I like:
* The new "battle zone" tactical maps
* The New UI
* The Character Creator

I will update this review if any of these problems get fixed (Which I truly hope that they will), or if I find more. I just wish the game would have been developed more, or at least released in Early Access, big disappointment...

Edit: The devs have been keeping us in the loop and have been releasing patches every week. I highly recommend joining the discord to keep an eye on what's going on. I will be changing my review to positive after I believe the game is mostly playable.

Horrible. Everything is a mess except the character editor, which is completely useless in the gameâ€”a shame, since it's the only good thing about it.
Seriously, everything else is a complete disaster. My graphics card gets hotter than it did with Cyberpunk, even though the graphics are on par with an average game from 2005.
SuperPower 2 is better (even though you can't play in full screen and therefore can't see the whole game). There's only one musical theme that repeats every 10 seconds. There's only one game speed. You can't pause with the spacebar; everything has to be done with the mouse (in 2022, yes...).

column8: UI is bulky, start out a Liberal Party of Canada (Canada) without option to change your political party, the game seems more generalised with respect to taxes, inflation, industry changes.  Thought it would be more specific.  For instance, legalizing drugs is only available across drugs in general, can't specify types of drugs, uses, research etc.  Graphics seem cheap looking too, zooming into cities show these sims cheesy buildings, instead on more map and statistical specific information.  I played SP2 for a while and actually found the UI for SP2 better and not as blown up. Feels like a game you would play on your phone.  Avoid imo.

column8:
In short: Until it is fixed, avoid it.

I annexed Baja California as America peacefully and although that caused Mexico to go to war with me, they did not actually make an effort to defend their country, nor did the rest of the world react according to the bugged diplomatic relations view. So I have to think the AI is broken. I honestly preferred looking at the plain battle menu from SP2 than the laggy clusterf**k that it is now. I can't even comprehend what's going on most of the time. Even so much as adjusting your budget sliders causes the game to slow to a crawl. The MP server list is broken and I can't find games because they appear for a second then just vanish. How can they mess up something as crucial to SuperPower as multiplayer? Icons missing, the game UI not caring what you put in the character creator, crashes. There is also a server application that launches with the game that eats your resources worse than joshua_server ever did. 

The list goes on and on, and these are the things I noticed in the first hour. Don't buy it.

Lots of bugs
No consequences for invading or annexing
AI seems non-existent? (Russia declared war on Ukraine and neither side did anything for over 2 years)
Don't like the lack of speed controls
UI is bad, it either tells you nothing or looks like a unity passion project

column8:
Ich bin extrem enttÃ¤uscht

Ich hatte so groÃŸe Hoffnungen, dass dieses Spiel eine annehmbare Konkurrenz zu Power & Revolution ist. Doch dieses Spiel hat kaum eine Tiefe. Man klickt auf ein paar KnÃ¶pfe, verÃ¤ndert minimal etwas, doch die meiste Zeit kann man gar nichts machen. Das Lustigste an dem Spiel ist es, die Atombomben abzufeuern, aber das war es dann auch schon. Ich weiÃŸ nicht, ob dies wirklich das End-Resultat sein soll, aber es ist viel zu wenig Inhalt. Die Community hat so lange auf dieses Spiel gewartet und herausgekommen ist ein Spiel, welches einem vorkommt, als wÃ¤re es innerhalb eines Monats gemacht worden.
Ich kann es gar nicht fassen, wie unfassbar enttÃ¤uscht ich bin... Holt euch Power & Revolution lieber, auch wenn das seine eigenen Probleme hat.
column9:
I'm extremely disappointed.

I had such high hopes that this game would be a worthy competitor to Power & Revolution. But this game has hardly any depth. You click a few buttons, change a few things minimally, but most of the time you can't do anything at all. The most fun thing about the game is launching the atomic bombs, but that's about it. I don't know if this is really supposed to be the final product, but there's far too little content. The community waited so long for this game, and what we got is a game that feels like it was made in a month.

I can't even begin to describe how incredibly disappointed I am... You're better off getting Power & Revolution, even though it has its own problems.

column8: dÃ©Ã§u, il y a tellement de truc qui vont pas on dirait que le jeu est pas fini et qu'il reste 30% du jeu Ã  faire, l'interface en jeu est horrible on dirait un jeu mobile c'est tellement gros Ã§a prend tout lâ€™Ã©cran a chaque fois que j'ouvre un truc je sais pas ou regarder il y a trop d'espace vide, il y a moins de contenu que sur superpower 2, Ã§a fait plusieurs annÃ©es que j'attends le jeu jâ€™espÃ¨re vraiment que les devs vont se rattraper, le jeu aurait du sortir bien plus tard ou pas Ã  ce prix la (30 euros mais actuellement il est Ã  27 euros avec la promo) bref si vous voulez le jeu attendez avant de l'acheter sinon vous allez Ãªtre dÃ©Ã§u et trouver Ã§a nul alors que le 2 Ã©tait incroyable
column9: Disappointed. There are so many things wrong; it feels like the game isn't finished and there's still 30% left to do. The in-game interface is awful; it looks like a mobile game. It's so big it takes up the whole screen. Every time I open something, I don't know where to look; there's too much empty space. There's less content than in Superpower 2. I've been waiting for this game for years. I really hope the developers will make up for it. The game should have been released much later, or not at this price (30 euros, but currently it's 27 euros with the promotion). In short, if you want the game, wait before buying it, otherwise you'll be disappointed and think it's rubbish, whereas the second one was incredible.

column9: I had no idea, but this is truly the worst game ever. From the bug where you are suddenly moved to the main screen and cannot do anything when spinning the globe, to the UI, graphics, optimization, everything is a total mess. I can't understand how they decided to release it. It seems like it was hastily made by a college student as a group project. It's not just disappointing, it's so miserable that I'm speechless. It's not a disappointment that feels like a flop, it's just that it was made with such a lack of sincerity that it's shocking.

column9: All that's left of the second superpower is the name. There are no convenient maps, no multitude of resources, just ONE! speed, and damn, the IMPOSSIBILITY TO CHANGE THE RULING REGIME. The game positions itself as "have fun with geopolitics," but you can't even change the regime... Plus, they say the AI â€‹â€‹in the game is weak, right down to the lack of reaction to a fucking NUCLEAR STRIKE. Basically, the game isn't worth it, it's not worth a hundred rubles, don't buy this nonsense. I'm refunding my money. But at least we have the option to create a character who essentially has no effect on gameplay, and the priority system is fantastic...

column8:
Boring, get ready to wait kind of game.
Major:
Feels like nothing is ever happening.
Mix of very micro and very macro control, little in between
No fast forward
Minor:
No pause keybind, very few keybind altogether despite being made in Unreal which should have this built in
UI is generic but functional
No queueing most tasks
Very minor:
No ultrawide support

I would say 20$ for people who really like this kind of game, $10 for those who only kind of like it. With a bunch of patches I could see it closer to it's current price, but it'll probably get abandoned before then.

column9:
No... what the heck... what's going on...
Where is the highly anticipated game I've been counting the days for 18 years, checking its release date every day since it was announced last year? Did we expect too much? I would have been satisfied if it had just made a few improvements and fixed some bugs in Super Power 2...

What the heck is this?
It's as heartbreaking and miserable as seeing a child you've raised with love and care for 18 years grow up to be an Ilbe resident.

I've bought dozens of games on Steam, but this is the first time I've written a review like this.
Dear developers? Have you ever played Super Power 2? You 10-year-olds... Don't you have a mom?

column8:
Insanely limited. Super easy and no real challenge to anything. I was playing as the US and I banned ethnic groups, nationalized all news, shut off the internet, raised income tax to 100%, and started a nuclear that killed 2b+ people. No opposition, no riots/protests, I wasnt removed, in fact, I was still beloved by the people. 

I hate the map. I hate the war. This is at best a bar sliding simulator.

column9:
1. The controls weren't explained in detail.
2. Despite being a 22-year-old game, it doesn't perform as well as it appears in the video, and the quality is even worse than Super Power 2.
3. While Super Power 2 allows you to speed up the game, Super Power 3 doesn't.
4. The tutorial should have been more engaging and more realistic.
5. Despite being 3D, there are many comparisons to Super Power 2.
1) The battle screen is more streamlined than Super Power 2.
2) Regardless of which missile you're firing, even with optimization, you'll experience immediate lag.
3) If you scroll down to the loading screen to look up information online and then re-open Super Power 3,
the game will crash even though you're playing single player.

column8:
Pretty serious game play issues at launch, which is disappointing. The AI is a cold fish, you could annex large parts of another country without eliciting a response, and the game does not have time acceleration controls (so you're stuck at the same speed for the entire game, which is rather slow).

Disappointment on launch, but it is still Superpower. I will keep an eye on it, I just hope THQ doesn't decide to can the game and works to fix the core issues with it.

column8:
AVOID AVOID AVOID!

This is unacceptable if it were early access
This is unacceptable even if it were early beta

The only positive thing I can say is it technically runs, and the documentation of features is excellent. But it endlessly glitches, there's little to no feedback on your interactions with it, unless you are keeping a complete spreadsheet of absolutely everything, there is no tracking of what anything you do is having any impact on or if it's making something better or worse.

I have seen better tech demos than this with more player feedback and information tracking

wow, that was terrible and embarrassing to play. 

as soon as i loaded in i had a big warning pop up on my screen. when you actually get into the game you realize theres literally nothing to do. and i mean nothing except look at some sliders. wanna make weed illegal or legal? just flick the slider. no parliament necessary. organising my army is another absolute mess. diplomacy is clunky and the game hardly tells you about random values and stats. or they'll tell you what it is but not tell you the scale that it is measured on. I mean... you guys could have waited to release this until it was polished and literally nobody would have noticed or cared. but you guys knew what you were doing. waste of money, will be refunding as i dont even see myself playing this game for another minute. 

Ladies and Gentlemen, the most boring Geo-Political game to date.

Pues no puedo recomendar este  juego por varios motivos:

Tecnicamente:

1. Ya nada empezar no he podido abrirlo, aunque reintentadolo lo he logrado, pero no es un buen comienzo.

2. No se ve en resoluciones altas, es decir el juego da la opciÃ³n de ponerlo en 4K pero luego no lo muestra en pantalla.

3. Mal optimizado, lento, lag, bugs, etc...

En fin, de momento muy mal lanzado, como viene siendo  habitual por parte de la gran mayorÃ­a de las compaÃ±Ã­as desarrolladoras.

En lo personal:

Se queda muy corto en simulaciÃ³n polÃ­tica, a penas hay opciones en lo que a politica se refiere. En investigaciÃ³n militar estÃ¡ bien detallado, pero es tanta la diferencia entre una parte de la simulaciÃ³n y otra, que basicamente acaba siendo un juego para atacar otra  naciÃ³n y poco mÃ¡s, asÃ­ que si vas buscando un juego donde puedas tocar todos los palos de un gobierno, tan solo encontrarÃ¡s militar y un poquito de industria, por lo demÃ¡s es nulo.

Es una lastima porque estuve muy pendiente de este juego y le tenÃ­a ganas, pero o lo arreglan mucho o serÃ¡ otro fracaso.

saludos.
column9:
I can't recommend this game for several reasons:

Technically:

1. I couldn't even open it from the start, although I managed to get it working after trying again, but it's not a good start.

2. It doesn't display in high resolutions. The game gives you the option to set it to 4K, but then it doesn't show it on screen.

3. Poorly optimized, slow, laggy, buggy, etc.

In short, a very poor launch so far, as is typical for most development companies.

Personally:

It falls very short in political simulation; there are hardly any political options. Military research is well-detailed, but the difference between one part of the simulation and another is so great that it basically ends up being a game about attacking another nation and little else. So, if you're looking for a game where you can explore all aspects of government, you'll only find military and a little bit of industry; otherwise, it's nonexistent.

It's a shame because I was really looking forward to this game, but unless they fix it drastically, it'll be another flop.

Regards.

column8:
I loved SP. I loved SP2. I went into this knowing that the SP series was always leaning more in the direction of geopolitical wargames with little domestic politics and diplomacy. And even so, this is just... wow.

As a tech demo, a pre- or early alpha, this would have shown a lot of potential. But as a finished game? No way. And I am not talking about No Man's Sky style lack of content - there is nothing resembling a serious gameplay loop here. I used to be a voluntary tester for other grand strategy games by another publisher, and let me tell you: their earliest test releases had a lot more going on than this released game.

I'll add a few issues I posted about in the community forum just to illustrate what kinds of issues I am talking about:

1. The world feels very passive. It doesn't seem like the AI is doing much or that there's even an AI at all. Someone else reported the AI not responding even to a nuclear attack, and I can confirm that.

2. That leads into the other major issue: information. The game does not give you any meaningful information about what's going on around the world, and if it does, it's just a very dry, small notification on the respective area of the screen. If you're used to Paradox titles where there's always something happening somewhere in the world and you can follow along, this is not doing a great job.

3. Add ot that lack of meaningful information about your own nation. The game tells you that unemployment is due to population groups preferring to work in industries that are underdeveloped, but it doesn't tell you *which* population groups or *which* industries. In general, you don't get a very good idea of what is going on in your country, making it really hard to make informed decisions.

This also affects diplomacy: Good luck finding out where the game shows you another country's opinion of yours, and good luck figuring out if another country is likely to accept your proposal or what your proposal even does. Diplomacy is *technically* there, but is not usable at all.

4. Finally, I've noticed there's a distinct lack of customization. Which is baffling, because they spent all the dev time on choosing a hat for my avatar, but I can't even name or choose my party? I can however name treaties and unit designs (a feature I don't think works reliably right now), but I'd rather be able to change information about my country such as its name or, getting really crazy here, flag.

5. Oh, and on another footnote: yes, there's only one game speed, no, pause is not bound to space, and most irritatingly, typing (e.g. when naming the aforementioned treaties) *triggers camera movement*, so the game doesn't even lock keyboard input to a text box when editing one. That's easily fixed, but screams "rushed" like little else.

It doesn't add anything the community waited for years, and it even lacks some very important features of its predecessor. The UI is one of the worst I have ever seen. It is even buggier than the predecessor which came out in 2004. Haven't any people over THQ or Golemlabs ever played the game a little bit? Because if they had, they would know that the game is not ready to be released. I am very sad.

column8: Seems to be in a bit of a mess. I saved my character I created yet the button to reload it doesn't work. There seems to be multiple icon glitches where icons become blank checkered images for no reason. I've just put the UK's income tax to 100% and it's had no effect at all and I waited quite a while so I'm raking in trillions. Seems somewhat glitchy, I dunno how to describe it and tbh I'm bored already cos I don't see anything noticeable happening when I drastically alter stats so I've changed loads of stats, notice no difference and now I'm sat here wondering what to do next. In it's current state it's a bit questionable whether it's worth buying, they need to fix the issues like icons going missing for a start. I'm contemplating a refund already and I've only played 45 minutes.

Do not buy.

Don't buy it. If you buy this game as a memory of playing Super Power 2, it's better to watch Gukppong TV
The optimization is rice, the aircraft carrier cuts through the ground, and the tanks travel over the sea
It's not 30 dollars, but it's hard to buy even if you sell it for 3 dollars
It's a genre that's hard to simulate strategies, but there's no tutorial, there's no speed in the previous work, and it's actually degraded
The previous one came out in 2002 and this one came out in 2022, so I think this company's development has deteriorated for 20 years
It might get better with the patch, but it's a big blow to the back of my head after waiting until dawn
column9:
Don't buy it. If you're buying this game to reminisce about playing Super Power 2, you'd be better off watching nationalistic TV. The optimization is a mess, and aircraft carriers rip through land and tanks sail across the sea. Even if this game were sold for 3,000 won, not 30,000 won, I'd hesitate to buy it. While strategy simulation is a challenging genre, there's no tutorial, no multi-speed mechanics like in the previous game, and it's actually a step backwards. The previous game came out in 2002, and this one comes out in 2022, so this company's development skills seem to have regressed over the past 20 years. Patches might improve things, but this is a huge slap in the face for someone who waited until dawn to buy it.

Don't buy it. If you buy this game as a memory of playing Super Power 2, it's better to watch Gukppong TV
The optimization is rice, the aircraft carrier cuts through the ground, and the tanks travel over the sea
It's not 30 dollars, but it's hard to buy even if you sell it for 3 dollars
It's a genre that's hard to simulate strategies, but there's no tutorial, there's no speed in the previous work, and it's actually degraded
The previous one came out in 2002 and this one came out in 2022, so I think this company's development has deteriorated for 20 years
It might get better with the patch, but it's a big blow to the back of my head after waiting until dawn

column9:
I don't recommend it. 10/10 crap.
So many years have passed, the developers have gotten completely lazy and couldn't even make the unit models match real prototypes (we're not asking for high-poly models, are we?). It's like I'm playing a cheap version of Hearts of Iron V.
- The units are all the same, and those are from World War II; some are more modern.
- If you were hoping to design your own unit model, you're sorely mistaken. It doesn't even have that; it's just crap.
- The nuclear explosion effect is worse than C&C Generals 2000. Even SuperPower 2 looked better.

10/10 crap.

column8:
Okay so,

First off, the Streaming of the game play yesterday did this title zero favours. Whoever made the decision to allow a copy of the game which was 400 builds behind to be live streamed made a mistake.

The character creation is a nice touch, makes you think and get involved with it characteristics of the nation you pick to play as. I like this and rarely see stuff like this in game.

The Steam page states 'SuperPower 3 is tailor-made for all the megalomaniacs out there who are convinced they can do a much better job at running the world than real politicians and military leaders across the globe'. That's a rather bold statement for a game that has 5 or 6 laws you can change for a whole country...., 

Overall the game in its current state is incredibly basic and lacks any depth in regards to the actual management and running of a country. No parliaments behind a leader etc, why? Even the excuse of the focus is around you and your characters decisions doesn't make much sense. It takes away the feeling of running a country, that which you are describing in the games description. Where are the ministers, the scandals that come with the running of a country?

The game isn't a write off, I personally feel it will be good in time but looks to be missing alot. Overall 5/10. Product refunded.

column8:
- Broken UI elements
  - missing national flag graphics during battle
  - unit movement trails never clear
  - units sporadically invisible
- No informational overlay maps of any kind
- Can't tell what's happening in battle areas
- Can't zoom in very far at all, not even as far as the screenshots show
- No option to change political party or make serious changes to form of government, much shallower than Superpower 2

Reeks of development crunch. Sorry GolemLabs, but I don't know what happened with this one. I'll check back in on you in a few months, okay?

column9:
Don't buy this garbage.

There's no multi-speed mode, and it's ridiculously laggy.

Each page seems to have a lot of content, but it's actually more rudimentary than a browser game. If Super Power 2 was already rough, then Super Power 3 is a half-cut version of the second.

The character creation system could be completely removed. This part is entirely unnecessary for the game, and the character models are terrible. I thought it would be like Tropico where you create a character with strengths and weaknesses, but currently, you can't see your created character anywhere except on the character creation page. In other words, they've made a purely gimmicky feature while making the game itself a mess.

I've requested a refund. The overall content and playability are even worse than some casual games, like Sunrise.

I rarely find a game that makes me want to swear after less than an hour, but this one absolutely has to.

After entering the game, the few bars at the bottom of the UI are your main operation options. The world map doesn't have the interactive or provincial information pop-up when you click on another player's territory like in similar games. It just lights up briefly and then disappears.

All the interaction relies on those few bars at the bottom. Once you click them, the overall gameplay experience is like a garbage browser game, worse than that free Cold War political browser game made by the French, or that kind of "simulation management" browser game from 2008 in China.

Clicking on the military page just shows huge soldier models, laughable.

No tutorials, no guidance, just a jumbled mess of buttons, a few "Off" and "On" switches, and a budget bar.

It's truly laughable. THQ should just go back to the grave. They've published so many pieces of garbage in a row. Now, seeing THQ as a publisher makes me uneasy; it's likely to be another piece of garbage.

The graphics aren't better than the second game, the content is less, and the optimization is worse. I suggest renaming it "Super Power 1.5".

column8:
I didn't have high expectations, but I didn't think it could be this bad - This game is AWFUL. It is nowhere near the quality of SP2 and I have requested a refund.

The game is clunky, has so many user faces which add nothing and you can't change anything in them. The military interface is shocking and very unclear. As far as I can see, it doesn't even include basics such as memberships of differing organisations such as the EU.

Feels like a university students graphic design project - looks good but no functionality. 

Probably best for some more unofficial updates to SP2.
