column9:
The UI is too cluttered.
I think a classic, text-heavy design would have been more readable.
They tried to make it look like a modern game by adding infographics and trying to look sophisticated, but instead, it ended up looking like a cheap, indie-like UI.

The optimization is quite poor. Crashes seem frequent.

I had my concerns, but I'm a bit disappointed even before I've actually played the game.

It feels like a newly released Early Access game. It needs some hotfixes.

column8: I am leaving a negative review for now, because the game can easily be fixed and i believe it will be, what made sp2 great was the complete accuracy of the economy, simple UI where you could simply see a bar of full numbers, either red or green to analyze how well your nation is doing, however in SP3 there is none of that no colour, no big number, just rounded up blank white numbers that mean nothing, i have absolutely no clue how to manage the economy (which is bad because SP2s economy was terrifyingly hard to grasp) which i believe will be an absolute nightmare for new players who have never heard of this series before and have never touched the economy aspect of the game. Another issue i had is the complete flooding of screens, again what was better in SP2 was that everything was nice and small and easy to navigate nothing ever jumped out at you and made you completely confused. And for my final note is that the game is terrifyingly terrible in the war aspect, when i takeover a territory i do not actually know what i have taken, because apparently that aspect needed to be removed, there is no highlight to what i have taken. Moving units is also especially hard, i can no longer drag to move units, again why that aspect was removed i will never know. The game will however be fixed in my opinion, if you're looking for a modern version of HOI4 i believe this game suits you, however this is not in the Hearts of Iron series this is a superpower game and i believe the devs need to realize this.

Made with toes?
This thing would stutter even with a quantum computer.
The basics are no speed, the UI is crappy, and what's the point of character customization? It's not even worth seeing in-game. The previous game, Super Power 2, from 18 years ago, was more fun.

column8:
DAY ONE LAUNCH: Ok, so they have some things to fix, Character Editor, is broke...it "fails to save customized character". The in Depth part of this is, from what i saw, shallow, like REALLY shallow. Does it meet the "Best of 2022"? No. 
Does it match best in show for "2015"? No. 
I'm not super impressed, not really super disappointed either. It is what Superpower 2 was, just unpolished and WAY overdue and outdated. So take this, as it is. Just being real. Recommended, sure, I guess. Maybe?

Update:8/21/23
So after almost a year, this now can be classified as what all games of recent memory have become; a complete and total dumpster fire, except this one seems to be abandoned. Congrats on the Scam and fooling everyone around your game, so THQ... You're FIRED! I will never give you a dime, until you prove that you can be trusted again. Thanks for the memories.

column8:
Okay so the UI is terrible so far, the UI is far too large, it takes up way too much space. The sliders barely function. You can no longer see what percentage each party has in your country. The singleplayer requires a connection ( my internet cut out and it told me "Disconnected from server" when I was in a singleplayer game. The multplayer takes far too long to do anything, messages take minutes to send, Decisions you make take minutes to take effect. and overall the game lacks many features and polish that were in SP2. Overall this is a massive let down and Im going to give it a day before I request a refund.

The game lacks so many features I do not know what to suggest, Firstly instead of excusing lazyness with " for the sake of simpclity" Show us what percentage each party and the party in power has in the nation played. It showed you it in Superpower 2 so you shouldnt excuse not adding a feature for " simplcity" Secondly. In SP2 theres a " more info" button that shows you all the current land you own. Population details, Terrarin details, A description of said nation and its basic summary of information relating to information. education and so on. Also the fact that you can not change the countries government type to what you want like you could in SP2 is dissapointing. You can also no longer chose a party of the nation you want to begin with like you could in SP2. Its just all really really sad to see features removed. Its pure laziness and it should not be excused what so ever.

column8:
Short review for my short play time.

I had high hopes for the game. I hoped it would be comparable to SP2 but no.
Shortly before its release I heard it was pretty bad from ppl who watched someone stream it.
I thought: "Aw come on, it canÂ´t be that bad!" (It was worse)

Firstly, a major offence imo: ItÂ´s SLOW
Not performance wise but you can only play on 1 speed that moves 1 day forward every 2 or 3 seconds.
Graphics look ok. Map itself is allright but if you zoom in everything just looks bland.
The bugs it has are bugs that shouldnÂ´t exist like icons missing, glitchy UI, different mapmodes not working.
It is not a finnished game. Nowhere near that. It would need another year for it to be playable.
I had more fun playing Cyberpunk on release.

Pls fix the game. I waited 15 years for a successor of SP2. I can wait another 5.

column9:
This game still has many bugs and many shortcomings.
The first bug you'll encounter is usually the resolution bug.
You won't be able to change the resolution in Options - Settings.

First, switch to windowed mode to activate the resolution change option.
After that, set the resolution, and then switch back to full screen.

As a bonus, I'm using a 3080ti, and the graphics card fan is spinning like crazy. It's amazing how much the graphics card is demanding... Even when I played other high-spec games, the fan didn't spin like this.

Furthermore, it seems poorly optimized, with poor frame rates. There are some stuttering issues.

This is a crappy game that only allows resolution adjustment in windowed mode. There's also no tutorial.

Those who have played the original Super Power 2 will probably enjoy it to some extent, but beginners will find it a bit challenging.

There's no game speed control.

The UI is in Korean, and while the translation quality isn't perfect, it's still decent.

The game still has a lot of bugs and is lacking in many ways.

It's currently on a 10% launch sale, but in my humble opinion, it's a bit... I think it'll only become worth playing once some bug fixes are made.

Summary: Currently, it's worse than its predecessor, Superpower 2.

column9:
1. The variable expenditure chute is so damn hard to pull! Please optimize it quickly, thank you.

2. Please add the time acceleration/deceleration function as soon as possible.

3. Unifying Taiwan was a complete rout; surrounding countries didn't even flinch, and there were no trade bans or sanctions. If it were really that easy, without sanctions, mainland China would have been unified long ago. If the game wants to portray itself as a game about great power diplomacy, it should add reasonable war penalties.

4. The begging system absolutely needs to be changed. Doing nothing, just being an international beggar, and you get 2-3 terabytes of starting capital in no time. Even Ukraine would be calling you "master."

column8:
I was skeptical of this game from the beginning, seeing as there was absolutely 0 gameplay footage right up until release. The one streamer they gave the game to was terrible, and playing on an outdated build. 

It didn't take long in playing SuperPower 3 that my fears were confirmed. This is a hollow, buggy, poorly designed mobile game if anything. Nothing seems to flow together, the music is cheap and annoying, and most importantly the game just feels empty. Things don't make sense, and seem like there was 0 thought put into any components of the game. Just as an example, there are flags placed on the globe for various countries, but it's a top down game with no option to adjust so you can't even see the flag. You're just looking at the top of a flagpole. Small, but anecdotal of a whole bunch of other lazy design choices or overlooked areas of the game.

 I know SuperPower games are what you make of it, but even then it's hard to get any enjoyment out of this game. 

I genuinely believe this game must've been slated for 2023, but rushed to release because of Victoria 3 coming out soon. I'm refunding this game- and perhaps I'll pick it up again maybe next year, but I definitely have a sour taste in my mouth.

column9:
This is a terrible game, incomparable to its predecessor.
The red-light system and UI are completely incomprehensible, and the tutorial is nowhere to be found.
I wish they had invested more manpower in the core game itself, rather than wasting it on unnecessary details.
Honestly, I regretted the time I've lost waiting for this game, and if others are considering buying it because they're thinking of playing Super Power 2, I recommend not buying it.
This is a fucking idiot game.

>> + The company's attitude of not even sharing proper in-game trailer information and telling you to try it out yourself... It's outrageous.

column9:
I can tell even after just 30 minutes of playtime.
This game is garbage.

The UI shows signs of minimalism, but it's extremely unintuitive and inconsistent, leading to user fatigue.
The combat is a step down from Superpower 2, with no tutorial or speed-up function.
The nuclear war, Superpower's main content, also has very poor graphics.
Do not play this. Not recommended.

Looking closely, Victoria 3 is coming out at the end of October, so I suspect they released it early because they were worried sales would plummet if it was released later.

Let's just go play Victoria 3.
I waited for 10 years, but all I got was a bunch of data.

column8:
I waited 8 years for this shit?

This game is pretty rough. Half the leaders are named John/Jane Doe. I cannot change my screen resolution past 1024x768. I have a 1200 dollar computer and the game runs like ass. And overall this looks like an unfinished buggy mess. You can not create new unit designs in the form of actually designing the model of your units. The AI can also be unresponsive, I walked right into territory most of the time and the country I invaded just let me take their land. I have also seen very basic grammatical issues as well. (Not a grammar nazi but some of these are just plain bad.) 

I do not intend to find out what else is wrong with this game as I have seen enough in the rough 30 minutes I have played to figure out I will not enjoy this game and will regret buying it.

Do yourself a favor, stick to Superpower 2 and wait for them to get their shit together with this game.

column9:
Back in elementary school, when copyright wasn't even a thing, I had so much fun playing it. Now that elementary schooler is almost an egg-laying child, I was thrilled to hear that Superpower 3 was coming out...

However, the saying that memories should be left as memories comes to mind. The crappy UI makes you wonder if this is a game from 2022. The immersion factor is insanely low for a game that requires reading and interpreting information. And the unfriendly gameplay...

If you want to relive those memories, just play Part 2 again.

column8:
No. 
No content. 
Broken game.
sliders that don't function properly. 
Super computer and the game still runs like dogwater, janky and very poor performance.
combat is an absolute joke. I'd laugh if it were funny.
This honestly looks like something you could whip up in about a month or two with minimal staff working on the game. 
one speed only and no option to speed it up or down.

even ignoring the bugs which are pretty staggering there is just nothing to do. Might be good in a year or two but it needed a delay, they only released it early so victoria 3 wouldn't body them and it seems like they just wanted to cut their losses. 

It's very sad because i enjoy niche games like this but outside of just memeing around with a friend (assuming the mp even works) there is currently nothing to do in game, and this won't even hold a candle to victoria 3 when it launches later this month. 

Just buy victoria 3 instead.

column9:
This is a mobile clicker.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xalZGISIdZ0
When I watched the game trailers, I realized that I really wanted to play this game. It sounded like a good and interesting strategic political simulator. But what do we actually have?

Of course, I hope that the developers will still manage to fix the game and in a few weeks or months I will check again if something is fixed in the game. But in short, it is not worth playing this game in its current state. Yes, of course, you can play a little and then get a refund if you don't like the game. Well, I would recommend another idea: use the refund option later, when there are new patches and fixes.

The first thing I noticed was that there were no tutorials. That will probably be in the first days after the release. There are a lot of sliders, buttons and folders, but very little useful information about how it works. But the influence of various parameters is strange and almost always none. For example, when I played for the Czech Republic, I set a 100% tax on wages and, in addition, completely omitted all options for the development and stability of the country from the budget. That lasted two years. And as a result, support from citizens more than 50% and then I won the elections.

Well, ok, maybe the game has a problem only with internal politics? But, unfortunately, no. Developing relations is very simple here. If you want good relations, you can just offer other countries to open an embassy, â€‹â€‹then have cultural exchange, and joint development. And that's solved. Now you can have an alliance treaty. It works so strangely that when I played for North Korea, I omitted all restrictions inside the country, then very quickly I got an alliance treaty with Germany and we also had an agreement that my army can be in Germany. I played on normal difficulty.

I also don't understand how wars work here. There are pictures of soldiers on the map, but I always had bugs with them. They often disappeared from the map and reappeared. The fighting process is automatic and not interesting.

When you look at SuperPower 3, it looks like a good game for mobile, when you don't know what to do in the evening and want to conquer the world. There is also a strange moment with this. The developers write that this game is not only about wars, but we can also play for the economic development of countries. But all the scenarios are about wars. 

I really hope that the game will be fixed somehow. But today, unfortunately, it's not worth it.
